query: Arabian horses are susceptible to several genetic disorders, including severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) $^{2}$ , which also occurs in humans. In Arabian horses, the disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion $^{3}$ , fatal in homozygotes but asymptomatic in heterozygous carriers. Foals with SCID are born completely lacking an immune system, like the 'bubble boy,' and typically succumb to opportunistic infection before the age of 3 months (ref. 2). Since the development of a DNA test to detect the mutation in healthy carriers $^{4}$ , however, horses can now be screened before mating to minimize the number of foals born with SCID $^{5}$ .
response: Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) occurs in Arabian horses (as in humans) and is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait: homozygous foals are born without an immune system and typically die from opportunistic infections before 3 months of age, while heterozygous carriers show no symptoms. A DNA test can identify healthy carriers, allowing pre-mating screening to reduce the number of SCID-affected foals.

query: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) (Kata) (Goat plague) is one of the most important viral diseases of small ruminant husbandry (Kabir et al., 2019). The etiological agent of this disease is small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV), which belongs to the Morbillivirus genus and the Paramyxoviridae family (Waret-Szkuta et al., 2008). Currently, PPR is endemic in many countries in Africa, the Middle East and South Asia, and there is concern about its spread in Europe (Constable et al., 2016; Mantip et al., 2022). Infection rates during outbreaks are high (above $50 - 90\%$) in endemic areas. Case fertility rate of the disease is $55 - 85\%$ in goat and less than $10\%$ in sheep (Constable et al., 2016).
response: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR), also called Kata or goat plague, is a major viral disease of small ruminants caused by small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV) in the genus *Morbillivirus* (family *Paramyxoviridae*). It is currently endemic in many countries in Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia, with concern about potential spread to Europe. Outbreaks in endemic areas have high infection rates (about 50–90%). The case fatality rate is 55–85% in goats and less than 10% in sheep.

query: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP) are a diverse group of evolutionary conserved peptides with a broad range of antimicrobial and immunomodulatory functions (Brogden et al., 2003; Zasloff, 2002; Barlow et al., 2014). Increased expression and release of CHDP is an important part of the innate immune response following detection of infection via recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMP) through pattern recognition receptors (PRR) such as the Toll-like receptors (TLR) and nucleotide-binding oligomerisation domain (NOD) receptors (NOD-like receptors or NLRs) (Ganguly et al., 2009; Lande et al., 2007; Rietdijk et al., 2008). In humans, there are two main families of CHDP, cathelicidins, and defensins (Peschel and Sahl, 2006) and these peptides have been identified in several cell types, including neutrophils, macrophages, lymphocytes, eosinophils, epithelial cells and placental trophoblasts (Bowdish et al., 2006).
response: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP) are an evolutionarily conserved and diverse group of peptides with broad antimicrobial and immunomodulatory functions. Their expression and release increase as part of the innate immune response after infection is detected through recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), including Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and NOD receptors (NOD-like receptors/NLRs). In humans, CHDP mainly comprise two families—cathelicidins and defensins—and are found in multiple cell types such as neutrophils, macrophages, lymphocytes, eosinophils, epithelial cells, and placental trophoblasts.

query: APP is a constitutively expressed, highly conserved, type-1 transmembrane glycoprotein, which is most abundantly expressed in neurons and glia of the central nervous system. It is found in the somatodendritic and axonal compartments of neurons, and in the presynaptic zone, the latter being reached by fast axoplasmic transport. APP is an acute phase protein, promoting survival under metabolically challenging conditions that produce cellular stress, such as ischaemia-hypoxia, traumatic brain injury, and inflammation (Mattson 1997; Finnie et al. 2010; Kogel et al. 2012; Plummer et al. 2016; Hefter and Draguhn 2017). Upregulation of APP in neurotrauma has been found to be due to increased mRNA expression (Van den Heuvel et al. 1999).
response: Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is a constitutively expressed, highly conserved type-1 transmembrane glycoprotein, most abundant in neurons and glia of the central nervous system. In neurons, it is located in somatodendritic and axonal compartments and at the presynaptic zone, which it reaches via fast axoplasmic transport. APP functions as an acute-phase protein that promotes survival under metabolic stress conditions such as ischaemia-hypoxia, traumatic brain injury, and inflammation, and its upregulation after neurotrauma is associated with increased APP mRNA expression.

query: Neospora caninum is an obligate intracellular protozoan parasite similar, as regards structure and development, to  $T.$  gondii [10].  $N.$  caninum and  $T.$  gondii cause abortions and due to their similarity in the morphology and in the lesions induced, histopathological techniques do not enable accurate differentiation between both parasites [10].  $T.$  gondii is one of the most common causes of reproductive failure in sheep worldwide and ovine abortions are often associated with this parasite [8]. Clinical manifestation of ovine neosporosis is like ovine toxoplasmosis although  $N.$  caninum has shown to be a more common cause of abortion in cattle [8]. For this reason, the economic, clinical, and epidemiologic importance of  $N.$  caninum infection in sheep remains under study [9, 10]. Bishop et al. [3] found  $N.$  caninum DNA in the brain of a ewe with encephalitis suggesting that the parasite might cause clinical neosporosis in adult sheep.
response: Neospora caninum is an obligate intracellular protozoan parasite structurally and developmentally similar to Toxoplasma gondii. Both can cause abortions, and because they produce similar morphology and lesions, histopathology cannot reliably distinguish between them. T. gondii is a major global cause of reproductive failure and abortion in sheep, while N. caninum causes similar clinical disease in sheep but is more commonly associated with abortion in cattle; therefore, the economic, clinical, and epidemiologic importance of N. caninum infection in sheep remains under investigation. Detection of N. caninum DNA in the brain of a ewe with encephalitis suggests it may also cause clinical neosporosis in adult sheep.

query: The allergenome of milk is highly complex due to the following: (1) the effects of genetic polymorphisms of the individual and specific breeds of ruminants, as observed in the presence of different alpha caseins ( $\alpha$ -CN), beta caseins ( $\beta$ -CN),  $\kappa$ -CN, ALA, and  $\beta$ -LG variants in different cow's breeds [11-14]; and (2) post-translational modifications, including glycosylation, phosphorylation, acetylation, and proteolytic cleavage [14]. Changes in amino acid sequence, deletion of peptide fragments, and post-translational modifications due to genetic polymorphisms greatly affect the milk proteins' functional properties, such as the stability of micelles, solubility, and digestibility [15]. These factors contributed to the changes of the milk protein structures and functions, leading to potential changes in the allergenicity of the proteins.
response: Milk’s allergenome is highly complex because (1) genetic polymorphisms in individuals and ruminant breeds produce different variants of major milk proteins (e.g., α-caseins, β-caseins, κ-casein, ALA, and β-lactoglobulin), and (2) post-translational modifications (glycosylation, phosphorylation, acetylation, proteolytic cleavage) further alter these proteins. Sequence changes, peptide deletions, and such modifications affect functional properties (micelle stability, solubility, digestibility), thereby changing milk protein structure and function and potentially altering protein allergenicity.

query: Ovine babesiosis, which is a hemolytic disease transmitted by ixodid ticks, occurs in small ruminants in many European, Asian, African, and the Far Eastern countries and causes significant economic losses in the livestock industry (Ahmed et al., 2006; Uilenberg, 2006; Inci et al., 2016; Sevinc and Xuan, 2015). The severity of infections varies according to host age, immune status, mixed infections with other pathogens, and genetic factors. The main clinical symptoms include fever, hemoglobinuria, anemia, anorexia, weakness, jaundice, and even death (Schnittger et al., 2012; Sevinc et al., 2013a; Sevinc and Xuan, 2015). Among the six species implicated in ovine babesiosis (B. crassa, B. foliata, B. motasi, B. ovis, B. taylori, and B. sp. Xinjiang), B. ovis is the most pathogenic species and is generally transmitted to hosts by ticks in the genus Rhipicephalus
response: Ovine babesiosis is a tick-borne hemolytic disease of small ruminants that occurs across many European, Asian, African, and Far Eastern countries, causing significant livestock economic losses. Infection severity varies with host age, immune status, mixed infections, and genetic factors. Main clinical signs include fever, hemoglobinuria, anemia, anorexia, weakness, jaundice, and possible death. Of the six Babesia species involved (B. crassa, B. foliata, B. motasi, B. ovis, B. taylori, and B. sp. Xinjiang), **B. ovis** is the most pathogenic and is generally transmitted by **Rhipicephalus** ticks.

query: Rapid aeration of liquid-filled lungs at birth is mandatory for a successful transition from the fetal to the newborn state. Forceful inspiratory efforts (in which intrathoracic pressure as high as  $-90\mathrm{cmH}_2\mathrm{O}$  is generated by the newborn during the first respirations) create a pressure gradient within the airways, which moves air into the lungs. This in turn opens the alveoli and moves the liquid across the alveolar epithelium into the parenchyma. In addition, repetitive active expiratory laryngeal closure contributes to air-stacking in the lungs, ultimately maintaining a sufficient amount of air into the lung at the end of expiration, i.e. functional residual capacity. The presence of surfactant is crucial in this process; by decreasing the surface tension of the distal airways, the surfactant decreases the elastic recoil of the lung, hence decreasing expiratory emptying of the lung. At the same time, lung inflation and ventilation are responsible for an increase in pulmonary blood flow and the release of two potent pulmonary vasodilators, nitric oxide (NO) and prostacyclin, by the pulmonary endothelium (1), creating an optimal situation for alveolar-capillary gas exchange.
response: At birth, rapid aeration of fluid-filled lungs is essential for the transition from fetal to newborn life. Newborns generate very strong inspiratory efforts (up to −90 cmH₂O intrathoracic pressure) that create airway pressure gradients driving air into the lungs, opening alveoli and moving liquid across the alveolar epithelium into lung tissue. Repetitive active expiratory laryngeal closure promotes air-stacking, helping establish functional residual capacity (air remaining at end-expiration). Surfactant is critical by lowering distal airway surface tension, reducing lung elastic recoil and limiting expiratory lung emptying. Lung inflation/ventilation also increase pulmonary blood flow and stimulate pulmonary endothelial release of nitric oxide and prostacyclin, facilitating pulmonary vasodilation and optimal alveolar-capillary gas exchange.

query: CircRNAs have a variety of biological functions, including as a competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA) to sponge miRNA [38], regulate the transcription of its host genes [39], and circRNA also has the potential to encode proteins [40-42]. Among them, circRNAs are the most widely studied as ceRNA mechanisms. Based on the multiple biological functions of circRNAs, circRNAs are extensively involved in biological processes such as the occurrence and development of cancer, osteogenic/myogenic/adipogenic differentiation, lipid metabolism, and browning of white adipose tissue [43-48]. A large number of studies have shown that circRNAs function as ceRNA to regulate adipocyte differentiation. For instance, in cattle, it has been reported that circFUT10 inhibits adipocyte differentiation via sponging let-7 [45], and circPPARγ facilitates adipocyte differentiation by binding miR-92a-3p and YinYang 1 [49].
response: CircRNAs have multiple biological functions: they can act as competing endogenous RNAs (ceRNAs) that sponge miRNAs, regulate transcription of their host genes, and potentially encode proteins. The ceRNA/miRNA-sponge role is the most widely studied. Through these functions, circRNAs are involved in many biological processes, including cancer development, osteogenic/myogenic/adipogenic differentiation, lipid metabolism, and browning of white adipose tissue. Many studies show circRNAs regulate adipocyte differentiation via ceRNA mechanisms; for example, in cattle, circFUT10 inhibits adipocyte differentiation by sponging let-7, while circPPARγ promotes adipocyte differentiation by binding miR-92a-3p and YinYang 1.

query: H. contortus parasite harbours in abomasum of affected animal and feeds on its blood, producing mild to severe symptoms and even death in acute form. The parasite thus inflicts heavy production losses and is of economic importance. H. contortus has developed diverse characters over the years leading to limited success in the production of vaccines. Indiscriminate use of the anthelmintics has produced drug resistance against almost all conventional products. Efficacy of medicinal plants and non-conventional chemicals has been reported under controlled experiments; however, research on their adverse effects on growth and fertility is yet to be studied. Research on molecular tools for identification and introduction of resistant genes into the flock is also underway but still a long journey to find its field application. Crossbreeding may compromise the production traits of the existing flock. In given circumstances, a targeted selective treatment approach along with selective breeding, culling of more susceptible animals, and maintaining a good body condition score through the provision of a balanced diet remains a workable strategy to control haemonchosis in sheep.
response: Haemonchus contortus inhabits the abomasum of affected animals and feeds on blood, causing mild to severe disease and potentially death in acute cases, leading to major production and economic losses. Vaccine development has had limited success because the parasite has developed diverse characteristics over time. Indiscriminate anthelmintic use has resulted in resistance to nearly all conventional drugs. Medicinal plants and non-conventional chemicals have shown efficacy in controlled experiments, but their adverse effects on growth and fertility still need study. Molecular approaches to identify and introduce resistant genes are being researched but are not yet ready for field application, and crossbreeding may compromise existing production traits. Given these constraints, a practical control strategy is targeted selective treatment combined with selective breeding, culling highly susceptible animals, and maintaining good body condition through a balanced diet.

query: Sertoli cells are somatic cells with a critical function in the seminiferous tubules; they play a crucial role in testicular development and spermatogenesis. Sertoli cells not only nourish the developing germ cells but also form the blood-testis barrier through tight junctions to protect the haploid germ cells from the innate immune system, ensuring that spermatogenesis proceeds normally.[10] However, the capacity of individual Sertoli cells to support germ cells is limited. Therefore, the number of Sertoli cells present in the seminiferous tubules was found to determine sperm production capacity in the adult animal and exert a great impact on testicular size.[11-14]
response: Sertoli cells are somatic cells in the seminiferous tubules that are essential for testicular development and spermatogenesis. They nourish developing germ cells and form the blood–testis barrier via tight junctions, protecting haploid germ cells from the innate immune system so spermatogenesis can proceed normally. Because each Sertoli cell can support only a limited number of germ cells, the total number of Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules determines adult sperm production capacity and strongly influences testicular size.

query: Goat pox is very often a threat to small ruminants, especially in goats and characterized by pyrexia, generalized pock lesions with lymphadenopathy resulting in high mortality (50%–100%) and morbidity up to 100% (Babiuk et al., 2008; Bhanuprakash et al., 2006). Diagnosis of the disease is difficult as the disease is not distinguishable from SPPV infection serologically, but can be diagnosed by molecular techniques (Hosamani et al., 2004). Goat pox is enzootic in Africa, the Middle East and southern part of Asia. India has 29 states and 7 union territories with goat population 135.2 million (19th Census DADF Report-2015-16), and goat pox has been recorded in different states (Rana, Kumar, & Vihan, 2005; Venkatesan, Balamurugan, Singh, & Bhanuprakash, 2010). The severity of the disease depends on the virus strain and the host breed (Davies, 1981) causing loss in goat farming. Indigenous breeds of sheep and goats are more resistant to infection than European breeds (Heine, Stevens, Foord, & Boyle, 1999).
response: Goat pox is a major threat to small ruminants, particularly goats, and is characterized by fever, generalized pock lesions, and lymphadenopathy, with high mortality (50%–100%) and morbidity up to 100%. It is difficult to diagnose because it cannot be distinguished serologically from sheeppox (SPPV) infection, but it can be identified using molecular techniques. The disease is enzootic in Africa, the Middle East, and southern Asia; in India (29 states and 7 union territories; ~135.2 million goats), outbreaks have been recorded in multiple states. Disease severity varies with the virus strain and host breed, causing losses in goat farming, and indigenous sheep/goat breeds are more resistant than European breeds.

query: Equine influenza A virus causes a contagious respiratory tract infection (Paillot, 2014; Sack et al., 2019), with  $100\%$  morbidity in populations of naïve animals that are exposed. Clinical signs in naïve horses include pyrexia, lethargy and anorexia, a harsh dry cough and serous nasal discharge (Wood et al., 2006). In primed horses, clinical signs are more mild and of shorter duration. In the majority of horses, the mortality rate arising from equine influenza is low, but secondary bacterial infection, which presents as a mucopurulent nasal discharge and an extended fever, can increase mortality in a small number of cases (Wood et al., 2006). The majority of equine influenza virus transmission occurs through close contact between infectious and naïve individuals, but this virus is highly infectious and can also be spread by transport of infected animals, contaminated personnel and equipment or in a wind-borne aerosol over  $1 - 2\mathrm{km}$
response: Equine influenza A virus causes a highly contagious respiratory tract infection, producing up to 100% morbidity in naïve exposed horse populations. In naïve horses it typically causes fever (pyrexia), lethargy, anorexia, a harsh dry cough, and serous nasal discharge; in previously primed horses, signs are milder and shorter. Mortality is generally low, but secondary bacterial infection (mucopurulent nasal discharge and prolonged fever) can increase mortality in a small number of cases. Transmission is mainly via close contact, but the virus can also spread through movement of infected animals, contaminated personnel/equipment, or wind-borne aerosol over 1–2 km.

query: Periodontal disease is the number one health problem in small animal patients. By just 2 years of age,  $70\%$  of cats and $80\%$  of dogs have some form of periodontal disease (Wiggs and Lobprise, 1997). Periodontal disease is exhibited in two stages, gingivitis and periodontitis. Gingivitis is the initial, reversible stage of the disease process in which the active inflammation is restricted to the gingiva. This inflammation is initiated by plaque bacteria and may be reversed with a professional dental cleaning and proper home care. Periodontitis is the later stage of the disease process which results from inflammation-induced tissue destruction and can present in active or dormant phase. It is defined as an inflammatory disease of the deeper supporting structures of the tooth (periodontal ligament and alveolar bone) and is also caused by microorganisms. The genus Porphyromonas is one of the major periodontopathic bacteria in humans and companion animals (Norris and Love, 1999). There is a direct relationship between the development of gingivitis and the accumulation of dental plaque with an increase in numbers of the genus Porphyromonas.
response: Periodontal disease is the most common health problem in small animals: by age 2, about 70% of cats and 80% of dogs are affected. It progresses in two stages: **gingivitis**, an initial reversible inflammation limited to the gingiva caused by plaque bacteria and reversible with professional cleaning and good home care; and **periodontitis**, a later stage marked by inflammation-driven tissue destruction that may be active or dormant, affecting deeper tooth-supporting structures (periodontal ligament and alveolar bone) and also caused by microorganisms. **Porphyromonas** is a major periodontopathic bacterial genus in humans and companion animals, and increasing dental plaque (and thus Porphyromonas numbers) is directly linked to gingivitis development.

query: Scrapie belongs to the transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) like other similar diseases such as bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob-disease (CJD). TSEs are fatal degenerative disorders of the central nervous system, which are characterized by the accumulation of an abnormal isoform $(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{sc}})$ of the cellular prion protein $(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{c}})$ (Prusiner and DeArmond 1994). Scrapie has long been known in sheep and goats, with a less frequent occurrence in the latter (Chelle 1942; EFSA BIOHAZ Panel 2014). In 1998, a new, atypical type of scrapie was identified in sheep that differs in its epidemiological and biochemical characteristics from the long-known classical scrapie type (Benestad et al. 2003).
response: Scrapie is a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE), like bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) and human Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD). TSEs are fatal degenerative central nervous system disorders characterized by accumulation of the abnormal prion protein isoform (PrP^sc) derived from the normal cellular prion protein (PrP^c). Scrapie has long been known in sheep and goats, occurring less frequently in goats, and since 1998 an atypical form has been identified in sheep that differs from classical scrapie in epidemiological and biochemical characteristics.

query: Classical scrapie is a naturally transmissible, fatal neurodegenerative disease of sheep and goats (small ruminants). Like other transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs), classical scrapie has a variable pre-clinical period (2-5 years) that culminates in neurologic signs which may include pruritus, gait changes, tremor, visual impairment, and changes in behavior [1, 2]. The transmissible agent is referred to as a 'prion' and a hallmark of infection is conversion of the normal cellular form of the prion protein into a misfolded, disease-associated form $(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{Sc}})$ that has a proteinase K resistant core $(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{res}})$ [3]. During the course of classical scrapie infection in small ruminants, $\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{Sc}}$ progressively accumulates in peripheral lymphoid tissues and the brain [4-6]. There is no treatment and the economic impact of scrapie to sheep and goat industries in the United States is estimated to be $10 - 20$ million annually [7]. Classical scrapie is also a significant problem for small ruminant industries abroad. As an example, more than 10,500 cases have been diagnosed in goats from some member states of the European Union over a 15-year period [8].
response: Classical scrapie is a naturally transmissible, fatal neurodegenerative prion disease of sheep and goats. It has a long, variable preclinical incubation period (about 2–5 years) that progresses to neurological signs such as pruritus, gait changes, tremor, visual impairment, and behavioral changes. The infectious agent is a prion, characterized by conversion of normal cellular prion protein into a misfolded disease-associated form (PrP^Sc) with a proteinase K–resistant core (PrP^res), which progressively accumulates in peripheral lymphoid tissues and the brain. There is no treatment, and scrapie causes substantial economic losses (estimated at $10–20 million annually in the U.S.) and remains a significant international problem, including over 10,500 diagnosed goat cases in parts of the EU over 15 years.

query: Ovine footrot is a complex disease. A further challenge to our understanding of disease pathogenesis is variation in virulence within  $D$  nodosus. There are 10 serogroups of  $D$  nodosus that lead to 10 different host antigens with no cross protection; several serogroups can be present on a foot.  $D$  nodosus can be categorised as virulent or benign based on an amino acid sequence of an extracellular protease (Kennan and others 2014). Maboni and others (2016) demonstrate that the majority of strains in their study were virulent, similar to previous findings in Great Britain (Moore and others 2005) and Australia (Kennan and others 2014). The relationship between numbers of serogroups, genetic virulence and disease severity is not clear. Research into the interaction between  $D$  nodosus and  $F$  necrophorum, between different strains of  $D$  nodosus, and the microbial community as a whole is still needed to further our understanding of this complex disease and to inform flock-specific control programmes
response: Ovine footrot is a complex disease complicated by virulence variation within *D. nodosus*. *D. nodosus* has 10 serogroups that produce 10 different host antigens with no cross-protection, and multiple serogroups can occur on a single foot. Strains can be classified as virulent or benign based on the amino acid sequence of an extracellular protease. Maboni et al. (2016) found most strains in their study were virulent, consistent with earlier results from Great Britain and Australia. However, how serogroup number, genetic virulence, and disease severity relate remains unclear, and further research is needed on interactions between *D. nodosus* and *F. necrophorum*, among *D. nodosus* strains, and within the wider microbial community to improve understanding and guide flock-specific control programs.

query: First registered in 2002, the Gudair® (Zoetis, Australia) vaccine has played a pivotal role in the control of ovine Johne's disease (OJD) in Australian sheep flocks. With over seven million doses used within its first few years of release, vaccination with Gudair contributes to a delayed onset of OJD, decreases mortalities and decreases faecal shedding of Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (Mptb). Although the vaccine is very effective in reducing the incidence of clinical disease, animals on some farms continue to shed Mptb in their faeces despite ongoing vaccination in their flocks for over a decade. Thus, there is concern amongst the scientific community and animal health policymakers of a risk of OJD resurgence if farmers cease to vaccinate following a lack of observable clinical cases after a few years, due to the assumption that they have eradicated the disease from their farms. There have also been considerations by farmers of not vaccinating wether lambs for economic reasons, concurrent with concerns about the human safety aspects of Gudair. Cessation of vaccination may not only compromise the management of this disease for individual producers but also jeopardise its control at a regional and national level.
response: Gudair® (Zoetis, Australia), first registered in 2002, has been central to controlling ovine Johne’s disease (OJD) in Australian sheep flocks, with over seven million doses used in its first few years. Vaccination delays OJD onset, reduces mortalities, and decreases faecal shedding of *Mycobacterium avium* subspecies *paratuberculosis* (Mptb). Despite strong effectiveness against clinical disease, some farms still have animals shedding Mptb after more than a decade of vaccination, raising concern that stopping vaccination—especially when few clinical cases are seen—could lead to OJD resurgence. Farmers have also considered not vaccinating wether lambs for economic reasons and due to human safety concerns about Gudair. Stopping vaccination could undermine disease management on individual farms and threaten regional and national control efforts.

query: The pre-implantation period is a coordinated process between fertilization and embryo implantation in the endometrium of mammalian species. The first cellular cycles of the fertilized oocyte are controlled by maternal RNAs and proteins synthesized and stored during oogenesis (Crosby et al., 1988). Around the fourth cell cycle in ruminants, the embryo begins to produce its own transcripts and maternal RNAs and proteins are degraded and replaced. This process is called maternal-to-embryonic transition (Graf et al., 2014; Sanchez et al., 2019), and its onset differs among species. In sheep, full activation of embryo transcription occurs at the 8-16 cell stage (Crosby et al., 1988). During the next cell divisions, E-cadherin membrane protein is responsible for cellular adhesion during sheep embryo compaction, being localized in all contact regions of blastomeres (Modina et al., 2010). At the morula stage, the compaction event induces cell polarization and blastomeres membranes are reorganized into apical and basolateral domains (Watson, 1992). These events are essential for the formation of the blastocyst, composed by trophectoderm (TE) cells that mediate maternal-foetal communication, a fluid-filled cavity and the inner cell mass (ICM) (Menchaca et al., 2018; Watson & Barcroft, 2001)
response: The pre-implantation period spans fertilization to embryo implantation and is coordinated with the maternal endometrium. Early embryonic cell cycles are driven by maternal RNAs and proteins stored during oogenesis, but around the fourth cell cycle in ruminants the embryo starts producing its own transcripts while maternal factors are degraded—this maternal-to-embryonic transition varies by species. In sheep, full embryonic genome activation occurs at the 8–16 cell stage. Subsequent divisions involve E-cadherin–mediated blastomere adhesion during compaction; at the morula stage, compaction triggers cell polarization and membrane reorganization into apical and basolateral domains. These steps are essential for blastocyst formation, which consists of trophectoderm cells (supporting maternal–foetal communication), a fluid-filled cavity, and the inner cell mass.

query: The prognosis of stringhalt  is poor and a horse's performance and quality of life are affected in severe cases. The digital extensors have been surgically cut as a treatment with an approximate  $50\%$  success rate (Crabhill et al., 1994). More recent published accounts of surgical myotenectomy of the lateral digital extensor tendon have shown positive results (Kachwaha et al., 2012). Botox was utilized as a treatment option of two Dutch Warmblood dressage horses with stringhalt. The extensor digitorum lateralis and the lateral vastus muscles were injected and showed a decrease in hyperflexion or hyperabduction for up to 12 weeks (Wijnberg et al., 2009). Regenerated nerve fibers with thin myelin sheaths were discovered in horses with Australian stringhalt. Anti-seizure medications showed improvement in trot gait, but not in walking or turning. The recovery time for stringhalt varies from 3 months to 3 years, and in severe cases the horse is euthanized (Huntington et al., 1989).
response: Stringhalt has a poor prognosis, and severe cases can significantly reduce a horse’s performance and quality of life. One treatment has been surgical cutting of the digital extensors, with about a 50% success rate, while more recent reports of surgical myotenectomy of the lateral digital extensor tendon describe positive results. Botox injections into the extensor digitorum lateralis and lateral vastus muscles in two Dutch Warmblood dressage horses reduced hyperflexion or hyperabduction for up to 12 weeks. In Australian stringhalt, regenerated nerve fibers with thin myelin sheaths have been found; anti-seizure medications improved trot gait but not walking or turning. Recovery can take from 3 months to 3 years, and severe cases may lead to euthanasia.

query: One of the possible limits to the information provided by published DTs in horses is the fact that they are determined from classic pharmacokinetic studies performed at rest under laboratory conditions. In field conditions, training and exercise programmes may have an influence on drug elimination. In horses, there is practically no experimental information on the direct effect of exercise on drug disposition. Prolonged submaximal exercise has not been shown to influence plasma clearance of frusemide measured several minutes after the end of the test exercise (Dyke et al. 1996). On the other hand, several studies have described the effects of exercise on functions involved in drug disposition (Poortmans 1977; Ylitalo 1991; McKeever et al. 1993; Manohar et al. 1995). In horses, hepatic blood flow is significantly decreased during submaximal exercise and it was hypothesised that drugs that are efficiently extracted by the liver may have decreased hepatic clearance when horses are subjected to submaximal exercise (Dyke et al. 1998a). For the kidney, it was shown that the glomerular filtration rate fell over  $40\%$  during mild exercise in humans (Gleadhill et al. 2000). As the kidney and liver are the 2 main organs involved in drug elimination, it is reasonable to suppose that the cardiovascular adaptation observed during sustained exercise can lead to changes in drug disposition and consequently, to a different DT from that obtained at rest.
response: Published drug detection times (DTs) in horses may be limited because they are usually derived from classic pharmacokinetic studies conducted at rest in laboratory conditions, whereas real-world training and exercise could affect drug elimination. There is little direct experimental evidence in horses on how exercise alters drug disposition: prolonged submaximal exercise did not change frusemide plasma clearance measured minutes after exercise, but other studies show exercise affects physiological functions relevant to drug disposition. In horses, submaximal exercise significantly reduces hepatic blood flow, suggesting liver-extracted drugs may have reduced hepatic clearance during exercise. Evidence from humans shows glomerular filtration rate can drop by over 40% during mild exercise, implying renal elimination may also decrease. Because the liver and kidneys are primary drug-eliminating organs, sustained exercise-related cardiovascular adaptations may change drug disposition and lead to DTs different from those measured at rest.

query: Goat's milk is a rich source of bioactive compounds (peptides, conjugated linoleic acid, short chain fatty acids, monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids, polyphenols such as phytoestrogens and minerals among others) that exert important health benefits. However, goat's milk composition depends on the type of food provided to the animal and thus, the abundance of bioactive compounds in milk depends on the dietary sources of the goat feed. The metabolic impact of goat milk rich in bioactive compounds during metabolic challenges such as a high-fat (HF) diet has not been explored. Thus, we evaluated the effect of milk from goats fed a conventional diet, a conventional diet supplemented with  $30\%$  Acacia farnesiana (AF) pods or grazing on metabolic alterations in mice fed a HF diet. Interestingly, the incorporation of goat's milk in the diet decreased body weight and body fat mass, improved glucose tolerance, prevented adipose tissue hypertrophy and hepatic steatosis in mice fed a HF diet. These effects were associated with an increase in energy expenditure, augmented oxidative fibers in skeletal muscle, and reduced inflammatory markers. Consequently, goat's milk can be considered a non-pharmacologic strategy to improve the metabolic alterations induced by a HF diet. Using the body surface area normalization method gave a conversion equivalent daily human intake dose of 1.4 to 2.8 glasses (250 mL per glass/day) of fresh goat milk for an adult of 60 kg, which can be used as reference for future clinical studies.
response: Goat milk contains many bioactive compounds with health benefits, but its composition varies with the goat’s diet. To address the unstudied metabolic effects of bioactive-rich goat milk during a high-fat (HF) diet challenge, the study tested milk from goats fed: (1) a conventional diet, (2) a conventional diet plus 30% *Acacia farnesiana* pods, or (3) grazing, in mice on an HF diet. Adding goat milk reduced body weight and fat mass, improved glucose tolerance, and prevented adipose tissue hypertrophy and liver steatosis; these benefits were linked to higher energy expenditure, more oxidative skeletal muscle fibers, and lower inflammatory markers. The authors conclude goat milk may be a non-pharmacologic strategy to counter HF-diet–induced metabolic alterations, with a human-equivalent reference intake of about 1.4–2.8 glasses/day (250 mL each) for a 60 kg adult.

query: The equine thoracolumbar spine acts like a flexible bow that is maintained in a slightly arched (rounded) position by tension in the string, formed by the abdominal and sublumbar muscles. Concentric contraction of these muscles rounds the back by flexing the intervertebral joints. Insufficient tension in the string allows the weight of the viscera to extend the intervertebral joints, and the back contour becomes more lordotic. It is desirable for horses to work in a rounded posture to maintain separation of the dorsal spinous processes, so the use of conditioning exercises that recruit and strengthen the hypaxial musculature is an important part of athletic training. In horses that have poor natural posture or weak, inactive hypaxial muscles, for example, following colic surgery or foaling, the rehabilitation program should target activation and strengthening of these muscles. Appropriate exercises include core training from the ground as well as specific types of locomotor exercises.
response: The equine thoracolumbar spine functions like a flexible bow, kept slightly rounded by tension from the “string” formed by the abdominal and sublumbar (hypaxial) muscles. When these muscles contract concentrically, they flex the intervertebral joints and round the back; if muscle tension is insufficient, the weight of the viscera extends the joints, creating a more lordotic back contour. A rounded working posture is desirable because it helps maintain separation of the dorsal spinous processes, so conditioning exercises that recruit and strengthen the hypaxial musculature are important in athletic training. Horses with poor posture or weak/inactive hypaxial muscles (e.g., after colic surgery or foaling) should undergo rehabilitation focused on activating and strengthening these muscles, using ground-based core training and specific locomotor exercises.

query: For decades the horse has been viewed as an isolated or "dead-end" host for influenza A viruses, with equine influenza virus being considered as relatively stable genetically. Although equine influenza viruses are genetically more stable than their human-lineage counterparts, they are by no means in evolutionary stasis. Moreover, recent transmission of equine-lineage influenza viruses to dogs also challenges the horse's status as a dead-end host.
response: For decades, horses were considered isolated (“dead-end”) hosts for influenza A viruses, and equine influenza virus was viewed as genetically relatively stable. However, although equine influenza viruses are more genetically stable than human-lineage strains, they still evolve, and recent transmission of equine-lineage influenza viruses to dogs challenges the idea that horses are dead-end hosts.

query: Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) is a widely recognized collection of risk factors for endocrinopathic laminitis. The most important of these risk factors is insulin dysregulation (ID). Clinicians and horse owners must recognize the presence of these risk factors so that they can be targeted and controlled to reduce the risk of laminitis attacks. Diagnosis of EMS is based partly on the horse's history and clinical examination findings, and partly on laboratory testing. Several choices of test exist which examine different facets of ID and other related metabolic disturbances. EMS is controlled mainly by dietary strategies and exercise programs that aim to improve insulin regulation and decrease obesity where present. In some cases, pharmacologic aids might be useful. Management of an EMS case is a long-term strategy requiring diligence and discipline by the horse's carer and support and guidance from their veterinarians.
response: Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) is a set of risk factors for endocrinopathic laminitis, with insulin dysregulation (ID) being the most important. Recognizing these risk factors is essential so they can be managed to reduce laminitis risk. EMS diagnosis combines history and clinical examination with laboratory testing; multiple test options assess different aspects of ID and related metabolic disturbances. Management focuses mainly on diet and exercise to improve insulin regulation and reduce obesity when present, with pharmacologic support in some cases. Long-term control requires sustained diligence from the horse’s caregiver and ongoing veterinary guidance.

query: African horse sickness (AHS) is an infectious and non-contagious disease, affecting all species of Equidae, caused by a double-stranded RNA orbivirus (Calisher & Mertens 1998). AHS was first recognised in southern Africa, with the first major outbreak recorded in 1719, when more than 1700 animals died (Theiler 1921 in Mellor & Hamblin 2004). Although endemic in Equidae in sub-Saharan Africa, outbreaks have also been recorded in north Africa, the middle and near east and southern Europe (MacLachlan & Guthrie 2010). Both AHS and bluetongue viruses are transmitted by the biting midges Culicoides. Culicoides imicola is the field vector of AHS virus although Culicoides bolitinos has been shown to play an important role in the transmission of AHS virus in the cooler upper highlands of South Africa (Meiswinkel & Paweska 2003). The highest incidence of the disease usually occurs in the late summer and early autumn in years when the climatic conditions favour an abundance of Culicoides midges (Coetzer & Guthrie 2004).
response: African horse sickness (AHS) is an infectious but non-contagious disease of all Equidae caused by a double-stranded RNA orbivirus. First recognized in southern Africa, a major outbreak in 1719 killed over 1,700 animals. While endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, outbreaks have also occurred in North Africa, the Middle and Near East, and southern Europe. AHS virus is transmitted by Culicoides biting midges: Culicoides imicola is the main field vector, and Culicoides bolitinos is important in cooler highland areas of South Africa. Disease incidence is usually highest in late summer and early autumn when climatic conditions favor large midge populations.

query: In horses, peracute colitis because of Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) often leads to severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and is associated with case fatality rates of  $37\% - 79\%$ . [1-3] Typical treatments for C. difficile colitis and secondary severe SIRS in horses include administration of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimicrobials, anti-lipopolysaccharide (LPS) therapy, and fluid therapy. In horses with renal compromise, these treatments are often limited because of the potential nephrotoxic effects of NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, and polymyxin B.
response: Peracute colitis caused by *Clostridioides difficile* in horses often triggers severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and has a high case fatality rate (37%–79%). Typical treatment for *C. difficile* colitis and associated severe SIRS includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimicrobials, anti-lipopolysaccharide (LPS) therapy, and fluid therapy; however, in horses with renal compromise, these options may be limited due to potential nephrotoxicity of NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, and polymyxin B.

query: Complementary and alternative veterinary medicine (CAVM) is defined as a 'heterogeneous group of preventive, diagnostic and therapeutic philosophies and practices', which do not belong to the traditional veterinary curriculum. Examples include veterinary acupuncture, homeopathy, manual therapy, chiropractic, phytotherapy and nutraceutical medicine. Complementary veterinary medicine is defined as the use of these practices in addition to conventional treatments, while AVM indicates the use of these practices instead of conventional treatments. Despite the lack of scientific evidence and uncertain efficacy, CAVM use appears to be a common practice among horse owners. CAVM use has been reported for a variety of indications such as behavioural and musculoskeletal problems, lameness, optimising performance, injury prophylaxis, enhancing recovery or chronic conditions in geriatric horses. However, several of these therapies or approaches are not evidence-based, and their efficacy and safety remain unclear.
response: Complementary and alternative veterinary medicine (CAVM) comprises preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic philosophies and practices not included in the traditional veterinary curriculum (e.g., acupuncture, homeopathy, manual therapy, chiropractic, phytotherapy, nutraceutical medicine). “Complementary” use means adding these methods to conventional treatment, while “alternative” use means using them instead of conventional treatment. Despite limited scientific evidence and uncertain efficacy, CAVM is commonly used by horse owners for issues such as behavioural and musculoskeletal problems, lameness, performance optimisation, injury prevention, recovery enhancement, and chronic conditions in geriatric horses; however, many approaches are not evidence-based and their efficacy and safety remain unclear.

query: Sequencing the genome of a Quarter Horse was considered important for several reasons. Almost 3 million Quarter Horses were registered in the United States in 2010 according to the American Quarter Horse Association, making it the single largest breed registry in the country [2,3]. When one includes non-registered Quarter Horses and other Quarter Horse-influenced breed registries (e.g., American Paint Horse Association), the Quarter Horse is by far the largest contributor to the population of horses in the United States. Although Quarter Horse breeding was, and continues to be, strongly influenced by Thoroughbred bloodlines, the 2 breeds were selectively bred to enhance different traits. Thoroughbred breeding has selected for speed over distances of  $3/4$  to 2 miles, whereas selection in the Quarter Horse has emphasized speed over shorter distances and compliant disposition suited to working cattle and other ranch-related duties [4]. Thus, there are important phenotypic differences between the breeds that have been achieved by selective breeding with a clear underlying genetic component [5,6]. Moreover, there are single-gene disorders in Quarter Horses, such as polysaccharide storage myopathy (PSSM) [7,8], hyperkalemic periodic paralysis (HYPP) [9], glycogen branching enzyme deficiency (GBED) [10], and hereditary equine regional dermal asthenia (HERDA) [11,12]. Most diseases and traits (such as predisposition to osteoarthritis or body-type) are complex, involving multiple genes, which may be modulated by environmental factors [5,13,14]. Thus, identifying genetic variants in the genome of a single Quarter Horse would provide a wealth of information for future genomic studies in equids.
response: Sequencing a Quarter Horse genome was considered important because Quarter Horses are the largest horse population contributor in the United States (about 3 million registered in 2010, plus many unregistered and related breed registries). Although influenced by Thoroughbred bloodlines, Quarter Horses and Thoroughbreds have been selectively bred for different traits—Thoroughbreds for longer-distance speed and Quarter Horses for short-distance speed and a compliant ranch-working disposition—creating phenotypic differences with a genetic basis. Quarter Horses also have several known single-gene disorders (PSSM, HYPP, GBED, HERDA), while many other traits and disease risks are complex and affected by multiple genes and environment. Therefore, identifying genetic variants from one Quarter Horse genome would provide valuable information for future equine genomic research.

query: Myostatin gene, a member of the transforming growth factor-beta superfamily, codifies the Growth Differentiation Factor 8 (GDF8), which is a negative regulator of muscle growth (Binns et al. 2010). The MSTN regulatory network decreases the proliferation rate of equine muscle precursor cells by inhibiting cell cycle progression (Thomas et al. 2000). Furthermore, it is involved in signalling pathways (Notch, Mitogen-Activated Protein Kinase signaling pathway and wingless-type MMTV integration site family (Wnt) signaling pathway), cell differentiation, glucose metabolism and adipocyte proliferation, regulation and homeostasis of skeletal muscle and cardiomyocyte, formation and renewal of bone and skeletal muscle (Grobet et al. 1997, Kellum et al. 2009, Hamrick et al. 2010, Elkasrawy and Hamrick 2010, Elliott et al. 2012, Budsuren et al. 2022).
response: Myostatin (MSTN) is a transforming growth factor-beta superfamily gene that encodes Growth Differentiation Factor 8 (GDF8), a negative regulator of muscle growth. The MSTN regulatory network reduces proliferation of equine muscle precursor cells by inhibiting cell-cycle progression. MSTN is also involved in multiple signaling pathways (Notch, MAPK, and Wnt), as well as cell differentiation, glucose metabolism, adipocyte proliferation, and the regulation and homeostasis of skeletal muscle and cardiomyocytes, and it contributes to bone and skeletal muscle formation and renewal.

query: Alopecia areata is an uncommon immune-mediated hair loss that has been reported in various species including the humans, nonhuman primates, $^{2}$  dogs, $^{8}$  cats, $^{8}$  cattle, $^{14}$  chickens, $^{16}$  laboratory rodents, $^{10}$  and horses. $^{3,5,11,15}$  Clinically, AA is characterized by sudden or insidious, well-circumscribed, nonscarring, and visually noninflammatory alopecia. In humans, AA occurs commonly on the scalp in a pattern of a focal patch or multiple patches; however, other subgroups such as complete loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) and entire body hair (alopecia universalis) have been recognized. $^{1}$  In horses, similar lesions are often noted on the face, neck, trunk, mane, tail, shoulder, and gluteal region with varying degrees of severity. $^{3,5,11,15,17}$  In humans, AA is quite common, affecting 1.7 to  $3.8\%$  of the general population, with no sex predilection. $^{18}$
response: Alopecia areata (AA) is an uncommon immune-mediated hair loss reported in multiple species (including humans, nonhuman primates, dogs, cats, cattle, chickens, laboratory rodents, and horses). Clinically, it presents as sudden or gradual, well-circumscribed, nonscarring alopecia with no visible inflammation. In humans, it most often affects the scalp as single or multiple patches, and can progress to complete scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis) or total body hair loss (alopecia universalis). In horses, similar lesions commonly occur on the face, neck, trunk, mane, tail, shoulder, and gluteal region with variable severity. In humans, AA affects about 1.7–3.8% of the general population and shows no sex predilection.

query: The horse's back is a complex anatomical region occupying an essential place in the musculoskeletal system [1]. This region is highly stressed during sports and racing activities, particularly when it must support the rider's weight [2]. Knowledge of the anatomy and biomechanics of the horse's back helps to understand how it works and to ensure its physical integrity [3]. Horses' spinal column is composed of seven cervical, eighteen thoracic, six lumbar, five sacral and fifteen to twenty-one coccygeal vertebrae. The area of the horse's back corresponding to the thoracolumbar region is the most mobile, particularly between the fourteenth thoracic vertebra (T14) and the eighteenth thoracic vertebra (T18) [4]. The very large volume and weight of a horse's visceral mass exert high stresses on the spinal column due to the inertia of these moving fluid masses during locomotion [3].
response: The horse’s back is a complex anatomical region that is essential to the musculoskeletal system and is heavily stressed during sports and racing, especially when supporting a rider’s weight. Understanding its anatomy and biomechanics is important to explain its function and maintain physical integrity. The horse’s spinal column consists of 7 cervical, 18 thoracic, 6 lumbar, 5 sacral, and 15–21 coccygeal vertebrae. The thoracolumbar back region is the most mobile part of the spine, particularly between thoracic vertebrae T14 and T18. The large volume and weight of the horse’s visceral mass also place high stresses on the spine due to inertia of these moving fluid masses during locomotion.

query: Genetic bleeding disorders can have a profound impact on a horse's health and athletic career. As such, it is important to understand the mechanisms of these diseases and how they are diagnosed. These diseases include haemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, prekallikrein deficiency, Glanzmann's Thrombasthenia, and Atypical Equine Thrombasthenia. Exercise-induced pulmonary haemorrhage also has a proposed genetic component. Genetic mutations have been identified for haemophilia A and Glanzmann's Thrombasthenia in the horse. Mutations are known for von Willebrand disease and prekallikrein deficiency in other species. In the absence of genetic tests, bleeding disorders are typically diagnosed by measuring platelet function, von Willebrand factor, and other coagulation protein levels and activities. For autosomal recessive diseases, genetic testing can prevent the breeding of two carriers.
response: Genetic bleeding disorders can significantly affect a horse’s health and athletic performance. Key disorders include haemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, prekallikrein deficiency, Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, and atypical equine thrombasthenia; exercise-induced pulmonary haemorrhage is also suggested to have a genetic component. In horses, specific genetic mutations have been identified for haemophilia A and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, while mutations for von Willebrand disease and prekallikrein deficiency are known in other species. When genetic tests are unavailable, diagnosis typically relies on assessing platelet function, von Willebrand factor, and other coagulation protein levels and activities. For autosomal recessive disorders, genetic testing can help avoid breeding two carrier animals.

query: A major cause of concern regarding the forces associated with horseback riding is that vascular occlusion may occur when the applied pressure exceeds the mean capillary pressure of $4.7\mathrm{kPa}$ (Chang and Siegreg, 1999). Prolonged vascular occlusion can lead to ischemia, oxygen and nutrient deprivation, and ultimately necrosis of the under-lying tissues with muscle being particularly vulnerable to pressure-induced injury (Linder-Ganz et al., 2006). Thus, it is important to seek metrics that are predictive for saddle-induced damage to underlying tissues. Minimal, maximal and mean pressures beneath the saddle have been suggested as relevant measures, with mean pressure showing the largest difference between saddle variants (Byström et al., 2010). Mean pressure is also more reliable than maximal pressure (De Cocq et al., 2006) and it differentiates more clearly between groups of horses with and without back pain (von Peinen et al., 2010). Based on published data (Mönkemöller et al., 2005; Nyikos et al., 2005; Meschan et al., 2007), it has been suggested that mean pressure $>11\mathrm{kPa}$ is a reasonable threshold to indicate a risk of inducing back pain (Byström et al., 2010).
response: Vascular occlusion during horseback riding may occur if saddle pressure exceeds mean capillary pressure (4.7 kPa); if prolonged, this can cause ischemia, oxygen/nutrient deprivation, and tissue necrosis, with muscle especially vulnerable. Therefore, metrics predicting saddle-induced tissue damage are needed. Minimal, maximal, and mean pressures under the saddle are proposed measures; mean pressure shows the largest differences between saddle variants, is more reliable than maximal pressure, and better distinguishes horses with vs. without back pain. Published data suggest a mean pressure >11 kPa as a reasonable threshold indicating risk of inducing back pain.

query: Back pain and dysfunction are common causes of poor performance in horses (Zimmerman et al., 2011a,b). One recent large-scale study of British dressage horses demonstrated that  $25\%$  had a history of back-related problems (Murray et al., 2010). Reasons may include primary thoracolumbar osseous pathology (Gillen et al., 2009; Girodroux et al., 2009; Meehan et al., 2009; Zimmerman et al., 2011a,b), or back muscle soreness developed secondarily to lameness, incorrect training, a poorly skilled rider, a saddle not fitting the horse and/or a saddle not fitting the rider. However, there is a lack of scientific data relating directly to riders. Both experimentally-induced forelimb or hindlimb lameness (Gómez Alvarez et al., 2007, 2008) and back pain/stiffness have been shown to alter the biomechanics of the spine and shift the centre of gravity (Wennerstrand et al., 2004, 2009). This may predispose to rider back pain or stiffness (Lagarde et al., 2005; Symes and Ellis, 2009) and abnormal saddle movement, such as saddle slip consistently to one side (Greve and Dyson, 2012). Saddle slip may induce focal areas of increased pressure beneath the saddle (deCocq et al., 2006).
response: Back pain and dysfunction commonly reduce horses’ performance, with a large study finding 25% of British dressage horses had a history of back-related problems. Causes include primary thoracolumbar bone pathology or secondary back muscle soreness due to lameness, incorrect training, an unskilled rider, or poor saddle fit for the horse and/or rider, though direct scientific data on rider-related factors are limited. Experimentally induced limb lameness and back pain/stiffness can alter spinal biomechanics and shift the horse’s centre of gravity, potentially contributing to rider back pain/stiffness and abnormal saddle movement (e.g., consistent one-sided saddle slip), which can create localized areas of increased pressure under the saddle.

query: It is generally accepted that the massive destruction of macrophages plays a major role in pathogenesis, especially in the impaired haemostasis due to the release of active substances including cytokines, complement factors and arachidonic acid metabolites (Penrith et al., 2004b). The genesis of thrombocytopenia that occurs particularly during the course of acute and subacute ASFV infection is controversially discussed. While some authors show evidence that infection and destruction of megakaryocytes may play a role (Rodriguez et al., 1996a), other researchers did not find structural or ultrastructural correlates for an impaired thrombocytopoiesis (Gomez-Villamandos et al., 1997a). Pigs infected with ASFV generally suffer from severe lymphopenia that could be attributed to apoptosis of lymphocytes. Production of pro-inflammatory cytokines by infected macrophages is strongly implicated in induction of apoptosis in lymphocyte populations (Gomez-Villamandos et al., 1995a, 2003; Oura et al., 1998a).
response: Massive destruction of macrophages is considered central to ASFV pathogenesis, contributing to impaired haemostasis through release of active substances such as cytokines, complement factors, and arachidonic acid metabolites. The cause of thrombocytopenia in acute and subacute infection remains controversial: some evidence suggests infection and destruction of megakaryocytes, while other studies find no structural or ultrastructural evidence of impaired thrombocytopoiesis. ASFV-infected pigs typically develop severe lymphopenia attributed to lymphocyte apoptosis, likely induced by pro-inflammatory cytokines produced by infected macrophages.

query: Clostridium difficile is considered one of the most important causes of diarrhea and enterocolitis in horses. Foals and adult horses are equally susceptible to the infection. The highly resistant spore of  $C$  difficile is the infectious unit of transmission, which occurs primarily via the fecal-oral route, with sources of infection including equine feces, contaminated soil, animal hospitals, and feces of other animals. Two major risk factors for the development of  $C$  difficile associated disease (CDAD) in adult horses are hospitalization and antimicrobial treatment, although sporadically, cases of CDAD can occur in horses that have not received antimicrobials or been hospitalized. The most common antibiotics associated with CDAD in horses are erythromycin, trimethoprim/sulfonamides,  $\beta$ -lactam antimicrobials, clindamycin, rifampicin, and gentamicin. Clinical signs and intestinal lesions of CDAD infection are not specific and they cannot be used to distinguish infections by  $C$  difficile from infections by other agents, such as Clostridium perfringens or Salmonella sp. The distribution of lesions throughout the intestinal tract seems to be age-dependent. Small intestine is invariably affected, and colon and cecum may or may not have lesions in foals  $< 1$ -month old. Naturally acquired disease in older foals and adult horses has a more aboral distribution, affecting colon and sometimes cecum, but rarely the small intestine. Detection of toxin A, toxin B or both in intestinal contents or feces is considered the most reliable diagnostic criterion for CDAD in horses. Isolation of toxigenic strains of  $C$  difficile from horses with intestinal disease is highly suggestive of CDAD. A better understanding of pathogenesis, reservoirs of infection, and vaccines and other methods of control is needed. Also further studies are recommended to investigate other possible predisposing factors and/or etiological agents of enteric diseases of horses.
response: Clostridium difficile is a major cause of diarrhea and enterocolitis in horses, with foals and adults equally susceptible. Transmission occurs mainly by the fecal–oral route via highly resistant spores, originating from sources such as equine feces, contaminated soil, animal hospitals, and feces of other animals. In adult horses, the main risk factors for C. difficile–associated disease (CDAD) are hospitalization and antimicrobial treatment, though cases can also occur without these exposures. Antibiotics most commonly linked to CDAD include erythromycin, trimethoprim/sulfonamides, β-lactams, clindamycin, rifampicin, and gentamicin. Clinical signs and intestinal lesions are nonspecific and cannot reliably distinguish C. difficile infection from other causes (e.g., Clostridium perfringens or Salmonella). Lesion distribution varies with age: in foals under 1 month the small intestine is always affected and colon/cecum may or may not be involved, while in older foals and adults lesions are more aboral, mainly affecting the colon and sometimes the cecum, with small-intestine involvement being rare. The most reliable diagnosis is detection of toxin A, toxin B, or both in intestinal contents or feces; isolating toxigenic C. difficile from horses with intestinal disease is strongly suggestive. Further research is needed on pathogenesis, reservoirs, vaccines/control methods, and additional predisposing factors or etiologic agents in equine enteric disease.

query: The body stem of a quadruped can be compared to a heavy beam on two supports. This beam is exposed to shearing forces and bending stresses under its own weight. As illustrated by Preuschoft and Fritz (1977), the anterior cantilever (=head and neck) is bent downward, so producing compression at its lower margin and tension on the upper. Between the supports, the trunk tends to sag ventrally downwards, so that compressing forces occur along the upper margin and tension at the lower. This distribution of internal forces is in agreement with the arrangement of the compression-resistant skeleton (vertebral column and sternum, pelvis, (Preuschoft & Fritz, 1977)) and the tension-producing musculature (neck, cranial thoracic dorsal musculature and several shoulder muscles, as detailed in Kienapfel (2014)). Aside from the muscles, there exist very strong strands of connective tissue, which can take over at least part of the tensile forces, and are claimed by several researchers (Gellman & Bertram, 2002; Nickel, Schummer, Seiferle, & Frewein, 2004; Slijper, 1946; Zschokke, 1892) to do so.
response: The quadruped’s body trunk can be modeled as a heavy beam supported at two points, experiencing shearing forces and bending stresses from its own weight. The head and neck act as an anterior cantilever that bends downward, creating compression along the lower margin and tension along the upper. Between the two supports, the trunk sags ventrally, producing compression along the upper margin and tension along the lower. This internal force pattern matches the placement of compression-resistant skeletal elements (vertebral column, sternum, pelvis) and the distribution of tension-generating muscles (neck muscles, cranial thoracic dorsal musculature, and several shoulder muscles). In addition, strong connective tissue strands can bear at least part of the tensile forces, as proposed by multiple researchers.

query: The most widely studied TLR is TLR4 which, together with its accessory receptor, MD-2, responds to monomeric endotoxins. Naturally occurring LPS, a vital component of the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria, is made up of 3 distinct structural parts. $^{16}$  The outermost polysaccharide O antigen domain of LPS is a repetitive glycan polymer that varies from strain to strain and is a target for recognition by host antibodies; this is connected to a core domain that consists of less variant oligosaccharides. The innermost component of LPS, Lipid A, is a phosphorylated glucosamine disaccharide attached to up to 6 hydrophobic fatty acids. Lipid A anchors the LPS molecule into the bacterial cell membrane, is responsible for many of the toxic effects of gram-negative bacteria, and is the smallest ligand recognized by TLR4/MD-2. Having both hydrophobic lipid and hydrophilic sugar moieties, LPS forms micelles in aqueous solutions. These features of LPS are important for the regulation of its movement in the circulation and its interaction with cells. Binding of LPS to TLR4 initiates cell-signaling cascades (see later discussion), activation of the cell, and the synthesis of mediators associated with inflammation. Equine cells, specifically monocytes, are highly sensitive to the presence of LPS, having a half-maximal effective concentration  $(\mathrm{EC}_{50})$  of 0.013 to  $0.030~\mathrm{ng / mL}$  for Escherichia coli LPS for the release of tumor necrosis factor  $\alpha$  (TNF $\alpha$ ) and expression of tissue factor. $^{13}$  This low  $\mathrm{EC}_{50}$  demonstrates the high sensitivity of horses to the presence of LPS in the circulation.
response: TLR4, together with its accessory receptor MD-2, is the most widely studied Toll-like receptor and responds to monomeric endotoxins such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS) from gram-negative bacteria. LPS has three structural parts: a variable outer O-antigen polysaccharide targeted by host antibodies; a less variable core oligosaccharide; and an inner Lipid A moiety (a phosphorylated glucosamine disaccharide with up to six fatty acids) that anchors LPS in the bacterial membrane, drives many toxic effects, and is the smallest ligand recognized by TLR4/MD-2. Because LPS contains both hydrophobic lipid and hydrophilic sugar components, it forms micelles in water, influencing its circulation and cellular interactions. LPS binding to TLR4 triggers signaling cascades, cell activation, and production of inflammatory mediators. Equine monocytes are highly sensitive to LPS, with an EC50 of 0.013–0.030 ng/mL (E. coli LPS) for TNFα release and tissue factor expression, indicating horses’ high sensitivity to circulating LPS.

query: Classical swine fever (CSF) remains one of the most important transboundary viral diseases of swine worldwide. The causative agent is CSF virus, a small, enveloped RNA virus of the genus *Pestivirus*. Based on partial sequences, three genotypes can be distinguished that do not, however, directly correlate with virulence. Depending on both virus and host factors, a wide range of clinical syndromes can be observed and thus, laboratory confirmation is mandatory. To this means, both direct and indirect methods are utilized with an increasing degree of commercialization. Both infections in domestic pigs and wild boar are of great relevance; and wild boars are a reservoir host transmitting the virus sporadically also to pig farms. Control strategies for epidemic outbreaks in free countries are mainly based on classical intervention measures; i.e., quarantine and strict culling of affected herds. In these countries, vaccination is only an emergency option. However, live vaccines are used for controlling the disease in endemically infected regions in Asia, Eastern Europe, the Americas, and some African countries.
response: Classical swine fever (CSF) is a major transboundary viral disease of swine worldwide caused by CSF virus, a small enveloped RNA virus in the genus *Pestivirus*. Three genotypes can be distinguished based on partial sequences, but they do not directly correlate with virulence. Clinical disease varies widely depending on virus and host factors, making laboratory confirmation mandatory using both direct and indirect methods that are increasingly commercialized. CSF is important in both domestic pigs and wild boar, with wild boar acting as a reservoir that can sporadically transmit the virus to pig farms. In CSF-free countries, outbreak control relies mainly on quarantine and strict culling, with vaccination reserved for emergencies, while live vaccines are used in endemic regions in Asia, Eastern Europe, the Americas, and some African countries.

query: ASF virus (ASFV) is a complex, large, icosahedral multi-enveloped DNA virus, classified as the only member of the family Asfarviridae, genus Asfivirus (Dixon et al., 2005). ASFV genome encodes a significant number of viral enzymes, viral transcription factors and immune homologues among others. The viral particle contains 54 structural proteins. Nearly, a hundred proteins have been identified on the target cells during ASFV infection, particularly in pig macrophages (Dixon, Chapman, Netherton, & Upton, 2013). Both, structural and infection-related proteins can regulate, inhibit and modulate essential and non-essential mechanisms affecting virus replication, virus particle production and apoptosis. Some of them are based on the inhibition of host transcription factors, the interferon response or several immune cell subsets, to evade host immune system.
response: African swine fever virus (ASFV) is a complex, large, icosahedral, multi‑enveloped DNA virus and the sole member of the family **Asfarviridae** (genus **Asfivirus**). Its genome encodes many viral enzymes, transcription factors, and immune-related homologues. The virion contains **54 structural proteins**, and nearly **100 proteins** have been identified on infected target cells, especially **pig macrophages**. Both structural and infection-related proteins can regulate, inhibit, or modulate host and viral processes affecting viral replication, particle production, and apoptosis, including evasion of host immunity by inhibiting host transcription factors, the interferon response, or various immune cell subsets.

query: African horse sickness virus (AHSV) is a member of the genus Orbivirus in the family Reoviridae (Calisher & Mertens 1998). It contains 10 linear double-stranded RNA segments which code for seven structural (VP1-7) and at least five non-structural proteins (NS1-4, S10-ORF2; Belhouchet et al. 2011; Roy, Mertens & Casal 1994; Stewart et al. 2015; Zwart et al. 2015). The gene segment coding for VP6 (segment 9) also codes for NS4, while segment 10 encodes NS3/3A and S10-ORF2. The structural proteins are arranged in three concentric layers, with VP2 and VP5 forming the outer capsid and are associated with cell attachment and inducing apoptosis (Manole et al. 2012; Vermaak & Theron 2015). The inner capsid consists of VP7 and VP3. It encloses the minor structural proteins VP1, VP4 and VP6 (replication complex) and the genome itself (Maree & Paweska 2005; Mellor & Hamblin 2004). There is currently no cure for AHS and the disease is controlled by vaccination. Although the vaccine is effective, there is the potential that the attenuated vaccine may revert to virulence. In addition, infected animals cannot be differentiated from vaccinated animals, a factor which is important in non-endemic areas (Kanai et al. 2014)
response: African horse sickness virus (AHSV) is an Orbivirus (family Reoviridae) with a genome of 10 linear double-stranded RNA segments encoding seven structural proteins (VP1–VP7) and at least five non-structural proteins (NS1–NS4 and S10-ORF2). Segment 9 (VP6) also encodes NS4, and segment 10 encodes NS3/3A and S10-ORF2. The virus has three capsid layers: the outer capsid (VP2 and VP5) is involved in cell attachment and apoptosis induction, while the inner capsid (VP7 and VP3) surrounds the replication complex (VP1, VP4, VP6) and the genome. There is no cure for African horse sickness; control relies on vaccination, but attenuated vaccines may revert to virulence and do not allow differentiation of infected from vaccinated animals, which is important in non-endemic areas.

query: Norovirus, an ssRNA + virus of the family Caliciviridae, is a leading disease burden in humans worldwide, causing an estimated 600 million cases of acute gastroenteritis every year. Since the discovery of norovirus in the faeces of swine in Japan in the 1990s, swine norovirus has been reported in several countries on several continents. The identification of the human-associated GII.4 genotype in swine has raised questions about this animal species as a reservoir of norovirus with zoonotic potential, even if species-specific P-types are usually detected in swine.
response: Norovirus is a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus in the family Caliciviridae and a major global cause of human disease, responsible for an estimated 600 million acute gastroenteritis cases annually. Since its detection in swine faeces in Japan in the 1990s, swine norovirus has been reported in multiple countries across several continents. Finding the human-associated GII.4 genotype in swine has raised concerns that pigs could act as a reservoir with zoonotic potential, although swine typically carry species-specific P-types.

query: CSFV can be assigned to three genotypes with three to four sub-genotypes (Lowings et al., 1996; Paton et al., 2000). Only recently, a new sub-genotype was added to genotype 1 (Postel et al., 2013b). The newly formed sub-genotype 1.4 comprises Cuban isolates that were so far placed into sub-genotype 1.2 (de Arce et al., 2005; Pereda et al., 2005). Regrouping was done after phylogenetic analyses of full-length E2 sequences revealed that these isolates formed a separate sub-genotype and were quite divergent from other genotype 1 strains. An additional differentiation and sub-grouping was suggested for sub-genotypes 2.1 (Cha et al., 2007; Chen et al., 2008; Jiang et al., 2013) and 2.3 (Blome et al., 2010). However, these systems were not internationally harmonized (e.g. clades/clusters 2.1a-2.1c, cluster 2.3.1 and 2.3.2). The latter sub-genotype was also subdivided within the EU based on clusters or lineages observed in the  $5^{\prime}$ -NTR-based phylogenetic tree. These clusters or lineages (e.g. 2.3 'Rostock') were mainly named after German regions (Wonnemann et al., 2001), and are sometimes still found in the literature (Fritzemeier et al., 2000; Depner et al., 2006; Simon et al., 2013). The most divergent strains are the genotype 3 CSFV strains 'Kanagawa' (Japan, 1974) and 'Congenital Tremor' (United Kingdom, 1964). The former has been suggested as harmonized outgroup strain for phylogenetic analyses (Paton et al., 2000).
response: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is classified into three genotypes, each with three to four sub-genotypes, with a newly added sub-genotype 1.4. Sub-genotype 1.4 includes Cuban isolates previously classified as 1.2, reassigned after full-length E2 phylogenetic analyses showed they form a distinct and highly divergent group within genotype 1. Additional sub-grouping schemes have been proposed for sub-genotypes 2.1 and 2.3, but these have not been internationally harmonized (e.g., 2.1a–2.1c; 2.3.1–2.3.2). Within the EU, sub-genotype 2.3 was also subdivided using 5′-NTR-based phylogenies into clusters/lineages often named after German regions (e.g., 2.3 “Rostock”), which still appear in some literature. The most divergent genotype 3 strains are “Kanagawa” (Japan, 1974) and “Congenital Tremor” (UK, 1964); “Kanagawa” has been suggested as a harmonized outgroup for phylogenetic analyses.

query: Influenza A is a zoonotic disease threatening economies and public health worldwide. Swine are important hosts in the ecology and epidemiology of influenza A virus (IAV) and periodic bi-directional transmission of IAV between pigs and people occurs worldwide (Myers et al., 2007, Nelson et al., 2012, Nelson & Vincent, 2015).
