The role of swine as a source of IAVs that impact human health has received considerable public attention following the pandemic caused by influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 in 2009 (Garten et al., 2009) and the 343 H3N2 variant IAV cases occurring in 2011-2014 (CDC, 2015). In the United States, there are generally limited opportunities for large populations of pigs and humans to intersect with each other; however, live animal markets and agricultural fairs are unique swine-human interfaces that have been associated with the recent variant influenza cases (Jhung et al., 2013, Wong et al., 2012, Choi et al., 2014). In contrast to the smaller human populaces visiting live animal markets, agricultural fairs in North America attract nearly 150 million attendees each year (International Association of Fairs and Expositions, personal communication, 2011), providing non-swine producers direct contact with pigs and the IAVs they might carry and vice versa. Additionally, the structure of many agricultural fairs results in co-housing multi-source pigs in a single location for multiple days, a time period sufficient for the spread and amplification of IAV through the swine population. These conditions make agricultural fairs suitable for zoonotic IAV transmission.
response: Influenza A is a worldwide zoonotic threat to public health and economies. Swine are key hosts in influenza A virus (IAV) ecology, with periodic two-way transmission between pigs and humans. Public concern increased after the 2009 H1N1 pandemic and 343 H3N2 variant human cases in 2011–2014. Although large-scale pig–human contact is generally limited in the U.S., live animal markets and especially agricultural fairs are important interfaces linked to recent variant cases. North American agricultural fairs draw about 150 million attendees annually, creating direct contact between pigs and many non-swine producers and enabling transmission. Fair practices—such as co-housing pigs from multiple sources for several days—facilitate IAV spread and amplification in swine, making fairs conducive to zoonotic transmission.

query: Classical swine fever (CSF) is an Office International des Epizooties (OIE)-listed, highly contagious, often fatal disease of swine. It is distributed almost worldwide. The disease is caused by classical swine fever virus (CSFV), a member of the Pestivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family. CSFV is genetically and serologically related to other pestiviruses, including bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV)-1, BVDV-2, and border disease virus (BDV). Pigs can be infected by other pestiviruses. Currently, CSF is controlled by a non-vaccination, stamping-out policy or prophylactic vaccination.
response: Classical swine fever (CSF) is an OIE-listed, highly contagious and often fatal swine disease with an almost worldwide distribution. It is caused by classical swine fever virus (CSFV), a Pestivirus in the Flaviviridae family, which is genetically and serologically related to other pestiviruses such as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV)-1, BVDV-2, and border disease virus (BDV); pigs can also be infected by other pestiviruses. CSF is currently controlled either by a non-vaccination stamping-out policy or by prophylactic vaccination.

query: The main components in the epidemiology of African swine fever (ASF) have been known since the first description of the disease: soft Ornithodoros spp. ticks, wart-hogs, domestic pigs, and pig-derived products such as pork. Three independent epidemiologic cycles (sylvatic, tick-pig, and domestic) have been described  $(I)$  (Figure). In the sylvatic cycle, ASF virus circulates between the natural reservoirs of the virus (i.e., warthogs and soft ticks), without causing disease in the warthogs. This ancient cycle is the origin of the tick-pig cycle and the domestic cycle and thus the origin of ASF as a disease. In the tick-pig cycle, the virus circulates between soft ticks and domestic pigs. This cycle has mainly been described in sub-Saharan Africa, but also played an important role during the epizootic on the Iberian Peninsula. In the domestic cycle, the virus is transmitted among domestic pigs, or from pig products to domestic pigs. This cycle does not involve the natural reservoirs.
response: African swine fever (ASF) epidemiology involves soft Ornithodoros ticks, warthogs, domestic pigs, and pig-derived products (e.g., pork). Three independent transmission cycles are described: (1) the sylvatic cycle, where the virus circulates between warthogs and soft ticks without causing disease in warthogs and serves as the origin of ASF and the other cycles; (2) the tick–pig cycle, where the virus circulates between soft ticks and domestic pigs, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa and also important in the Iberian Peninsula epizootic; and (3) the domestic cycle, where transmission occurs among domestic pigs or via pig products to pigs, without involvement of natural reservoirs.

query: Swine play an important role in the ecology and evolution of IAVs. They can be naturally infected with IAVs of both avian and human origin because they express both SA receptor types in their respiratory tract, making them possible intermediate hosts and appropriate 'mixing vessels' for generating reassortants (Ito et al., 1998; Yang et al., 2016). Therefore, enzootic swine influenza A viruses (swIAVs) are not only of veterinary, but also of potential public health concerns. In addition to economic losses to farmers, swIAVs may sporadically be transmitted to humans causing subclinical or mild respiratory symptoms indistinguishable from that of seasonal influenza, but can harbour pandemic propensity as well (Corzo et al., 2013; Epperson et al., 2013; Kong et al., 2015; Shinde et al., 2009). Enzootic swIAVs of subtypes H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 of different origins (avian or human) and genetic constellations circulate at variable frequencies in swine populations worldwide with the occasional emergence of other subtypes restricted temporally and geographically (Corzo et al., 2013; Harder et al., 2013; Zhu et al., 2011). For instance, H1N1 that circulates in European swine is a purely avian-derived virus transmitted into the swine population in 1979, while in North America, several H1N1 virus
response: Swine are important in the ecology and evolution of influenza A viruses (IAVs) because they can be naturally infected with both avian- and human-origin IAVs due to having both sialic acid (SA) receptor types in their respiratory tract, making them “mixing vessels” that can generate reassortant viruses. As a result, enzootic swine influenza A viruses (swIAVs) are a veterinary and potential public health concern: they cause economic losses and can occasionally transmit to humans, typically causing subclinical or mild influenza-like illness but with potential pandemic risk. Globally, enzootic swIAVs mainly circulate as H1N1, H1N2, and H3N2 with diverse origins and genetic constellations, while other subtypes emerge only sporadically and with limited time/geography. An example given is that European swine H1N1 is purely avian-derived and entered swine in 1979; the text is cut off when beginning to describe North American H1N1.

query: Classical swine fever (CSF), also known as hog cholera, is a highly contagious disease of pigs<sup>1,2</sup> caused by a pestivirus. In its acute form, typical clinical signs can include fever, hyperaemia or cyanosis of the extremities, loss of appetite, vomiting, abortions, convulsions and/or a stiff gait and eventual death.<sup>3</sup> In the chronic form, clinical signs are generally milder and persist for 3 to 4 weeks. The incubation period of pigs infected postnatally is 2 to 14 days (up to 3 months in chronic cases), while pigs exposed prenatally may be persistently infected throughout life. In infected holdings, up to  $43\%$  of pregnant sows may become carriers.<sup>4</sup> Infection can result in high within-holding mortality rates and substantial economic losses due to reductions in productivity and increased feed costs.<sup>5</sup>
response: Classical swine fever (CSF), or hog cholera, is a highly contagious pig disease caused by a pestivirus. In acute cases it can cause fever, hyperaemia or cyanosis of the extremities, loss of appetite, vomiting, abortions, convulsions and/or stiff gait, often leading to death; chronic cases have milder signs lasting 3–4 weeks. The incubation period is 2–14 days after postnatal infection (up to 3 months in chronic cases), while prenatal exposure can result in lifelong persistent infection, and in infected holdings up to 43% of pregnant sows may become carriers. CSF can cause high within-holding mortality and major economic losses from reduced productivity and increased feed costs.

query: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a single stranded, non-segmented, positive-sense RNA virus that belongs to the family Flavi-viridae, genus Pestivirus (Francki et al., 1991). This lipid-enveloped RNA virus infects domestic and wild pigs worldwide, and causes major losses in stock farming. CSFV infection is associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombocytopenia and immunosuppression (Yin and Liu, 1997). The CSFV genome is approximately 12,300 nucleotides in length and comprises a long open reading frame (ORF) flanked by  $5^{\prime}$  and  $3^{\prime}$  untranslated regions (UTRs). The ORF is translated to a primary polyprotein and then subsequently processed into 12 mature proteins by cellular and viral proteases, including eight nonstructural proteins (Npro, P7, NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, NS5B) and four structural proteins (C, Erns, E1, E2; (Rice, 1996; Thiel et al., 1991).
response: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a lipid-enveloped, single-stranded, non-segmented, positive-sense RNA virus in the family *Flaviviridae*, genus *Pestivirus*. It infects domestic and wild pigs worldwide, causing major losses in stock farming, and is associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombocytopenia, and immunosuppression. Its ~12,300-nucleotide genome contains a long open reading frame flanked by 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions; the ORF is translated into a polyprotein that is cleaved by cellular and viral proteases into 12 mature proteins: four structural (C, Erns, E1, E2) and eight nonstructural (Npro, P7, NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, NS5B).

query: Human-origin influenza A(H1N1) pandemic 2009 (pdm09) viruses are regularly isolated from swine in North America and Europe (1, 2). The global seasonal spread of A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses in humans and their re-introduction into swine resulted in the generation of circulating swine-associated genetic clades (3, 4). The reintroduction of human viruses into swine was estimated to have occurred at least 133 times, globally, leading to the circulation and reassortment of these viruses with other circulating swine influenza A viruses (1,5). Reassortment of human A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses with North American swine influenza viruses containing the triple reassortant internal gene (TRIG) cassette was also identified resulting in numerous genome constellations found in pigs since the 2009 pandemic (6, 7). This onward reassortment of swine-origin A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses has greatly increased their genetic variability and generated novel genotypes of unknown phenotypic and epidemiologic consequences.
response: Human-origin A(H1N1)pdm09 influenza viruses are frequently detected in swine in North America and Europe. Their global spread in humans and repeated spillback into pigs has produced swine-associated genetic clades; reintroduction from humans to swine is estimated to have occurred at least 133 times worldwide. Once in swine, these viruses have circulated and reassorted with other swine influenza A viruses, including reassortment with North American swine viruses carrying the triple reassortant internal gene (TRIG) cassette, generating many genome constellations in pigs since 2009. Continued reassortment has markedly increased genetic diversity and produced novel genotypes with unknown phenotypic and epidemiologic impacts.

query: African swine fever (ASF) is a serious disease of domestic pigs caused by a DNA arbovirus (African swine fever virus [ASFV]) belonging to the family Asfaviridae (1). Its highly contagious nature and ability to spread over long distances make it 1 of the most feared diseases of pigs; it causes devastating effects on pig production as manifested in the Caucasus since its introduction from southeastern Africa during 2007 (2). Considerable spread of ASF has been reported in western Africa during the past 20 years, and, except for in Côte d'Ivoire, the disease remains endemic (3). Because discernible ASFV serotypes are lacking, the field strains are grouped genetically by using sequencing of the C-terminus of the p72 protein, which discriminates 22 genotypes (4,5). Genotype I is historically associated with outbreaks in western Africa, whereas viruses from southern and eastern Africa have higher heterogeneity, with all 22 known genotypes having been recorded within the region (5-7).
response: African swine fever (ASF) is a serious, highly contagious disease of domestic pigs caused by African swine fever virus (ASFV), a DNA arbovirus in the family Asfaviridae. Its capacity to spread long distances makes it one of the most feared pig diseases, with devastating impacts on production, exemplified by spread in the Caucasus after introduction from southeastern Africa in 2007. Over the past 20 years, ASF has spread considerably in western Africa and remains endemic there except in Côte d'Ivoire. Because ASFV lacks discernible serotypes, field strains are genetically classified by sequencing the C-terminus of the p72 protein, which distinguishes 22 genotypes: genotype I is historically linked to western African outbreaks, while southern and eastern Africa show greater diversity, with all 22 genotypes recorded.

query: Pigs play a critical role as intermediate hosts in the transmission of influenza viruses from another species such as humans and birds, and thereby contribute to the establishment of new, potentially virulent strains (Ito et al., 1998; Brown, 2000; De Vleeschauwer et al., 2009). Such virulence is demonstrated by the capacity of a given strain to provoke an uncontrolled, excessive immune response to infection, subsequent to the massive release of proinflammatory cytokines and chemoattractants in the lung. This potentially fatal scenario has been metaphorically described as a 'cytokine storm' (Osterholm, 2005).
response: Pigs are important intermediate hosts that can transmit influenza viruses between species (e.g., from humans and birds), helping generate new and potentially virulent strains. Such virulence can involve triggering an uncontrolled, excessive immune response in the lung, marked by massive release of proinflammatory cytokines and chemoattractants, a potentially fatal process known as a “cytokine storm.”

query: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) infection causes mild to severe diseases among pigs, depending on the age and immune status of the host and viral strains. CSFV targets various cells, including macrophages and conventional and plasmacytoid dendritic cells. Classical swine fever is one of the most devastating diseases of pigs which leads to high morbidity and mortality, and causes significant economic loss worldwide. In response to infection with CSFV, host innate immune system eliminates the virus by recognizing specific viral molecules via distinct cellular pattern recognition receptors. These receptors trigger downstream intracellular signaling pathways, which regulate the translocation and activation of transcription factors that control the production of cytokines and interferons (IFNs). In turn, these IFNs activate JAK-STAT signaling that governs the transcription of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) that play critical roles in antiviral immunity. However, CSFV has evolved different strategies to evade innate immune signaling and can establish persistent infection without being recognized by immune surveillance.
response: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) causes diseases in pigs ranging from mild to severe depending on the host’s age/immune status and the viral strain, and it is highly devastating with high morbidity and mortality and major worldwide economic losses. CSFV infects multiple cell types, including macrophages and both conventional and plasmacytoid dendritic cells. Host innate immunity counters infection by using pattern recognition receptors to detect viral molecules and activate signaling pathways that induce cytokines and interferons (IFNs); IFNs then trigger JAK-STAT signaling to drive interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) important for antiviral defense. CSFV can evade these innate immune pathways and establish persistent infection without immune detection.

query: The SLA complex corresponds to a genomic region of 2.40 (haplotype Hp-1.1) to 2.66 Mb (genome assembly Sscrofa11.1) that maps to chromosome 7 (SSC7) and spans the centromere (1) (Figure 1a; Supplemental Figure 1). It consists of three regions, the class I and class III regions mapping to 7p1.1 and the class II region mapping to 7q1.1 (Figure 1a). The split of the MHC complex by the centromere in swine is unique among mammals studied to date. By convention and in agreement with reports on other vertebrate species, the class I and class II regions include the MHC class I and II gene series, respectively, together with many non-MHC genes with various functions. The class III region, located between the class I and II regions, does not contain MHC genes but comprises key immunity-related genes. Thus, as shown in Figure 1a (more detail in Supplemental Figure 2), the SLA complex includes clusters of MHC gene series embedded among non-MHC genes that were well conserved during evolution across mammals and are referred to as anchor genes (2). The MHC gene clusters correspond to the hot spots of functional polymorphisms from which SLA complex haplotypes in class Ia and II are defined (Figure 1b).
response: The swine leukocyte antigen (SLA) complex is a 2.40–2.66 Mb genomic region on pig chromosome 7 (SSC7) that spans the centromere. It is divided into three regions: class I and class III on 7p1.1 and class II on 7q1.1; this centromere split of the MHC is unique among mammals studied. Class I and II regions contain the respective MHC gene series plus many non-MHC genes, while the intervening class III region lacks MHC genes but contains key immunity-related genes. Overall, the SLA comprises MHC gene clusters interspersed with evolutionarily conserved non-MHC “anchor genes,” and the MHC clusters are hotspots of functional polymorphism used to define SLA class Ia and II haplotypes.

query: PCV2 is divided into five genotypes according to the Cap gene sequence: PCV2a, 2b, 2c, 2d, and 2e [2,21]. Moreover, the PCV2b genotype is classified into three clusters, 1A to 1C, and the PCV2a genotype is subdivided into five clusters, 2A to 2F [2,22-24]. Recently, a retrospective study of PCV2 infection between 1996 and 1999 in China revealed a novel genotype PCV2f which shared lower sequence identity with the other known genotypes [25]. Since the discovery of PCV2 in the late 1990s, the virus has continued to evolve, and two major genotype shifts have been observed. The first genotype shift in PCV2 was from PCV2a to PCV2b in 2004/2005 [26,27]. Since 2012, the predominant PCV2b has been gradually replaced by the PCV2d genotype in North America, China, South Korea and Uruguay [22,26-30]. Besides, PCV2F becomes the predominant genotype in the PCV2a cluster in China [22].
response: PCV2 is classified into five genotypes based on the Cap gene sequence (PCV2a, PCV2b, PCV2c, PCV2d, PCV2e). PCV2b is further divided into three clusters (1A–1C), and PCV2a into five clusters (2A–2F). A retrospective study in China (1996–1999) identified a novel genotype, PCV2f, with lower sequence identity to known genotypes. Since PCV2’s discovery in the late 1990s, two major genotype shifts have occurred: PCV2a was replaced by PCV2b around 2004/2005, and since 2012 PCV2d has gradually replaced PCV2b as the predominant genotype in North America, China, South Korea, and Uruguay. In China, PCV2f has become the predominant genotype within the PCV2a cluster.

query: Currently, African swine fever (ASF) constitutes the biggest threat faced by the world pork industry. The causative agent, African swine fever (ASFV), is a large and complex double-stranded DNA virus belonging to the Asfarviridae family [1]. ASFV affects domestic pigs and wild boars as well as other African suids. Clinical signs during infection vary considerably from acute forms, with mortality rates up to  $90 - 100\%$  in domestic pigs and wild boar to inapparent infections in bushpigs (Potamochoerus sp.) and warthogs (Phacochoerus sp.). The latter are involved in the sylvatic cycle with a soft tick vector Ornithodoros sp. [2]. The mature viral particle has an icosahedral morphology with a size range of  $180 - 200 \mathrm{~nm}$  in diameter and is composed of multiple layers (nucleoprotein core, core shell, inner envelope, viral capsid and external envelope when the virus egresses from the cell) [3]. The genome is a double-stranded DNA molecule located in the nucleoprotein core, with approximately 170 to  $193 \mathrm{kbp}$  codifying for 151 to 167 open reading frames (ORFs). Most differences in genome size are associated with the gain or loss of members of multigene families (MGF) [4,5].
response: African swine fever (ASF) is currently the biggest threat to the global pork industry. It is caused by African swine fever virus (ASFV), a large, complex double-stranded DNA virus in the family Asfarviridae. ASFV infects domestic pigs, wild boars, and other African suids, producing disease ranging from acute infections with up to 90–100% mortality in domestic pigs and wild boar to inapparent infections in bushpigs and warthogs, which participate in a sylvatic cycle involving soft ticks (Ornithodoros spp.). The mature virion is icosahedral, about 180–200 nm in diameter, and has multiple layers (nucleoprotein core, core shell, inner envelope, capsid, and an external envelope during egress). Its genome is a 170–193 kbp dsDNA encoding about 151–167 ORFs, with genome size variation mainly due to gain/loss of multigene family (MGF) members.

query: Feral swine are an invasive species introduced into the United States by Spanish explorers in the 1500s and have significantly expanded their range to at least 38 states (35, 36). Swine were introduced to Hawai'i much earlier when Polynesian voyagers settled on the islands (37). Feral swine are the same species as domesticated swine, Sus scrofa, and often include a variety of phenotypic and genotypic traits from both populations (35, 38). At about 1 year of age, female swine can breed and produce up to ten piglets each year (39). The rapid reproduction rate and lack of predation have aided the geographic and population expansion of feral swine (35). The expansion of feral swine across the United States is a concern for numerous reasons, including conservation of threatened/endangered species; damage to agriculture and livestock, leading to major economic loss; and transmission of pathogens to humans or livestock (40). For example, a proportion of feral swine in the state of Texas have been found to harbor antibodies against Bacillus anthracis, suggesting exposure to the causative agent of anthrax (41). Feral swine are also a reservoir for other human and animal diseases including, but not limited to, brucellosis, trichinellosis, tuberculosis, leptospirosis, and classical swine fever (42). Understanding the distribution of pathogens within feral swine populations is critical to identify and mitigate threats to humans, livestock, and wildlife from the pathogens disseminated by this invasive and destructive species.
response: Feral swine (Sus scrofa) are an invasive species introduced to the United States by Spanish explorers in the 1500s and have expanded to at least 38 states; they were introduced to Hawai‘i earlier by Polynesian voyagers. They are the same species as domestic swine and often show mixed traits from both feral and domesticated populations. Females can breed at about 1 year old and produce up to ten piglets annually, and their rapid reproduction plus limited predation has driven major range and population growth. This expansion threatens conservation of endangered species, damages agriculture and livestock with significant economic losses, and increases pathogen transmission risks to humans and livestock. Evidence includes Texas feral swine with antibodies to Bacillus anthracis (anthrax exposure), and they also serve as reservoirs for diseases such as brucellosis, trichinellosis, tuberculosis, leptospirosis, and classical swine fever. Monitoring pathogen distribution in feral swine is important to mitigate risks to humans, livestock, and wildlife.

query: Probiotics not only reduce intestinal pathogens but also detoxify harmful compounds in feed through hydrolytic enzymes and the production of vitamins, biotin, and vitamin B12 [24, 25]. Growth elevation with improved feed utilization can ensure improved yields at lower production costs which are of value to aquaculture. Several authors have characterized responses to probiotics including alterations of digestive enzyme synthesis and release [26] and of intestinal structure to increase nutrient digestion and absorption [27], influencing the final body weight gain and production scale.
response: Probiotics can reduce intestinal pathogens and detoxify harmful feed compounds via hydrolytic enzymes, while also producing vitamins such as biotin and vitamin B12. They can enhance growth by improving feed utilization, leading to higher aquaculture yields at lower production costs. Reported probiotic effects include changes in digestive enzyme synthesis and release and modifications of intestinal structure that increase nutrient digestion and absorption, ultimately improving body weight gain and production scale.

query: There are many reasons why an ASFV vaccine has proved so elusive. First, the virus itself is large and complex with many proteins, some of which have adapted to evade the immune response of the host (Powell and others 1996, Sanchez and others 2013). The virus is also variable, with many genotypes in existence and limited or no cross-protection across genotypes (Bastos and others 2003). Second, the host-immune response to the virus is complex, with only partial protection produced by neutralising antibodies (Escri-ano and others 2013), with the cell mediated arm of the immune system (T cells) playing an important complementary role (Oura and others 2005, Takamatsu and others 2013). Simple inactivation or attenuation of the virus does not produce sufficient protection, and the administration of individual recombinant proteins and/or DNA only gives partial protection (Argilaguet and others 2013).
response: An African swine fever virus (ASFV) vaccine has been difficult to develop because: (1) ASFV is a large, complex virus with many proteins, some adapted to evade the host immune response; it is also genetically variable, with many genotypes and limited or no cross-protection between them. (2) The host immune response is complex: neutralising antibodies provide only partial protection, while T-cell (cell-mediated) immunity plays an important complementary role. As a result, simple virus inactivation or attenuation is insufficient, and vaccines based on individual recombinant proteins and/or DNA have produced only partial protection.

query: Hepatitis is an inflammatory condition of the liver. In dogs infectious canine hepatitis is caused by Canine mastadenovirus A (formerly called Canine adenovirus 1 [CAV-­1]). The clinical signs of pyrexia, jaundice, vomiting and signs of encephalopathy are typical of canine hepatitis and usually resolve after a brief illness. Most dogs receive an effective vaccine. In the large domestic animals, hepatitis is usually due to ingested plant toxins, e.g. ragwort.
response: Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver. In dogs, infectious canine hepatitis is caused by Canine mastadenovirus A (formerly Canine adenovirus 1, CAV-1) and typically presents with fever (pyrexia), jaundice, vomiting, and signs of encephalopathy, usually resolving after a brief illness; most dogs are protected by an effective vaccine. In large domestic animals, hepatitis is usually caused by ingested plant toxins such as ragwort.

query: Betanodavirus virions were first described as non-enveloped, spherical in shape, and have icosahedral symmetry, with a diameter around  $25\mathrm{nm}$  and a capsid formed by 180 copies of a  single protein of 42 Kda (Mori et al. 1992). A similar virus of  $20 - 34\mathrm{nm}$  in diameter was detected in infected Asian sea bass Lates calcarifer larvae, striped jack Pseudocaranx dentex, turbot Scophthalmus maximus, European sea bass Dicentrarchus labrax (Yoshikoshi & Inoue 1990; Glazebrook et al. 1990; Bloch et al. 1991; Munday et al. 1992) and many various fish species through the world were subsequently recorded to be infected by betanodaviruses (Munday et al. 2002; Shetty et al. 2012).
response: Betanodavirus virions were first described as non-enveloped, spherical, icosahedral particles about 25 nm in diameter, with a capsid made of 180 copies of a single 42 kDa protein. Similar viruses (20–34 nm) were detected in infected larvae or fish of several species (Asian sea bass, striped jack, turbot, and European sea bass), and later many fish species worldwide were reported to be infected by betanodaviruses.

query: Probiotic Bacillus has been proven to better combat a wide range of fish pathogens relative to other probiotics in aquaculture; therefore, understanding the various mechanisms used by Bacillus in combating diseases will help improve their mode of action hence yielding better results in their combat against pathogens in the aquaculture industry. Thus, an overview of the mechanisms (production of bacteriocins, suppression of virulence gene expression, competition for adhesion sites, production of lytic enzymes, production of antibiotics, immunostimulation, competition for nutrients and energy, and production of organic acids) used by Bacillus probiotics in mitigating fish pathogens ranging from Aeromonas, Vibrio, Streptococcus, Yersinia, Pseudomonas, Clostridium, Acinetobacter, Edwardsiella, Flavobacterium, white spot syndrome virus, and infectious hypodermal and hematopoietic necrosis virus proven to be mitigated by Bacillus have been provided.
response: Probiotic **Bacillus** has been shown to combat a broader range of fish pathogens in aquaculture than other probiotics. Understanding its disease-fighting mechanisms can improve its effectiveness. The text outlines Bacillus mechanisms including **bacteriocin production, suppression of virulence gene expression, competition for adhesion sites, lytic enzyme production, antibiotic production, immunostimulation, competition for nutrients and energy, and organic acid production**. Bacillus has been reported to mitigate pathogens such as **Aeromonas, Vibrio, Streptococcus, Yersinia, Pseudomonas, Clostridium, Acinetobacter, Edwardsiella, Flavobacterium**, and also viruses including **white spot syndrome virus** and **infectious hypodermal and hematopoietic necrosis virus**.

query: While the emerging viruses associated with significant clinical diseases in pigs such as PRRSV and PCV2 have justifiably received the most attention, much less is known of a number of emerging and re-emerging swine viruses with a limited or uncertain clinical significance on pig health including swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV) (Meng et al., 1997), Torque teno sus virus (TTSuV) (Okamoto et al., 2002), porcine bocavirus (PBoV) and related novel porcine parvovirus (PPV) (Lau et al., 2008; Blomström et al., 2009), porcine kobuvirus (Reuter et al., 2008), porcine toroviruses (PToV) (Kroneman et al., 1998), porcine lymphotropic herpesviruses (PLHV) (Ehlers et al., 1999), porcine endogenous retrovirus (PERV) (Pal et al., 2011) and porcine sapovirus (porcine SaV) (Guo et al., 1999) (Table 1). Most of these swine viruses are ubiquitous in swine population worldwide and are extremely understudied, and consequently their biology, epidemiology and pathogenicity are poorly understood. The effects of concurrent infections with multiple swine agents on pig health and on the efficacies of modified live-attenuated viral vaccines in swine require further investigations. Importantly, some of these emerging swine viruses such as NiV (Chua et al., 2000), Menangle virus (Philbey et al., 1998) and swine HEV (Meng et al., 2011) have zoonotic potential and pose a risk for human infection, especially in the high-risk population such as swine veterinarians, producers and other pig handlers. For example, swine HEV is a recognized zoonotic virus and has been definitively linked to sporadic and cluster cases of acute hepatitis in humans who have consumed raw or undercooked pork products (reviewed in Meng, 2010a,b, 2011a,b). Other emerging swine viruses such as PLHV and PERV are also of concern in human xenotransplantation with pig organs, tissues and cells (Abrahante et al., 2011).
response: In addition to major swine pathogens like PRRSV and PCV2, several emerging or re-emerging swine viruses with limited or uncertain clinical significance are poorly understood, including swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV), Torque teno sus virus (TTSuV), porcine bocavirus (PBoV) and related novel porcine parvovirus (PPV), porcine kobuvirus, porcine toroviruses (PToV), porcine lymphotropic herpesviruses (PLHV), porcine endogenous retrovirus (PERV), and porcine sapovirus (SaV). Most are ubiquitous worldwide but understudied, leaving gaps in knowledge about their biology, epidemiology, and pathogenicity. Further research is needed on how co-infections affect pig health and the efficacy of modified live-attenuated viral vaccines. Some (e.g., Nipah virus, Menangle virus, and swine HEV) have zoonotic potential and may infect high-risk groups such as veterinarians and pig handlers; swine HEV is definitively linked to human acute hepatitis from consuming raw or undercooked pork. PLHV and PERV are also concerns for human xenotransplantation using pig organs, tissues, or cells.

query: The evolution of pandemic viruses requires a 'perfect ecological storm' in which multiple host populations perform at least two key functions: (a) generating and sustaining viral diversity and (b) transmitting viral diversity to humans. Reservoir hosts serve the former role, harboring high viral genetic diversity but with low rates of direct contact with humans (such as wild birds, bats, or rodents) (5). Intermediary hosts are typically livestock or domestic animals that serve the latter role: they often harbor only a subset of the viral diversity that circulates in reservoir hosts yet are capable of transmitting viral diversity to humans via high rates of contact (1). In the United States, commercial swine serve as reservoir hosts, and exhibition swine effectively serve as intermediary hosts. Commercial swine are produced for food production exclusively in a year-round system that is highly conducive to the evolution and sustained transmission of genetically diverse viruses (6), but less conducive to zoonotic transmission, with high biosecurity and less frequent contact with humans. In contrast, exhibition swine effectively serve as intermediary hosts because they are raised and exhibited in a system with low biosecurity that maximizes human contact (7, 8) but purges genetic diversity and host immunity at the end of the summer show season when exhibition swine finish showing and a new cohort of swine are raised for next year (9). A production system in which commercial and exhibition swine are occasionally raised together provides opportunities for genetically diverse viruses to end up at county fairs and find their way into humans (10-12).
response: Pandemic viruses tend to emerge under a “perfect ecological storm” in which different host populations (1) generate and sustain viral genetic diversity and (2) transmit that diversity to humans. Reservoir hosts (e.g., wild birds, bats, rodents) maintain high viral diversity but have relatively little direct human contact, while intermediary hosts (often livestock/domestic animals) carry a subset of that diversity but have frequent human contact enabling spillover. In the United States, commercial swine function as reservoir hosts because year-round, high-throughput production supports evolution and sustained circulation of diverse viruses, yet high biosecurity limits zoonotic transmission. Exhibition swine function as intermediary hosts because low biosecurity and intense human contact promote transmission to people, though viral diversity and immunity are reduced when the show season ends and animals are replaced. Occasional mixing of commercial and exhibition swine can move diverse viruses into county fairs, creating pathways for human infection.

query: Bacterial gill disease (BGD) is a common and occasionally devastating disease that affects numerous cultured fish species throughout the world (Starliper & Schill 2012). Outbreaks of BGD tend to occur when environmental conditions deteriorate, and opportunistic pathogens can more readily cause overt disease (Bullock 1972; Schachte 1983). The putative causative agent, Flavobacterium branchiophilum, has been shown to induce BGD under laboratory conditions (e.g. Lumsden et al. 1995; Ostland et al. 1995); however, diagnosis of BGD in the field is generally carried out through light microscopy and/or observation of clinical signs. Therefore, the identity of the bacterial specie(s) present on the gills of BGD-affected fish in culture settings is most often based on visual assessment alone. The observed bacteria using microscopy are presumed to be  $F$  branchiophilum based on organism morphology (numerous long, thin rods; Fig. 1.), with this presumption supported by previous BGD research (e.g. Byrne et al. 1995; Ostland et al. 1997; Derksen, Ostland & Ferguson 1998) and various  $F.$  branchiophilumspecific diagnostic approaches that have been developed. The latter include ELISA (MacPhee et al. 1995), IFAT (Heo, Kasai & Wakabayashi 1990), and PCR (Toyama, Kita & Wakabayashi 1996).
response: Bacterial gill disease (BGD) is a widespread and sometimes severe disease affecting many cultured fish species worldwide. Outbreaks commonly occur when environmental conditions worsen, allowing opportunistic pathogens to cause disease. *Flavobacterium branchiophilum* is considered the likely causative agent and has been shown to induce BGD in laboratory studies, but field diagnosis is usually based on light microscopy and/or clinical signs rather than definitive identification. As a result, the bacteria on gills of affected fish are often identified mainly by visual assessment, with organisms seen under microscopy presumed to be *F. branchiophilum* based on characteristic morphology (many long, thin rods), supported by prior research and available *F. branchiophilum*-specific tests such as ELISA, IFAT, and PCR.

query: The hypothalamus in chickens is responsible for controlling temperature regulation, feeding behavior, water balance, and reproduction. It plays a vital role in maintaining homeostasis. It regulates body temperature through thermoregulatory mechanisms, ensuring that birds maintain a stable internal temperature. It is involved in the control of various behaviors, including feeding, drinking, aggression, sexual behavior, and parental care. Different hypothalamic nuclei, such as the lateral and the ventromedial hypothalamic nuclei, are associated with specific behavioral patterns (Balthazart and Ball 2007). It controls feeding behavior in chickens by regulating hunger and satiety. The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus produces neuropeptides that stimulate or suppress appetite, depending on the nutritional status of the chicken (Sohn 2015). Environmental cues, such as light, temperature, and social interactions, can influence hypothalamic function in chickens. Photoperiod, for instance, affects reproductive activities and seasonal adaptations in response to changing day lengths (Bentley 2009). The hypothalamus regulates water balance in chickens by controlling thirst and fluid intake. The supraoptic nucleus produces vasopressin which regulates water reabsorption in the kidneys.
response: The chicken hypothalamus maintains homeostasis by regulating body temperature, feeding, water balance, and reproduction. It controls thermoregulation to keep internal temperature stable and influences behaviors such as feeding, drinking, aggression, sexual behavior, and parental care, with specific nuclei (e.g., lateral and ventromedial) linked to different behaviors. Feeding is controlled through hunger and satiety regulation, including appetite-stimulating or -suppressing neuropeptides produced by the arcuate nucleus depending on nutritional status. Hypothalamic function is affected by environmental cues (light, temperature, social interactions); photoperiod in particular influences reproduction and seasonal adaptation. Water balance is regulated via control of thirst and fluid intake, with the supraoptic nucleus producing vasopressin to promote kidney water reabsorption.

query: The brachial wing vein (basilic or cutaneous ulnar vein) is the most common site for blood collection in an adult chicken (Figure 12). It can be accessed near the elbow. It runs between the biceps and triceps muscles and bifurcates just proximal to the elbow. Blood should be collected at the bifurcation. Two jugular veins are present, but the right side of the chicken’s neck allows for faster collection of larger volumes of blood (Figure 10.15). The vein is very mobile and there is a large amount of subcutaneous space, making the site prone to hematoma formation. The medial metatarsal vein in the lower leg can be used to collect blood. It is surrounded by muscles, minimizing the risk of hematoma formation, but can be difficult to locate, especially in an adult bird (Kelly and Alworth 2013).
response: In adult chickens, the most common blood-collection site is the brachial wing vein (basilic/cutaneous ulnar vein), accessed near the elbow; it runs between the biceps and triceps, bifurcates just proximal to the elbow, and blood should be collected at this bifurcation. Chickens have two jugular veins, but the right jugular allows faster collection of larger blood volumes; however, it is very mobile with substantial subcutaneous space, making hematoma formation likely. The medial metatarsal vein in the lower leg is another option; it is muscle-surrounded (reducing hematoma risk) but can be difficult to locate, especially in adult birds.

query: The pancreas has both an endocrine and an exocrine function. The pancreatic islets (islets of Langerhans) produce the endocrine secretions, insulin (beta cells), glucagon (alpha cells), somatostatin (delta cells) and pancreatic polypeptide (gamma cells), and their function is mainly the regulation of blood sugar levels. The exocrine function is the secretion of pancreatic juice containing digestive enzymes for action on carbohydrates, proteins and fats within the duodenum. The alkalinity of the pancreatic juice is maintained by the production of bicarbonate, which neutralises the acidic gastric juice.
response: The pancreas has both endocrine and exocrine functions. The endocrine pancreas (islets of Langerhans) secretes insulin (beta cells), glucagon (alpha cells), somatostatin (delta cells), and pancreatic polypeptide (gamma cells), mainly regulating blood sugar levels. The exocrine pancreas secretes pancreatic juice with digestive enzymes that act on carbohydrates, proteins, and fats in the duodenum; its bicarbonate maintains alkalinity and neutralizes acidic gastric juice.

query: Swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV) belongs to the species Orthohepevirus A within the genus Orthohepevirus in the family Hepeviridae. Four different genotypes of swine HEV within the species Orthohepevirus A have been identified so far from domesticated and wild swine population: genotypes 3 (HEV-3) and 4 (HEV-4) swine HEVs are zoonotic and infect humans, whereas HEV-5 and HEV-6 are only identified from swine. As a zoonotic agent, swine HEV is an emerging public health concern in many industrialized countries. Pigs are natural reservoir for HEV, consumption of raw or undercooked pork is an important route of foodborne HEV transmission. Occupational risks such as direct contact with infected pigs also increase the risk of HEV transmission in humans. Cross-species infection of HEV-3 and HEV-4 have been documented under experimental and natural conditions. Both swine HEV-3 and swine HEV-4 infect non-human primates, the surrogates of man. Swine HEV, predominantly HEV-3, can establish chronic infection in immunocompromised patients especially in solid organ transplant recipients. The zoonotic HEV-3, and to lesser extent HEV-4, have also been shown to cause neurological diseases and kidney injury. In this review, we focus on the epidemiology of swine HEV, host and viral determinants influencing cross-species HEV infection, zoonotic infection and its associated pork safety concern, as well as swine HEV-associated chronic infection and neurological diseases.
response: Swine hepatitis E virus (swine HEV) is classified in species *Orthohepevirus A*, genus *Orthohepevirus*, family *Hepeviridae*. Four swine HEV genotypes are identified: HEV-3 and HEV-4 are zoonotic and can infect humans, while HEV-5 and HEV-6 have only been found in swine. Swine HEV is an emerging public health concern in industrialized countries; pigs are the natural reservoir, and eating raw or undercooked pork is an important foodborne transmission route. Human risk is also increased by occupational exposure through direct contact with infected pigs. Cross-species infection by HEV-3 and HEV-4 occurs in both experimental and natural settings, and both can infect non-human primates. Swine HEV (mainly HEV-3) can cause chronic infection in immunocompromised people, especially solid organ transplant recipients, and zoonotic HEV-3 (and less often HEV-4) has been associated with neurological disease and kidney injury. The reviewed topics include swine HEV epidemiology, determinants of cross-species infection, zoonotic/pork safety concerns, and swine HEV–associated chronic and neurological disease.

query: The cuticle is an extremely thin proteinaceous layer, which plugs the entry to the shell pores and regulates the permeability to gases, liquids, and particles (Board and Halls 1973; Mortola 2009). The cuticle is deposited by the epithelial cells lining the hen uterus during the last 5 h before oviposition (Nys et al. 1999). The cuticle thickness on the eggs of domestic hens varies from 0.5 to 12.8 μm and can have an uneven or patchy distribution on the eggshell surface (Board and Halls 1973). Theoretically, the cuticle subserves diverse functions, varying from reducing water loss to the first lines of defense against bacterial penetration by blocking the external surface of pores (Kulshreshtha et al. 2018). It has been shown that cuticle composition is correlated with the hen age and egg ­freshness, and this information could be useful to design strategies to evaluate and reduce the contamination risks during egg processing (Rodríguez-­Navarro et al. 2013). The cuticle consists of 85–87% protein, 3.5–4.4% carbohydrates, 2.5–3.5% lipids, and 3.5% ash (Nys et al. 1999; Rose-­Martel et al. 2012; Rodríguez-­Navarro et al. 2013). It is recommended to lightly brush off any organic debris from eggs, rather than washing them, to prevent damage to the cuticle. If eggs are to be cleaned then it is recommended to use water that is warmer, specifically 20 °F (11 °C) warmer, than the egg so that contaminants are not drawn into the egg via vacuum action through the pores in the shell (Damerov 1994).
response: The cuticle is an extremely thin protein layer that seals eggshell pores and regulates permeability to gases, liquids, and particles. It is deposited by uterine epithelial cells in the last ~5 hours before oviposition, varies in thickness (about 0.5–12.8 μm), and may be unevenly distributed. Its proposed functions include reducing water loss and protecting against bacterial penetration by blocking pore openings. Cuticle composition correlates with hen age and egg freshness, which may help assess and reduce contamination risks during egg processing. Composition is ~85–87% protein, 3.5–4.4% carbohydrates, 2.5–3.5% lipids, and ~3.5% ash. To avoid damaging the cuticle, lightly brush off debris instead of washing; if cleaning is necessary, use water about 20°F (11°C) warmer than the egg to prevent contaminants being drawn in through shell pores by vacuum action.

query: Recent global health assessments have identified FZT as among the most important (and neglected) parasitic zoonotic diseases [1-7]. Along with bacteria and viruses, FZT can be important causes of illnesses in humans, ranging from mild gastroenteritis to life-threatening disease [8]. These infections occur in humans and other reservoir hosts as a result of ingesting raw or improperly cooked fish that are infected with the metacercaria stage of the zoonotic trematodes (or flukes). The liver flukes Opisthorchis viverrini, O. felineus, and Clonorchis sinensis are notable for causing chronic inflammation of the hepatobiliary system, which in chronic infections may lead to cholangiocarcinoma [9]. Infections with intestinal FZT (mainly species of Heterophyidae such as Haplorchis spp.) and Echinostomatidae (e.g., Echinochasmus spp.) may cause intestinal inflammation, diarrhea, and invasion of the heart, brain, and spinal cord by parasite eggs [10,11]. Other important intestinal flukes are Metagonimus spp., Centrocestus spp.,stellantchasmus falcatus,and Procerovum varium [11].
response: Fish-borne zoonotic trematodes (FZT) are globally important but neglected parasitic zoonoses that can cause human illness ranging from mild gastroenteritis to life-threatening disease. Humans and other reservoir hosts become infected by eating raw or improperly cooked fish containing the metacercariae stage of these flukes. Key liver flukes (Opisthorchis viverrini, O. felineus, and Clonorchis sinensis) cause chronic hepatobiliary inflammation and, in long-term infections, may lead to cholangiocarcinoma. Intestinal FZT—mainly Heterophyidae (e.g., Haplorchis spp.) and Echinostomatidae (e.g., Echinochasmus spp.)—can cause intestinal inflammation and diarrhea, and their eggs may invade the heart, brain, and spinal cord. Other notable intestinal flukes include Metagonimus spp., Centrocestus spp., Stellantchasmus falcatus, and Procerovum varium.

query: Aeromonas dhakensis is increasingly recognised to be an important pathogen responsible for disease losses in warm-water aquaculture and, similar to several other Aeromonas species, it can infect humans. Knowledge of A. dhakensis is accumulating, but this species remains relatively underinvestigated compared to its close relative, Aeromonas hydrophila. The significance of A. dhakensis may have been overlooked in disease events of aquatic animals due to issues with reliable identification. Critical to appreciating the importance of this pathogen is the application of dependable molecular tools that enable accurate identification and discrimination from A. hydrophila and other motile aeromonads. This review aims to synthesise the key literature on A. dhakensis, particularly with relevance to aquaculture, including knowledge of the bacterium derived from disease case studies in aquatic hosts. Identification methods and strain phylogeny are discussed, with accurate detection important for prompt diagnosis and for distinguishing strains with heightened virulence. Increasing evidence suggests that A. dhakensis may be more virulent than A. hydrophila and correct identification is required to determine the zoonotic risks posed, which includes concerns for antibiotic-resistant strains. This review provides an impetus to improve species identification in the future and screen strain collections of presumptive Aeromonas spp. retrospectively to reveal the true prevalence and impact of A. dhakensis in aquaculture, the environment, and healthcare settings.
response: Aeromonas dhakensis is an increasingly recognized pathogen causing disease losses in warm-water aquaculture and can also infect humans, but it remains less studied than Aeromonas hydrophila. Its importance has likely been underestimated because reliable identification is difficult, so accurate molecular tools are needed to distinguish it from A. hydrophila and other motile aeromonads. The reviewed literature synthesizes aquaculture-relevant knowledge (including aquatic disease case studies), discusses identification methods and strain phylogeny, and emphasizes that accurate detection supports prompt diagnosis and recognition of highly virulent strains. Evidence suggests A. dhakensis may be more virulent than A. hydrophila, and correct identification is necessary to assess zoonotic risk, including concerns about antibiotic-resistant strains. The review calls for improved identification going forward and retrospective screening of presumptive Aeromonas collections to determine the true prevalence and impact of A. dhakensis in aquaculture, the environment, and healthcare.

query: Currently, aquaculture is the fastest growing animal food sector worldwide (FAO 2014). However, fish and shellfish production is limited by several emerging diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, fungi, oomycetes, amoebas and other ectoparasites. Bacterial fish diseases are typically addressed by antibiotics (Romero et al. 2012; Cabello et al. 2013), viral diseases by vaccination (Evensen and Leong 2013) and parasitic diseases by chemical treatment (Burridge et al. 2010). However, the risk of antibiotic resistance development and the transfer of antibiotic resistance genes to other animal pathogens, as well as concerns for environmental impact and consumer safety, have stimulated the need for new sustainable control measures (Brandt et al. 2015). Vaccination is a sustainable control measure, but various viral and bacterial fish diseases, and more specifically fungal and oomycete diseases, cannot yet be controlled by vaccination (Evensen and Leong 2013; Dhar, Manna and Thomas Allnutt 2014; Holvold et al. 2014). In addition, the oral delivery of efficacious and safe vaccines remains a challenge, partly due to antigen breakdown of oral vaccines in the harsh gastric environment, the high tolerogenic gut environment and inadequate vaccine design (reviewed in Embregts and Forlenza 2016). Additional strategies for sustainable disease control include breeding for disease resistance (Gjedrem 2012), the use of plant extracts as prebiotics (Akhter et al. 2015; Van Hai 2015) and augmentation or introduction of beneficial microorganisms.
response: Aquaculture is the world’s fastest-growing animal food sector, but fish and shellfish production is constrained by emerging diseases caused by diverse pathogens (viruses, bacteria, fungi, oomycetes, amoebas, and ectoparasites). Current control methods include antibiotics for bacterial diseases, vaccination for viral diseases, and chemical treatments for parasites; however, concerns about antibiotic resistance (including gene transfer), environmental impacts, and consumer safety drive the need for sustainable alternatives. Although vaccination is considered sustainable, many viral and bacterial diseases—and especially fungal and oomycete diseases—still cannot be effectively controlled this way, and safe, effective oral vaccines remain difficult due to antigen breakdown in the stomach, a highly tolerogenic gut environment, and suboptimal vaccine design. Other sustainable approaches include selective breeding for disease resistance, using plant extracts as prebiotics, and augmenting or introducing beneficial microorganisms.

query: Bird thymus originates from the third, fourth, and fifth pharyngeal pouches. The primitive cells migrate distally to form a solid mass of cells of the future thymus. They are completely separated from the pharyngeal endodermal cells. Mesenchymal cells migrate to the thymus from the surrounding head mesenchyme and arrive through the blood vessels penetrating the thymic tissue. Head mesenchymal cells form the stroma except for the epithelial-­ reticular component which is endodermal in origin. These cells produce the meshwork or the reticulum within the thymus. The thymus migrates superficially along the cervical region close to the external jugular vein and vagus nerve to reach the entrance of the thoracic portion of the celomic cavity. It is usually represented by six to eight lobes completely separated from each other (Singh 2019) (Figure 5). One should be careful when describing the thymus location from the upper cervical to the first few thoracic vertebrae because it continues to migrate caudally and distally with age. Therefore, it will be higher in the cervical region at a very young age and lower with advancing age.
response: Bird thymus develops from the third, fourth, and fifth pharyngeal pouches: primitive cells migrate distally to form a solid thymic cell mass and become completely separated from pharyngeal endoderm. Mesenchymal cells from surrounding head mesenchyme enter the thymus via blood vessels and form the thymic stroma, except for the epithelial‑reticular component, which is endodermal in origin and produces the internal reticular meshwork. The thymus migrates superficially along the neck near the external jugular vein and vagus nerve to the entrance of the thoracic part of the coelomic cavity, and is typically composed of six to eight completely separate lobes. Its apparent position shifts with age as it continues migrating caudally/distally—higher in the cervical region when very young and lower with advancing age.

query: WFD events are characterized by the presence of white faecal strings which float in the rearing water<sup>3,6</sup>. They usually occur after approximately 50 days of culture<sup>6</sup>, resulting in retarded shrimp growth, unprofitable harvests, and even mass mortality<sup>7</sup>. Loss of microvilli and subsequent lysis in hepatopancreas and midgut associated with WFD indicate a pathological process in shrimp's gut. Enterocytozoon hepatopenaei (EHP), veriform bodies resembling protozoan gregarines, and certain culturable Vibrio species, such as V. parahaemolyticus, V. fluvialis, V. mimicus, V. alginolyticus, and Vibrio sp. were reported as potential causative agents of the disease[3,6,8,9]. Furthermore, deteriorated water quality with oxygen concentrations below  $3.0\mathrm{mgL}^{-1}$  and alkalinity below 80 ppm caused peak mortality rates during WFD outbreaks[10]. However, the aetiology of the WFD in shrimp pond farming remains inconclusive[6,8,11]. For instance, EHP-infected shrimps did not always produce white faeces[11], while Vibrio such as V. alginolyticus was also reported to be probiotic for P. vannamei[12,13].
response: White faeces disease (WFD) in shrimp is marked by floating white faecal strings, typically appearing after ~50 days of culture. It leads to slowed shrimp growth, unprofitable harvests, and can cause mass mortality. Pathology includes microvilli loss and lysis in the hepatopancreas and midgut, indicating a gut disease process. Reported potential causes include Enterocytozoon hepatopenaei (EHP), vermiform bodies resembling gregarines, and several culturable Vibrio species (e.g., V. parahaemolyticus, V. fluvialis, V. mimicus, V. alginolyticus, and other Vibrio spp.). Poor water quality—dissolved oxygen <3.0 mg/L and alkalinity <80 ppm—was associated with peak mortality during outbreaks. However, WFD aetiology remains unresolved because EHP infection does not always produce white faeces and some implicated Vibrios (e.g., V. alginolyticus) have also been reported as probiotics for P. vannamei.

query: Pancreas disease (PD) is a viral disease that affects farmed salmonids in the seawater phase in Ireland, Norway and Scotland. It is caused by Salmonid alphavirus (SAV), a member of the genus Alphavirus, family Togaviridae, a spherical, enveloped, single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus of approximately  $60 - 70\mathrm{nm}$  in diameter with a  $12\mathrm{kb}$  genome (Strauss & Strauss 1994; Weston et al. 1999; Powers et al. 2001). The genome contains two open reading frames with the  $5^{\prime}$  two-thirds of the genome encoding the four nonstructural proteins (nsP1-4), while the four capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3 and 6K) are encoded in the  $3^{\prime}$  end of the genome (Strauss & Strauss 1994; Powers et al. 2001). Six SAV subtypes have been identified based on the nucleic acid sequences encoding proteins E2 and nsP3 (Fringuelli et al. 2008), namely SAV subtypes 1-6. The SAV subtype 2 is divided into two subgroups: the freshwater variant, SAV2 FW, and the marine variant, marine SAV2. SAV2 FW typically causes sleeping disease (SD) in freshwater-reared rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss (Walbaum)) in England, Scotland and a number of countries on the European mainland (Graham et al. 2007a). Marine SAV2 typically causes PD in seawater-reared Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.) and rainbow trout. This paper focuses on PD, therefore only covering SAV infections in the seawater phase. The current distribution of SAV subtypes is shown in Fig. 1. SAV 1, 4, and 6 have been identified in conjunction with Irish PD outbreaks, while SAV 1, 4, 5 and marine SAV2 have been associated with Scottish outbreaks (Fringuelli et al. 2008). SAV 3 has so far only been detected in Norway (Hodneland et al. 2005; Weston et al. 2005; Karlsen et al. 2006, 2014; Jansen et al. 2010a), where outbreaks caused by marine SAV2 are also seen (Hjortaas et al. 2013, 2016).
response: Pancreas disease (PD) is a viral disease affecting farmed salmonids during the seawater phase in Ireland, Norway, and Scotland. It is caused by Salmonid alphavirus (SAV), an enveloped, spherical, single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus (genus *Alphavirus*, family *Togaviridae*) about 60–70 nm in diameter with a ~12 kb genome containing two open reading frames: the 5′ two-thirds encode nonstructural proteins nsP1–4, and the 3′ end encodes the capsid and glycoproteins E1, E2, E3, and 6K. Based on E2 and nsP3 sequences, six SAV subtypes (SAV1–SAV6) are recognized; SAV2 has two variants, freshwater (SAV2 FW) and marine (marine SAV2). SAV2 FW typically causes sleeping disease in freshwater-reared rainbow trout in England, Scotland, and parts of mainland Europe, while marine SAV2 typically causes PD in seawater-reared Atlantic salmon and rainbow trout. The paper focuses only on seawater-phase SAV infections: Irish PD outbreaks involve SAV1, SAV4, and SAV6; Scottish outbreaks involve SAV1, SAV4, SAV5, and marine SAV2; SAV3 has only been detected in Norway, where marine SAV2 outbreaks also occur.

query: Paravertebral anaesthesia involves the injection of a local anaesthetic alongside the dorsal and ventral rami of the spinal nerves at T13, L1 and L2 as they emerge from the intervertebral foramina. The technique produces analgesia of the body wall including the parietal peritoneum. The patient remains standing and fully conscious. The GSA neurons that have touch and pain receptors in the body wall are anaesthetised in the localised area. The anaesthetised ventral rami (T13, L1, L2) contain GSE neurons that innervate the striated muscle in the localised region of the body wall. The parasympathetic system does not have any neurons in the thoracolumbar spinal nerves. The sympathetic system does have preganglionic motor neurons within the ventral roots of the thoracolumbar spinal cord. However, the ratio of pre-­ to postganglionic sympathetic neurons is about 1:20 so that the system is capable of a widespread response or a compensation for the anaesthetised neurons. The result is that, whereas the GSA and GSE neurons are effectively anaesthetised, there are plenty of sympathetic GVA neurons to maintain function.
response: Paravertebral anaesthesia is performed by injecting a local anaesthetic near the dorsal and ventral rami of the T13, L1, and L2 spinal nerves as they exit the intervertebral foramina, producing analgesia of the body wall (including the parietal peritoneum) while the patient remains standing and fully conscious. It anaesthetises GSA sensory neurons (touch and pain) in the targeted body-wall area and affects GSE motor neurons in the ventral rami that innervate local striated muscle. The thoracolumbar spinal nerves contain no parasympathetic neurons; although they include sympathetic preganglionic motor neurons in the ventral roots, the ~1:20 pre- to postganglionic ratio allows sufficient remaining sympathetic (including GVA-related) function to maintain physiological activity despite effective local GSA/GSE blockade.

query: The dorsal mesogastrium attaches to the greater curvature of the stomach and grows caudally as a net-­like cover over the ventral aspect of the intestines; it becomes the greater omentum. The greater omentum actually comprises two layers like a pouch with a parietal or superficial part and a visceral or deep part. The two layers extend cranially to the transverse colon, where they pass either side and form attachments to the pancreas and the spleen. The enclosed cavity is the omental bursa and has only one entry, the epiploic foramen, located caudomedial to the caudate lobe of the liver. The epiploic foramen is dorsal to the caudal vena cava and dorsomedial to the hepatic portal vein. It is slit-­like and measures about 4 cm in the dog.
response: The dorsal mesogastrium attaches to the stomach’s greater curvature and grows caudally as a net-like covering over the ventral intestines, forming the greater omentum. The greater omentum consists of two layers (a superficial/parietal layer and a deep/visceral layer) forming a pouch; these layers extend cranially to the transverse colon, then pass on either side to attach to the pancreas and spleen. The space within is the omental bursa, which has a single entrance: the epiploic foramen, located caudomedial to the liver’s caudate lobe, dorsal to the caudal vena cava, and dorsomedial to the hepatic portal vein; it is slit-like and about 4 cm long in the dog.

query: Certain liver diseases that affect the urea cycle, particularly acquired or inherited defects in any one of the five urea cycle enzymes, may have severe consequences for the mammalian organism since there are no alternative pathways for urea biosynthesis. For example, arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency, although rare, has been reported in dogs. Patients exhibit protein intolerance, hyperammonemia, and a hepatoencephalopathy that leads to CNS depression, coma and death if left untreated. Treatment generally requires measures to control the hepatoencephalopathy, including a low-protein diet and oral antibiotics. Vascular abnormalities that shunt portal blood into the systemic circulation without perfusing hepatic sinusoids (i.e., portalcaval shunts) compromise the liver's ability to detoxify \(NH_{3}\) through the urea cycle, and many other liver diseases are known as well to result in decreased urea cycle enzyme activity with hyperammonemia.
response: Defects in any of the five urea cycle enzymes—whether inherited or acquired—can have severe consequences in mammals because there are no alternative pathways for urea production. An example is the rare argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency reported in dogs, which causes protein intolerance, hyperammonemia, and hepatoencephalopathy leading to CNS depression, coma, and death if untreated. Treatment generally focuses on controlling hepatoencephalopathy, including a low-protein diet and oral antibiotics. In addition, portalcaval shunts (portal blood bypassing hepatic sinusoids into systemic circulation) and various other liver diseases can reduce urea cycle detoxification of ammonia by decreasing urea cycle enzyme activity, resulting in hyperammonemia.

query: The actual mechanism by which the descent of the testes occurs has been the subject of debate for many years and the object of much research. It is clear that there is considerable variation between species not least because of anatomical and physiological differences. Endocrine factors certainly appear to have a significant role. The requirement for the descent of the mammalian testes to an extra-­abdominal location is due to the need to lower the temperature by 2–3°C of the body temperature for spermatogenesis (see Section 5). However, the testes of the elephant and the hyrax are intra-­abdominal. Inguinal passage occurs at about 120 days of pregnancy in the ox, 80 days in the sheep and 90 days in the pig. In the horse, however, the testis is drawn to the inguinal ring, but at 100–120 days the foetal gonad starts to enlarge rapidly and is unable to pass through the inguinal canal. The gonads reach maximum size at about 210–240 days of pregnancy. The testes then undergo shrinkage until inguinal passage is possible at about 300 days, although some distortion of the testes is still necessary. By the time the foal is born the testes are normally through the inguinal canal.
response: The mechanism of testicular descent is debated, varies between species due to anatomical and physiological differences, and likely involves important endocrine factors. Descent to an extra-abdominal location in most mammals is needed to keep testes about 2–3°C cooler than body temperature for spermatogenesis, though some species (elephant and hyrax) retain intra-abdominal testes. Timing of inguinal passage differs by species: about 120 days of gestation in cattle, 80 days in sheep, and 90 days in pigs. In horses, the testes are drawn to the inguinal ring, but rapid fetal gonad enlargement at 100–120 days prevents passage; they reach maximum size at 210–240 days, then shrink until passage becomes possible around 300 days (often requiring some distortion), and by birth the testes are usually through the inguinal canal.

query: Critical issues that maintain PRRSV circulation within the herd include: ￭The co-existence of genetically diverse isolates mainly as a consequence of the entry of new viruses, due to a lack of biosecurity measures or the introduction of contaminated animals or semen. ￭The existence of naïve, fully susceptible subpopulations.￭Improper management of gilt replacement pools.       Proper development of replacement gilts is a pivotal component of PRRS control and involves exposing incoming naïve animals to the farm-specific resident PRRSV isolate before entering a positive breeding herd in order to reduce seronegative subpopulations.
response: Key factors that maintain PRRSV circulation within a herd include the co-existence of genetically diverse isolates due to new virus introductions (from inadequate biosecurity or introduction of contaminated animals or semen), the presence of naïve fully susceptible subpopulations, and improper management of gilt replacement pools. Effective PRRS control relies on proper development of replacement gilts by exposing incoming naïve gilts to the farm’s resident PRRSV isolate before they enter a PRRSV-positive breeding herd to reduce seronegative subpopulations.

query: The characterization of nephron segments varies among fishes because some species lack some segments, and also the cellular structure can be different within the same portion for different species, especially because the major function of this organ is directly correlated with fish habitat under adaptation to the water of different salinities. Some fish lack renal corpuscles (RCs) altogether and their kidneys are termed aglomerular. This type is predominantly found in marine species and euryhaline fishes in seawater, such as toadfish (family Batracoididae), anglerfish (order Lophiiformes), sea horses (genus Hippocampus), and needlefish (family Belonidae). Teleosts, such as eels, salmonids, and ostariophysids (e.g., carps and catfishes) possess a long multisegmental nephron, whereas, in marine teleosts of different orders, such as percids (family Percidae), killifish (order Cyprinodontiformes), flounder (order Pleuronectiformes), and sticklebacks (family Gasterosteidae), the nephron is shorter because the distal segment is absent.
response: Nephron segment composition differs among fish species because some lack certain segments and cellular structures vary, largely reflecting kidney function adaptations to habitats with different salinities. Some fish completely lack renal corpuscles, forming aglomerular kidneys found mainly in marine species and euryhaline fishes in seawater (e.g., toadfish, anglerfish, seahorses, needlefish). In contrast, teleosts such as eels, salmonids, and ostariophysids (including carps and catfishes) have long, multisegmental nephrons, while many marine teleosts (e.g., percids, killifish, flounders, sticklebacks) have shorter nephrons because they lack the distal segment.

query: Injury to the paw or digits is a frequent cause of a non‐weight‐bearing lameness. As many dogs are sensitive to paw palpation and tend to withdraw the limb during palpation, paw and digit palpation should be performed with other joints (carpal and elbow) in relatively flexed positions. Examination of the paw generally consists of assessing each digit, including the nail and nail bed. Common sources of lame­ ness arising from these sites include: Split nails, Nail‐bed tumors, Fracture/luxation of the phalanges, Infection, Penetrating foreign bodies, Pad lacerations. Nails are inspected for signs of wear, which may indicate digit dragging due to neurologic disorders (Figure 1). Careful palpation of the digits and manipulation of the joints in flexion and extension, while observing for evidence of pain or swelling, is a sensitive method to deter­ mine whether any part of the paw is a source of pain.
response: Injury to the paw or digits commonly causes non-weight-bearing lameness. Because many dogs withdraw the limb during paw palpation, the paw and digits should be palpated while keeping other joints (carpal and elbow) relatively flexed. Paw examination involves assessing each digit, including the nail and nail bed. Common causes of lameness from these areas include split nails, nail-bed tumors, phalangeal fracture or luxation, infection, penetrating foreign bodies, and pad lacerations. Nails should be checked for abnormal wear that may indicate digit dragging from neurologic disease. Careful digit palpation and flexion–extension joint manipulation while watching for pain or swelling is a sensitive way to identify paw-related pain.

query: The majority of MCTs originate in the dermis and extend into the subcutis, but there is a subset that is restricted to the subcutaneous fat and are classified as a subtype in their own right – subcutaneous MCTs. This is determined on the basis of location within the subcutaneous tissue and no invasion of the dermis, although multifocal extension of low numbers of mast cells around the base of hair follicles or mast cells infiltrating the underlying panniculus musculature is allowed, as long as the bulk of the tumour is within the subcutaneous tissue. There is no supporting evidence for the usefulness of grading these tumours with any of the cutaneous grading systems, but a few studies have looked at the prognostication of subcutaneous MCTs as a separate entity. Tumours should be assessed based on the growth pattern, presence of multinucleation (defined as more than 1 nuclei per cell, present if there was at least 1 multinucleated cell in 10 HPFs [400×]), and the mitotic count. The strongest effect on clinical outcome appears to be mitotic activity. Subcutaneous tumours are more effectively controlled by surgery alone than their cutaneous counterparts. Surgery is curative for the majority of these tumours.
response: Subcutaneous mast cell tumours (MCTs) are a distinct subset of MCTs confined mainly to subcutaneous fat without dermal invasion; limited mast cell extension around hair follicle bases or into underlying panniculus musculature is acceptable as long as most of the tumour remains subcutaneous. There is no evidence that cutaneous MCT grading systems are useful for these tumours, so some studies evaluate them separately for prognosis. Assessment should focus on growth pattern, multinucleation (>1 nucleus per cell; considered present if at least one multinucleated cell is seen in 10 high-power fields at 400×), and mitotic count, with mitotic activity having the strongest impact on clinical outcome. Compared with cutaneous MCTs, subcutaneous tumours are better controlled with surgery alone, which is curative in most cases.

query: Mobilization of glucose from glycogen stores requires two reactions: shortening of the nonreducing ends of α -1,4 glycosidic chains by a regulatory phosphorylase, and disassembly of the \(\alpha-1,6\) branch points by a non-regulatory debranching enzyme. The first reaction adds inorganic phosphate (Pi) rather than \(H_{2} O\) across the glycosidic bond, resulting in the release of Glc-1-P which can then be converted to Glc-6-P by PGM. The second reaction removes a free glucose residue from glycogen which can be quickly phosphorylated to Glc-6-P and used in the Embden-Meyerhoff pathway (EMP), or released by liver tissue into blood (Fig. 23-4). Additionally, Glc-6-P may also be dephosphorylated by hepatic Glu-6-Pase, and released as free glucose into blood. Approximately 90% of glycogen degradation results in Glc-1-P formation through reaction one above, and 10% in free glucose formation through reaction two.
response: Glycogen breakdown mobilizes glucose via two reactions: (1) a regulatory phosphorylase shortens nonreducing ends of α-1,4 glycosidic chains by adding inorganic phosphate (Pi) instead of water, releasing glucose-1-phosphate (Glc-1-P), which is converted to glucose-6-phosphate (Glc-6-P) by phosphoglucomutase (PGM); and (2) a non-regulatory debranching enzyme disassembles α-1,6 branch points, releasing free glucose that is rapidly phosphorylated to Glc-6-P for use in the Embden–Meyerhof pathway (EMP) or, in liver, released into the blood. In liver, Glc-6-P can also be dephosphorylated by glucose-6-phosphatase (Glu-6-Pase) to free glucose for blood release. About 90% of glycogen degradation yields Glc-1-P (reaction 1) and about 10% yields free glucose (reaction 2).

query: Hydrophthalmos refers to an unusually enlarged globe, associated with chronically increased IOP secondary to glaucoma. This is synonymous with the term buphthalmos, but as this term indicates that the globe is cow-­sized, which is actually smaller than a horse globe, hydrophthalmos is the preferred term in equids. Hydrophthalmos suggests an enlarged globe, whatever the original size. In adult horses, with glaucoma, globe size increases slowly and is associated with other clinical signs of glaucoma such as corneal edema and endothelial (Haab’s) striae (Figure 14). Vision may be present, reduced, or absent at the time of diagnosis. Vision may return if the increased IOP is controlled, even if mild globe enlargement remains. Congenital glaucoma may also occur.
