Hydrophthalmos is more rapid in these cases due to the greater elasticity of young globes; however, vision is lost more rapidly and permanently. Hydrophthalmos must be differentiated from exophthalmos (displacement of a normal-­sized globe), and in unilateral disease comparative ultrasound measurements can confirm this.
response: Hydrophthalmos is an abnormally enlarged eye globe caused by chronically increased intraocular pressure (IOP) due to glaucoma. It is synonymous with buphthalmos, but “hydrophthalmos” is preferred in equids because it indicates enlargement regardless of original globe size. In adult horses with glaucoma, globe enlargement occurs slowly and is accompanied by other glaucoma signs such as corneal edema and endothelial (Haab’s) striae; vision at diagnosis may be normal, reduced, or absent, and may return if IOP is controlled even if mild enlargement persists. Congenital glaucoma can also cause hydrophthalmos, which progresses faster in young horses due to greater globe elasticity, but vision is lost more rapidly and permanently. Hydrophthalmos must be distinguished from exophthalmos (forward displacement of a normal-sized globe), and in unilateral cases comparative ultrasound measurements can help confirm the difference.

query: Cutaneous xanthomas are rare granulomatous skin lesions that occur in both dogs and cats because of an abnormality in lipid metabolism. High-­fat diets and diabetes mellitus can be associated with these skin lesions in both species and hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia has been seen in cats with xanthomas. Patients may present with white or yellow papules, nodules, or plaques with surrounding erythema. The lesions may ulcerate with time and can be pruritic or painful. Typical locations involved include the head, distal limbs, feet, and bony prominences. Differential diagnoses for cutaneous xanthomas include sterile nodular panniculitis, sterile granuloma/pyogranuloma syndrome, and neoplasia. Diagnosis is made by histopathology, which reveals foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lipid lakes throughout the dermis. If the patient is a cat, remember to check lipid levels on a serum chemistry panel. Tissue samples from nodular lesions should also be submitted for bacterial and fungal cultures and secondary infections should be addressed. Deep skin scrapings and fungal culture should also be performed if the patient is pruritic or has spreading lesions. Treatment involves feeding a prescription low-­fat diet as well as managing any underlying disease such as diabetes. Clients should be informed that removing the lesions surgically without correcting the underlying cause will result in recurrence; however, it may be prudent to remove lesions that are on pressure point areas to relieve any discomfort.
response: Cutaneous xanthomas are rare granulomatous skin lesions in dogs and cats caused by abnormal lipid metabolism, sometimes associated with high-fat diets and diabetes mellitus; cats may have hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia. They present as white or yellow papules, nodules, or plaques with surrounding erythema, may ulcerate over time, and can be pruritic or painful, commonly affecting the head, distal limbs, feet, and bony prominences. Differentials include sterile nodular panniculitis, sterile granuloma/pyogranuloma syndrome, and neoplasia. Diagnosis is via histopathology showing foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and lipid lakes in the dermis; in cats, serum lipid levels should be checked. Nodular tissue should be cultured for bacteria and fungi, secondary infections treated, and if lesions are pruritic or spreading, deep skin scrapings and fungal culture should be performed. Treatment focuses on a prescription low-fat diet and managing underlying disease (e.g., diabetes); surgical removal without correcting the cause leads to recurrence, though removal may be considered for lesions on pressure points to reduce discomfort.

query: The superficial cervical lymph nodes receive afferent lymph vessels from: the skin of the caudal part of the dorsal head region, the pinna, the parotid and neck areas, the caudal half of the cranial neck region, the forelimb digits, the metacarpus, carpus and forearm, most of the lateral side of the upper shoulder, upper foreleg region, and the medial side of the humerus region, the anterior thorax, and the cranial part of the ventral thorax. The lymph nodes also often drain the skin of the masseter region, the antebrachial fascia, most of the shoulder muscles (M. deltoideus, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis) as well as the Mm. interossei of the forepaw, the extensors and flexors of the \(1^{st }\) and \(5^{th }\) digits, and the tendons of the M . extensor carpi radialis, extensor digitorum communis and lateralis, extensor carpi ulnaris, abductor pollicis longus, as well as the M . flexor digitalis sublimis. and profundus, most of the trunk limb muscles (M. trapezius, omotransversarius, brachiocephalic, sternomastoid, rhomboid, serratus ventralis and the Mm. pectorales), the M .splenius, sternohyoideus and sternothyroideus and the neck skin muscle, all bones of the forelimb, the carpal joint, the forepaw digit joints and the pinna.
response: The superficial cervical lymph nodes receive afferent lymph mainly from the skin of the caudal dorsal head (including pinna, parotid and neck areas), the caudal half of the cranial neck, the forelimb (digits, forepaw, metacarpus, carpus, forearm), much of the shoulder/upper forelimb (lateral upper shoulder and upper foreleg, medial humerus), and the cranial/anterior ventral thorax. They also often drain the skin of the masseter region; antebrachial fascia; many shoulder muscles (deltoideus, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis); forepaw interossei; digit flexors/extensors (especially 1st and 5th); tendons of major carpal/digital extensors and flexors (including extensor carpi radialis, extensor digitorum communis/lateralis, extensor carpi ulnaris, abductor pollicis longus, flexor digitalis superficialis and profundus); major trunk–limb and neck muscles (trapezius, omotransversarius, brachiocephalic, sternomastoid, rhomboid, serratus ventralis, pectorals, splenius, sternohyoideus, sternothyroideus, and neck skin muscle); all forelimb bones; the carpal joint; forepaw digit joints; and the pinna.

query: Copper accumulates in the liver of dogs with chronic hepatopathies and can be seen as a primary cause (primary copper associated hepatopathy) evident in a growing number of breeds. However, it is also seen accumulating secondary to other causes of hepatopathy. Therefore, the finding of copper in and of itself is not diagnostic for a primary copper associated hepatopathy. There is a difference in the quantity and distribution of copper accumulation seen in primary copper associated hepatopathy as opposed to secondary, but in my experience, it can be sometimes difficult to confidently distinguish between the two, particularly if other changes to the hepatic parenchyma are also severe and distort the lobular architecture and/or in Tru­cut biopsies with few intact lobules. It is very important to assess for the presence of copper, as chelating agents are a potential therapeutic option, regardless of whether the accumulation is primary or secondary. Special staining for copper (typically with stains such as rhodanine, or rubeanic acid) is typically performed on canine liver biopsies for this reason. These special stains detect the presence of copper, the distribution (periportal versus centrilobular), and can allow for a subjective assessment of the severity of any such accumulation. Assessment also entails identifying which cells are accumulating the copper (macrophages and/or hepatocytes) and whether its presence is associated with necrotic hepatocytes, and formation of small ‘copper granulomas’.
response: Copper can accumulate in the livers of dogs with chronic hepatopathies either as a primary disease (primary copper-associated hepatopathy, increasingly recognized in more breeds) or secondary to other liver disorders, so copper presence alone is not diagnostic. Primary vs secondary cases can differ in the amount and lobular distribution of copper, but distinguishing them may be difficult, especially with severe parenchymal distortion or limited Trucut biopsy samples. Copper should still be assessed because chelation therapy may be useful regardless of cause. Accordingly, canine liver biopsies commonly receive special copper stains (e.g., rhodanine or rubeanic acid) to detect copper, characterize its distribution (periportal vs centrilobular), and subjectively gauge severity, including which cells contain copper (macrophages and/or hepatocytes) and whether it is associated with hepatocyte necrosis and small “copper granulomas.”

query: Cyprinid fishes (such as goldfish and carp) have one of the simplest types of gastrointestinal tract among vertebrates. Those fish species do not possess a true stomach, and even in the intestine, there is no differentiation of the intestinal glands or crypts of Lieberkuhn. The absence of the true stomach in grass carp is replaced by a simple dilatation at the anterior part of the intestine called the intestinal bulb. The mean diameter of the bulb is 65 ± 41.54 µm, and the mean thickness of the wall is 1598.03 ± 31.58 µm. The wall of the intestinal bulb is composed of tunica mucosa, tunica submucosa, tunica muscularis, and tunica SE. The mean thickness of the tunica mucosa is 1109.80 ± 13.85 µm. The mucosa shows numerous (about 52), deep longitudinal folds. A large distinct concavity is noted to be present between the MFs. The folds of the intestinal bulb are higher and more complex than that of the intestine. The mean height of the folds is 1066.98 ± 42.40 µm, and their mean width is 181.38 ± 5.58 µm. The mean diameter of the lumen is 1952.59 ± 42.86 µm .
response: Cyprinid fishes such as goldfish and carp have a very simple gastrointestinal tract: they lack a true stomach, and their intestine has no differentiated intestinal glands or crypts of Lieberkuhn. In grass carp, the missing stomach is functionally replaced by an anterior intestinal dilatation called the intestinal bulb. The bulb has a mean diameter of 65 ± 41.54 µm and a mean wall thickness of 1598.03 ± 31.58 µm, with a wall composed of tunica mucosa, submucosa, muscularis, and serosa (SE). The tunica mucosa averages 1109.80 ± 13.85 µm thick and forms about 52 deep longitudinal folds with a large distinct concavity between them; these folds are higher and more complex than intestinal folds, with mean height 1066.98 ± 42.40 µm and mean width 181.38 ± 5.58 µm. The lumen has a mean diameter of 1952.59 ± 42.86 µm.

query: The canal of the AO of guppy contains mucous cells that stained slight violet with PAS-AB stain, also the apical border of support cells was AB-posi­ tive (Figure 19B). The presence of the neutral mucosubstances that fill the ampulla along with the acid mucosubstances secreted by abundant mucous cells of the epidermis suggests that it may modulate the intensity of signals from receptor cells and/or give some protection and these materials have excellent electric conductivity. The ampullary pores (APs) are distributed throughout the head and lined with a single layer of squamous cells (Figure 7.19C). The transverse-section through the AO shows that it composes of a sac of fusiform receptor cells that lie below the AP (Figure 7.19D). The superficial and deep (canal) neuromasts of guppy differ from those present in red-tail shark. The canals neuromast is widely distributed in the head and operculum and open at intervals to the exterior and surrounded by dermal bone (DB). The CN is lined by two layers of sensory cells with apical microvilli and the opposite side of the canal is lined with a simple squamous epithelium containing AB-positive mucous cells as these canals are filled with fluid (water and mucous secretion), which allow transmission of vibrations to the neuromasts through the skin pores. A bundle of nerve fibers lied below the canal and passed between the DBs (Figure 7.20A). The CN of guppies is surrounded by an osseous coat, while that of red-tail shark is supported by a fibrous coat and this may be an adaptive means against squeezing the contents of the canal by high water pressures in the bottom.
response:
In guppies, the ampullary organ (AO) canal contains mucous cells that stain slightly violet with PAS-AB, and the apical border of support cells is AB-positive. Neutral mucosubstances filling the ampulla, together with acidic mucosubstances secreted by abundant epidermal mucous cells, may modulate receptor-cell signal intensity and/or provide protection, and these materials have high electrical conductivity. Ampullary pores are distributed over the head and are lined by a single squamous cell layer; the AO itself is a sac of fusiform receptor cells located beneath the pores.

Guppy superficial and canal (deep) neuromasts differ from those in red-tail shark. In guppies, canal neuromasts are widely distributed in the head and operculum, open to the exterior at intervals, and are surrounded by dermal bone. The canal neuromast has two layers of sensory cells with apical microvilli, while the opposite canal wall is simple squamous epithelium containing AB-positive mucous cells; the canals are filled with fluid (water and mucus) that transmits vibrations to neuromasts via skin pores. Nerve fibers lie below the canal and pass between dermal bones. Guppy canal neuromasts are enclosed by an osseous coat, whereas in red-tail shark they are supported by a fibrous coat, possibly adapting guppies to prevent canal contents from being squeezed by high bottom-water pressure.

query: Malassezia dermatitis can be treated with topical or systemic antifungals alone or in combination. Combination therapy may lead to faster resolution of disease. Topical therapy alone or pulse dosing of oral therapy can be used as prevention once infection and underlying disease are better controlled. Topical therapy is available as a shampoo, spray, wipe, mousse, or gel and should contain 2% chlorhexidine with 2% miconazole or ketoconazole, 3–4% chlorhexidine when it is the sole active ingredient, 1–2% miconazole, or 2% climbazole. A frequency of two to three times per week for three to four weeks is recommended for active infection; this can be reduced to one to two times per week for maintenance and prevention. The author prefers shampoo for generalized infections and wipes for facial fold, claw fold, and interdigital treatment. Ketoconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) and itraconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) are the most effective oral therapeutic options for dogs. Overall itraconazole is better tolerated, although some canine patients will have gastrointestinal upset (vomiting, inappetence, and diarrhea) with both oral medications. Fluconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) is another option and may have fewer adverse effects and drug interactions, but may not be as reliable for Malassezia treatment. Terbinafine (30 mg/kg/day) does not achieve high stratum corneum or sebum concentrations and is not as effective for surface infections (Gimmler et al. 2015). The duration of oral therapy varies, but most cases are given daily therapy for 20–30 days, then if pulse therapy is needed, the dose is continued one to three times a week. The compounded versions of any of the azole medications should be avoided due to poor bioavailability of these formulations.
response: Malassezia dermatitis can be treated with topical and/or systemic antifungals; combination therapy may resolve disease faster. After infection and underlying disease are controlled, topical therapy alone or pulse-dosed oral therapy can be used for prevention. Topical options (shampoo, spray, wipe, mousse, gel) should contain: 2% chlorhexidine + 2% miconazole or ketoconazole; 3–4% chlorhexidine alone; 1–2% miconazole; or 2% climbazole. For active infection, treat 2–3 times weekly for 3–4 weeks, then reduce to 1–2 times weekly for maintenance/prevention; shampoo is preferred for generalized disease and wipes for facial folds, claw folds, and interdigital areas. In dogs, the most effective oral options are ketoconazole or itraconazole (both 5–10 mg/kg/day), with itraconazole generally better tolerated though both can cause GI upset; fluconazole (5–10 mg/kg/day) may have fewer adverse effects/interactions but may be less reliable, and terbinafine (30 mg/kg/day) is less effective for surface infections due to low stratum corneum/sebum levels. Oral treatment is typically daily for 20–30 days, then may continue as pulse therapy 1–3 times per week if needed. Compounded azole formulations should be avoided because of poor bioavailability.

query: Idiopathic Megaesophagus Idiopathic megaesophagus is the most common cause of regurgitation in the dog.10 Aside from dysautonomia, megaesophagus is a rare finding in the domestic cat. The disorder is characterized by esophageal hypomotility and dilation, progressive regurgitation, and loss of body condition. Several forms of the syndrome have been described, including congenital, acquired secondary, and acquired idiopathic megaesophagus. Dysautonomia Dysautonomia is a generalized autonomic neuropathy that was originally reported in cats in the United Kingdom, but that has now been documented in dogs and cats throughout Western Europe and the United States.11,12 Clinical signs reflect a generalized autonomic dysfunction but megaesophagus, esophageal hypomotility, and regurgitation are fairly consistent findings. Pathologically, degenerative lesions are found in autonomic ganglia, intermediate gray columns of the spinal cord, and some sympathetic axons. No definitive etiology has ever been established despite an intensive search for genetic, toxic, nutritional, and infectious etiologic agents. Gastroesophageal Intussusception Gastroesophageal intussusception is a rare condition of young dogs (most younger than 3 months of age) resulting from invagination of stomach into the esophagus, with or without other abdominal organs (e.g., spleen, duodenum, pancreas, omentum).17 Many affected animals have preexisting esophageal disease, most importantly idiopathic megaesophagus. The role of idiopathic megaesophagus in the pathogenesis of gastroesophageal intussusception is not well understood, but it may be that the greatly enlarged capacity of a dilated esophagus accommodates invagination of the stomach through the diaphragmatic hiatus. Gastroesophageal intussusception is a true gastrointestinal emergency that may culminate in death if untreated.
response: Idiopathic megaesophagus is the most common cause of regurgitation in dogs but is rare in cats except with dysautonomia; it involves esophageal hypomotility and dilation leading to progressive regurgitation and loss of body condition, and occurs as congenital, acquired secondary, or acquired idiopathic forms. Dysautonomia is a generalized autonomic neuropathy first reported in UK cats and now seen in dogs and cats in Western Europe and the U.S.; it causes widespread autonomic dysfunction with consistent megaesophagus, esophageal hypomotility, and regurgitation, and shows degenerative lesions in autonomic ganglia, intermediate gray columns of the spinal cord, and some sympathetic axons, with no confirmed etiology despite investigation of genetic, toxic, nutritional, and infectious causes. Gastroesophageal intussusception is a rare emergency in young dogs (usually <3 months) where the stomach invaginates into the esophagus, sometimes with other organs; many cases have preexisting esophageal disease (especially idiopathic megaesophagus), which may permit stomach invagination due to an enlarged, dilated esophagus, and it can be fatal if untreated.

query: A Wood’s lamp examination is one of the simplest screening tools for dermatophytosis, but is only useful for some strains of \(M.\) canis, since only \(M.\) canis produces the classic emerald or apple-­green fluorescence of the hair shaft (Figure 9). In the hands of a skilled user, a Wood’s lamp will detect positive \(M.\) canis infection approximately 70–100% of the time (Moriello et al. 2017). Unfortunately, lint, skin surface crust and debris, and topical medications can cause similar fluorescence, which can lead to false positive results. Glowing hairs should be plucked and examined under the microscope for confirmation of the diagnosis. Hairs treated with appropriate topical therapy will not cease to fluoresce; but only the infected portion will glow, so a simple trick for monitoring response to treatment is to watch for loss of fluorescence as hairs grow out. Direct microscopic evaluation of infected hairs is another reliable diagnostic tool in the hands of a skilled examiner. Hairs from the edge of a lesion are plucked and placed on a slide with mineral oil and a coverslip. They are evaluated for the presence of hyphae and arthrospores on 100× power. Lowering and closing the condenser can increase contrast, which allows spores and hyphae to stand out. Infected hairs tend to be larger in diameter with a fuzzy or irregular outline, and they lack a clear demarcation between the cortex and the medulla. Most dermatophyte infections in animals produce an ectothrix distribution of arthrospores: coccoid elements surrounding the outside of the hair shaft. Hyphae will be seen growing within the hair shaft (Figure 6.10). Use of a Wood’s lamp to highlight actively glowing hairs on the microscope slide can assist in identification of M. canis.
response:
A Wood’s lamp is a simple screening test for dermatophytosis but is mainly useful for some strains of *Microsporum canis*, which can produce an emerald/apple‑green fluorescence of the hair shaft. In skilled hands it detects *M. canis* infection about 70–100% of the time, but lint, crust/debris, and topical medications can fluoresce similarly and cause false positives. Fluorescing hairs should be plucked and microscopically examined to confirm diagnosis. With topical therapy, hairs do not stop fluorescing; only the infected portion glows, so treatment response can be monitored by watching fluorescence move outward and disappear as new hair grows.

Direct microscopic examination is another reliable method: pluck hairs from the lesion edge, mount with mineral oil and a coverslip, and examine at 100× for hyphae and arthrospores. Contrast can be improved by lowering/closing the condenser. Infected hairs are often thicker with a fuzzy/irregular outline and poor cortex–medulla demarcation. Most animal dermatophyte infections show ectothrix arthrospores (coccoid spores coating the outside of the hair shaft) with hyphae growing within the shaft; using a Wood’s lamp to highlight glowing hairs on the slide can aid *M. canis* identification.

query: Treatment of intestinal obstruction caused by a foreign body, an intussusception or a volvulus: Abdominal surgery is another option. This is outside the author’s experience, but it is feasible, certainly in smaller pigs. If a stone can be felt in the small intestine it can be removed or milked into the large intestine. At least with a laparotomy, the extent of any disease process can be assessed so that euthanasia can be carried out promptly if necessary.
response: Abdominal surgery (laparotomy) is a feasible option for treating intestinal obstruction due to a foreign body, intussusception, or volvulus, especially in smaller pigs, though it is outside the author’s experience. If a stone is palpable in the small intestine, it can be removed or milked into the large intestine. Laparotomy also allows assessment of the extent of disease so that euthanasia can be performed promptly if needed.

query: Nursery pigs and growers very often show sneezing and catarrhal nasal discharge as the first clinical sign after an infection with M. hyorhinis. They might exhibit fewer, reduced feed intake and depression for up to 10–14 days, before they recover in case of no further complications. In case of a concurrent infection with a primary respiratory pathogen, M. hyorhinis is also found in the lower airways and might contribute to the pathogenesis of pneumonia, and thereby to the severity of coughing and dyspnoea. When the infection becomes systemic, M. hyorhinis can cause pleuritis, which further enhances the respiratory symptoms attributed to pneumonia provoked by a primary respiratory pathogen. Apart from this, pigs often demonstrate a pathological posture with their back curved upwards due to peritonitis and they suffer from pericarditis and lameness because of (poly-) arthritis (Fig. 2). In case of polyserositis and polyarthritis, symptoms often last for more than 6 weeks. Suckling pigs and adult pigs seldom suffer from an infection with M. hyorhinis. However, in rare cases, they might exhibit similar symptoms to those observed in nursery and growing pigs.
response: After infection with *Mycoplasma hyorhinis*, nursery and growing pigs commonly first show sneezing and catarrhal nasal discharge, along with reduced feed intake and depression lasting about 10–14 days if there are no complications. With concurrent primary respiratory infections, *M. hyorhinis* may be present in the lower airways, contributing to pneumonia and worsening coughing and dyspnoea; systemic spread can cause pleuritis that further aggravates respiratory signs. Systemic disease may also lead to peritonitis (causing a curved-back posture), pericarditis, and lameness due to (poly)arthritis; in cases of polyserositis and polyarthritis, signs often persist for more than six weeks. Suckling and adult pigs are rarely affected, but can occasionally show similar signs to nursery and growing pigs.

query: Macrolide antibiotics and similar molecules are active against gram-­positive (S. aureus, Streptococcus spp.) and atypical pathogens (Chlamydia spp., Mycoplasma spp.), but have a limited spectrum against gram-­negative organisms. Macrolides are ineffective against enteric gram-­ negative bacilli such as Escherichia coli and are ineffective against P. aeruginosa. They are active against fastidious gram-­negative organisms (Campylobacter spp., Borrelia spp., Bordetella spp., Brucella spp., Pasteurella spp., Haemophilus spp., H. pylori) and spirochetes (Treponema pallidum). Some differences exist in the overlapping spectrums of each macrolide antibiotic. Macrolides and their relatives are bacteriostatic agents that block bacterial protein synthesis. Macrolides may also inhibit production of bacterial virulence factors (Kanoh and Rubin 2010), may have anti-­inflammatory properties (Rubin and Tamaoki 2000; Culić et al. 2001), immunomodulatory activity (Piacentini et al. 2007), and effects on cell signaling (Clapham 2007). Resistance to macrolides and related compounds occurs in three ways (Nakajima 1999; Leclercq and Courvalin 2002). The first is target site modification by methylation or other mutation that prevents binding of the drug to the ribosomal target. For example, the A2059G mutation confers high-­level resistance to macrolides such as erythromycin and azithromycin, moderate resistance to clarithromycin and clindamycin, but no resistance to streptogramins (Tait-­Kamradt et al. 2000; Canu et al. 2002). The second is efflux mediated by physiologic pumps that actively pump the drug out of the bacterial cell and are encoded by the mef (A) gene with efflux driven by proton motive force (Clancy et al. 1996). The third is drug inactivation by degradation from hydrolysis of the macrolide lactone ring or drug modification related to macrolide phosphorylation. Macrolide inactivation is rare and less common than other mechanisms of macrolide resistance.
response: Macrolide antibiotics (and related molecules) are mainly active against gram-positive bacteria (e.g., *S. aureus*, *Streptococcus* spp.) and atypical pathogens (*Chlamydia*, *Mycoplasma*), but have limited activity against gram-negative organisms; they are ineffective against enteric gram-negative bacilli such as *E. coli* and against *P. aeruginosa*. They do have activity against certain fastidious gram-negative organisms (e.g., *Campylobacter, Borrelia, Bordetella, Brucella, Pasteurella, Haemophilus, H. pylori*) and against spirochetes (e.g., *Treponema pallidum*), with some spectrum differences among individual macrolides. Macrolides are bacteriostatic agents that inhibit bacterial protein synthesis and may also reduce virulence factor production, have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects, and influence cell signaling. Resistance occurs via three main mechanisms: (1) ribosomal target-site modification (methylation/mutation) preventing drug binding (e.g., A2059G causing high resistance to erythromycin/azithromycin, moderate resistance to clarithromycin/clindamycin, and no resistance to streptogramins); (2) drug efflux via pumps encoded by **mef(A)** driven by proton motive force; and (3) drug inactivation (lactone ring hydrolysis or phosphorylation), which is rare compared with other mechanisms.

query: So far, resistance of helminths to anthelmintics has not been found to be a problem in pigs. Treatment should be carried out in adults on a 6-monthly basis, with outdoor pigs being moved to clean pasture and indoor pigs having their accommodation steam cleaned. Growing pigs should be treated at 8 weeks of age and then every 2 months until maturity. It is important to remember to reduce the risk of resistance by treating animals up to weight. Only licensed medicines for pigs should be used. Control of helminths in pigs can be easily accomplished in commercial herds by in-feed ivermectin or fenbendazole given at 6-monthly intervals. Individual treatments can be given by i.m. injection of doramectin at 3 mg/10 kg or by s.c. injection of ivermectin at 300 μg/kg. Small group treatment may be carried out by in-water medication of flubendazole at 1 mg/kg for 5 days or fenbendazole oral pellets at 5 mg/kg as a single dose. As with all medication, meat withdrawal periods must be followed.
response: Helminth resistance to anthelmintics has not yet been a problem in pigs. Adult pigs should be treated every 6 months, with outdoor pigs moved to clean pasture and indoor accommodation steam cleaned. Growing pigs should be treated at 8 weeks of age and then every 2 months until maturity. To reduce resistance risk, dose animals accurately to their weight and use only licensed pig medicines. In commercial herds, control can be achieved with in-feed ivermectin or fenbendazole every 6 months. Individual treatments include i.m. doramectin (3 mg/10 kg) or s.c. ivermectin (300 μg/kg). Small groups can be treated via in-water flubendazole (1 mg/kg for 5 days) or fenbendazole oral pellets (5 mg/kg single dose). Meat withdrawal periods must be observed.

query: H. parasuis strains are heterogeneous and exhibit a wide variability in the degree of virulence, from non-virulent to highly virulent strains. Non-virulent strains are commonly found in the upper respiratory tract as part of the normal microbiota of the animals, where do not cause any pathology. These strains are susceptible to the killing action of porcine alveolar macrophages (PAM) and, under normal conditions, are effectively cleared from the lungs (Fig. 4). If these strains reach the lung, they are detected by PAM, which are then activated for an effective phagocytosis and killing. Non-virulent strains are also sensitive to serum, and cannot survive in blood for systemic dissemination. These characteristics explain why non-virulent strains are not able to cause disease in healthy animals and are controlled by the innate immune system. On the opposite side, virulent strains can evade the immune system and cause disease. After the initial colonization of the upper respiratory tract, virulent strains can reach the lung, where they survive due to their ability to resist phagocytosis. After nasal inoculation, virulent strains can be found colonizing not only the nasal mucosa, but also the tracheal mucosa, where they can form biofilm-like structures. When virulent strains reach the lung, they are confronted by PAM. The interaction between virulent \(H.\) parasuis and PAM is limited and macrophage activation is delayed. During lung infection, \(H.\) parasuis adapt its metabolism to survive in the lung environment and express the necessary virulence factors to resist host defences (Fig. 4). Bacterial capsule and two surface proteins from the trimeric autotransporter family, named VtaA8 and VtaA9 (virulence-associated trimeric autotransporters o VtaA), play a role in phagocytosis resistance. Survival of virulent \(H.\) parasuis in the lung induces inflammation, including neutrophil recruitment, which may result in suppurative bronchopneumonia. The study of cellular location of virulent \(H.\) parasuis in the lung has shown that it can be found associated with neutrophils and macrophages, but also with pneumocytes. This later location of \(H.\) parasuis within pneumocytes may serve as a reservoir for persistent infections.
response: *H. parasuis* strains vary widely in virulence. Non-virulent strains are part of the normal upper respiratory microbiota, cause no disease, are susceptible to porcine alveolar macrophage (PAM) killing and serum, are cleared effectively if they reach the lungs, and cannot survive in blood for systemic spread—so they are controlled by innate immunity in healthy animals. In contrast, virulent strains evade host defenses: after colonizing the upper respiratory tract they can reach and persist in the lung by resisting phagocytosis, show limited interaction with PAM and delayed macrophage activation, and can also colonize nasal and tracheal mucosa (forming biofilm-like structures in the trachea). In the lung they adapt metabolism and express virulence factors, including the capsule and trimeric autotransporter surface proteins VtaA8 and VtaA9, which contribute to phagocytosis resistance. Their survival triggers inflammation with neutrophil recruitment that may lead to suppurative bronchopneumonia, and they can associate with neutrophils, macrophages, and pneumocytes; localization in pneumocytes may act as a reservoir for persistent infection.

query: The fracture reduction can be achieved either by closed, open, or semi-open method. Reduction of fracture without incising the skin or exposing the bone, through external manipulation, is called closed reduction. The technique involves holding the major bone segments over the skin, separating the impacted broken ends by traction if needed and then aligning them to the near normal anatomical position. Normally, after a closed reduction, fracture is immobilized with an external fixation technique, although in certain internal fixation, reduction can be achieved externally as in fresh cases of incomplete/greenstick fractures of femur in young animals without bone displacement. Closed reduction is generally indicated in fresh lower limb fractures, comprising only two bone pieces with little or no overriding of the bone segments. Closed reduction is done only when the bone segments are easily palpable with less muscular coverage. It reduces the risk of soft tissue trauma from the surgical incision and also the cost of initial treatment.
response: Fracture reduction can be performed by closed, open, or semi-open methods. Closed reduction realigns a fracture without skin incision or bone exposure, using external manipulation: the main bone segments are held through the skin, impacted ends are separated by traction if needed, and the fragments are aligned to near-normal anatomy. After closed reduction, fractures are usually immobilized with external fixation, though in some cases reduction can be done externally even when using internal fixation (e.g., fresh incomplete/greenstick femoral fractures in young animals without displacement). Closed reduction is generally indicated for fresh lower-limb fractures with two bone pieces and minimal or no overriding, and when fragments are easily palpable with little muscle coverage. It lowers soft-tissue trauma risk compared with surgical incision and reduces initial treatment cost.

query: In normal animals, the dorsal cricoaryten­ oideus muscles contract to abduct the corni­ culate processes of the arytenoids during inspiration, causing opening of the rima glot­ tidis. This muscle is innervated by the recur­ rent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus that originates near the thoracic inlet and loops around the subclavian artery on the right side, or the aorta on the left side, and returns cra­ niad to the larynx. Laryngeal paralysis is recog­ nized as a congenital disorder or heritable disease in some breeds and as an acquired form in older, large breed dogs. Some breeds that develop congenital laryngeal paralysis are affected by a generalized polyneuropathy (Table 1), and in the acquired idiopathic form, several studies have now confirmed the generalized nature of the neurologic deficits. Electromyographic studies and nerve conduc­ tion velocities in peripheral limb musculature of dogs with acquired laryngeal paralysis are suggestive of axonal disease (Jeffrey et al. 2006; Thieman et al. 2010). It has been recognized that affected older, large breed dogs often dis­ play clinical signs and physical examination findings of esophageal dysfunction and decreased proprioceptive placing, supporting a more generalized neurologic defect (Stanley et al. 2010). Laryngeal sensation is also abnor­ mal. This syndrome has been labeled geriatric-­ onset laryngeal paralysis–polyneuropathy (GOLPP).
response: Normally, the dorsal cricoarytenoideus muscles abduct the corniculate processes of the arytenoids during inspiration to open the rima glottidis; they are innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (a vagal branch) that loops around the right subclavian artery or the left aorta before returning to the larynx. Laryngeal paralysis occurs as a congenital/heritable disorder in some breeds and as an acquired condition in older large-breed dogs. Both congenital cases (in some breeds) and acquired idiopathic cases are associated with generalized polyneuropathy/generalized neurologic deficits, with EMG and nerve conduction findings suggesting axonal disease. Affected older large-breed dogs often also show esophageal dysfunction, decreased proprioceptive placing, and abnormal laryngeal sensation, consistent with a generalized neurologic syndrome termed geriatric-onset laryngeal paralysis–polyneuropathy (GOLPP).

query: In all cases where there is no chance of any eye condition recovering, enucleation should be considered on welfare grounds. This can be carried out under heavy sedation, normally with xylazine. Local anaesthetic should be instilled all around the orbit, not only under the skin but also into the deeper tissues with a single very deep injection of 5 ml behind the eye to block the optic nerve. The eyelids should then be sutured together and the whole area clipped and prepared aseptically. A careful incision is then made through the skin parallel to the upper eyelid margin, but not entering the conjunctival sac. Using blunt dissection, the eye muscles are sectioned around that half of the eye. The same procedure is then carried out on the lower half. Eventually, a pair of curved scissors can be used to section the optic nerve and the eye can be removed. The remaining socket can then be obliterated with subcuticular suturing with absorbable material and the remaining eyelids sutured with non-absorbable material. The animal should receive antibiotics and NSAIDs for a minimum of 5 days. The sutures should be removed in 10 days.
response: Enucleation should be considered for welfare when an eye condition has no chance of recovery. It is performed under heavy sedation (typically xylazine) with local anaesthetic instilled around the orbit, including a deep 5 ml injection behind the eye to block the optic nerve. The eyelids are sutured closed, the area is clipped and prepared aseptically, and an incision is made parallel to the upper eyelid margin without entering the conjunctival sac. Using blunt dissection, the eye muscles are cut around the upper half and then the lower half of the eye; curved scissors are used to cut the optic nerve and remove the eye. The socket is closed with absorbable subcuticular sutures and the eyelids with non-absorbable sutures. Postoperatively, antibiotics and NSAIDs are given for at least 5 days, and sutures are removed after 10 days.

query: The causative organism  of bluetongue disease, Bluetongue virus (BTV), is an Orbivirus with 24 serotypes, which tend to be restricted to certain areas. Various species of Culicoides midges are required as vectors. Replication of the virus has to occur in the vector. BTV serotype 8 first came to northern Europe in 2006 and caused the birth of ‘dummy’ calves. BTV is primarily a disease of sheep and goats, but the first recorded case in the UK was in a cow. Bluetongue is a notifiable disease and a number of cases were reported in the UK in  Normally the virus is asymptomatic in cattle except for causing abortions and stillbirths with central nervous system (CNS) defects. If there are signs of clinical disease in cattle they are caused by endothelial damage and disseminated intravascular coagulation, and are shown as haemorrhage, ischaemia, inflammation and oedema. The lesions are common in areas subject to mechanical trauma and abrasion, e.g. the feet, mouth and eyes. There is fever up to 42°C. The diagnosis is confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for viral RNA. It can detect all 24 serotypes. There is no specific treatment for BTV. Antibiotics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) are helpful. Nursing is vital and should include offering water and mushy food, and providing deep bedding out of the sun and heat. There are vaccines available which are monovalent for each serotype. Cattle require two doses separated by 2 weeks.
response: Bluetongue disease is caused by Bluetongue virus (BTV), an Orbivirus with 24 serotypes that are often geographically restricted; transmission requires Culicoides midges as vectors, and the virus must replicate within the vector. BTV primarily affects sheep and goats, though the first UK case was in a cow; serotype 8 entered northern Europe in 2006 and was associated with “dummy” calves. The disease is notifiable. In cattle, infection is usually asymptomatic but can cause abortions and stillbirths with CNS defects; when clinical signs occur, they result from endothelial damage and disseminated intravascular coagulation, producing haemorrhage, ischaemia, inflammation, and oedema, especially in trauma-prone areas (feet, mouth, eyes), with fever up to 42°C. Diagnosis is confirmed by PCR detection of viral RNA, which can identify all 24 serotypes. There is no specific treatment; supportive care is key, with antibiotics and NSAIDs as helpful adjuncts, plus nursing (water, mushy food, deep bedding, shade/cool environment). Vaccines are available as serotype-specific monovalent products; cattle need two doses 2 weeks apart.

query: Salmonella typhimurium is found in cattle, sheep, goats, SACs, pigs and (rarely) in poultry worldwide. It will cause enteritis in humans. S. enteritidis is mainly found in poultry worldwide and will also cause enteritis in humans. S. enterica serovar Dublin is mainly found in cattle and rarely causes human enteritis. There are also other Salmonella species/subspecies/serovars causing salmonellosis which are ever present on farms, e.g. S. enterica ssp. diarizonae and serovar Montevideo. Further, there are species-specific salmonellae, e.g. S. pullorum and S. gallinarum, both found in poultry, and S. abortus ovis, found in sheep. These species rarely cause human disease. Most human Salmonella infections are acquired as a result of eating contaminated food. Infection on farms is more commonly acquired by mouth from hands contaminated by infected animals, their bedding and surroundings. In addition to the general safety measures outlined in the Introduction, the following simple precautions will go a long way towards preventing people associated with livestock from becoming infected with salmonellosis: Ensure that anyone with diarrhoea, vomiting or flu-like illness consults a doctor, and informs the doctor if salmonellae have been isolated from livestock. Don’t allow vulnerable people, including children, the elderly, those with a weakened immune system and pregnant women to come into contact with infected animals. Don’t bring infected animals into any room where food is prepared or eaten. Don’t drink raw milk or eat undercooked eggs from the herd/flock when salmonellae have been isolated – even healthy animals may excrete salmonellae.
response: Salmonella typhimurium infects multiple livestock species worldwide (cattle, sheep, goats, SACs, pigs, and rarely poultry) and can cause enteritis in humans. S. enteritidis is mainly associated with poultry worldwide and also causes human enteritis, while S. enterica serovar Dublin is mainly found in cattle and rarely causes human enteritis. Other salmonellae may be present on farms (e.g., S. enterica ssp. diarizonae and serovar Montevideo), and some are species-specific (e.g., S. pullorum and S. gallinarum in poultry, S. abortus ovis in sheep) and rarely cause human disease. Most human infections come from eating contaminated food, whereas farm-acquired infection more often occurs via oral exposure from hands contaminated by infected animals, bedding, or surroundings. Recommended precautions include: anyone with diarrhoea, vomiting, or flu-like illness should consult a doctor and mention livestock salmonella; keep vulnerable people (children, elderly, immunocompromised, pregnant women) away from infected animals; do not bring infected animals into rooms where food is prepared or eaten; and avoid raw milk and undercooked eggs from herds/flocks when salmonellae have been isolated, since even healthy animals may shed salmonellae.

query: It is perhaps in the reproductive system where ruminants are most at variance from SACs. Ruminants have an oestrus cycle, with spontaneous ovulation and no follicular wave cycle. SACs do not have an oestrus cycle and are induced ovulators, but they do have a follicular wave cycle. Ruminants copulate in the standing position with ejaculation short and intense. SACs copulate in the prone position and have prolonged ejaculation. The male SAC has a cartilaginous projection on the tip of his penis. This is absent in ruminants. SACs have a diffuse placenta and the fetus is surrounded by an epidermal membrane. Ruminant fetuses do not have such a membrane but have placental cotyledons. SACs are primarily nasal breathers with an elongated soft palate, and mouth breathing in SACs is an extremely serious sign. Ruminants have a short soft palate and can breathe nasally or orally. The kidneys of SACs are smooth and elliptical. Some ruminants have smooth kidneys, e.g. sheep, and some lobed kidneys, e.g. cattle. The female SAC has a suburethral diverticulum at the external urethral orifice. Ruminants have no such diverticulum. SACs have not only unique internal parasites and protozoa, but also share other species of parasite with cattle, sheep and goats. The picture with external parasites is confusing. SACs certainly have unique lice, and they may also have unique mange mites, but the classification is not yet confirmed.
response: South American camelids (SACs) differ from ruminants in several key ways. In reproduction, ruminants have an oestrus cycle with spontaneous ovulation and no follicular wave cycle, whereas SACs lack an oestrus cycle, are induced ovulators, and do have a follicular wave cycle. Mating differs: ruminants copulate standing with short, intense ejaculation; SACs copulate prone with prolonged ejaculation. Male SACs have a cartilaginous projection at the tip of the penis, which ruminants lack. Placentation differs: SACs have a diffuse placenta and the fetus is surrounded by an epidermal membrane; ruminants lack this membrane but have placental cotyledons. Respiratory anatomy differs: SACs are mainly nasal breathers with an elongated soft palate, and mouth breathing is a very serious sign; ruminants have a short soft palate and can breathe through nose or mouth. SAC kidneys are smooth and elliptical, while ruminant kidneys may be smooth (e.g., sheep) or lobed (e.g., cattle). Female SACs have a suburethral diverticulum at the external urethral orifice; ruminants do not. Regarding parasites, SACs have unique internal parasites and protozoa and also share some parasites with cattle, sheep, and goats; externally, they clearly have unique lice and may have unique mange mites, but classifications remain unconfirmed.

query: The many functions of the liver include blood detoxification, regulation of circulating hormones, carbohydrate metabolism, protein synthesis, and secretion of bile salts (Fox, 2002). In addition, de novo lipogenesis, the conversion of glucose to triglycerides (neutral lipids), takes place primarily in the liver of the chicken. In the case of laying hens, the liver is a source of triacylglycerols (TAG) found within eggs. This is due to a production shift in hepatocytic lipoproteins caused by estrogen (Walzmen et al., 1999).
response: The liver performs many functions, including detoxifying blood, regulating circulating hormones, carbohydrate metabolism, protein synthesis, and secreting bile salts. In chickens, the liver is also the primary site of de novo lipogenesis (converting glucose into triglycerides/neutral lipids). In laying hens, the liver supplies the triacylglycerols (TAG) deposited in eggs because estrogen shifts hepatocyte lipoprotein production.

query: Spring viraemia of carp (SVC) is an acute viral disease of carps and some other cyprinid and ictalurid species causing haemorrhagic and contagious viraemia [15]. It causes significant mortality during spring [16]. This disease is OIE-notifiable and is caused by SVC virus (SVCV), a member of the genus Vesiculovirus under the family Rhabdoviridae in the order Mononegavirales. The virus is enveloped and bulletshaped, measuring approximately 80–180 nm in length and 60–90 nm in diameter. The genome of the virus is non-segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA consisting of 11,019 nucleotides encoding five proteins: a nucleoprotein (N), a phosphoprotein (P), a matrix protein (M), a glycoprotein (G), and an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L). The non-virion (NV) gene found in between the G and L genes in Novirhabdovirus genus of Rhabdoviridae family is missing in this virus [16]. Based on the partial G gene sequence, SVCV isolates are classified into four genotypes, 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d. Isolates from North America and Asia belong to genotype 1a, while isolates from Europe belong to genotypes 1b, 1c, and 1d [96].
response: Spring viraemia of carp (SVC) is an acute, haemorrhagic, contagious viral disease of carp and some other cyprinid and ictalurid fish, causing significant mortality in spring and being OIE-notifiable. It is caused by spring viraemia of carp virus (SVCV), an enveloped, bullet-shaped vesiculovirus (family Rhabdoviridae, order Mononegavirales) about 80–180 nm long and 60–90 nm in diameter. SVCV has a non-segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA genome of 11,019 nucleotides encoding five proteins (N, P, M, G, L) and lacks the NV gene found between G and L in Novirhabdovirus. Based on partial G gene sequences, SVCV isolates are grouped into four genotypes (1a–1d): North American and Asian isolates are genotype 1a, while European isolates are genotypes 1b, 1c, and 1d.

query: Septic pedal arthritis does occur in small ruminants but it is rare. Antibiotic treatment, even if prolonged, is rarely successful. Welfare must always be considered, and euthanasia is certainly an option for relieving further suffering. Full drainage of the distal phalangeal joint, with subsequent arthrodesis, may be considered, but this will result in a long period of severe pain. Surgical removal of the digit is a more humane option. It is vital that this surgery is not attempted if there is sepsis in the proximal joints, as pain will then persist. If clinicians are in any doubt, radiography should be carried out. Regional anaesthesia can be used. The distal limb can be cleaned but full asepsis is not required. A length of embryotomy wire is placed between the digits. The sawing direction should be at an angle of 45° above the horizontal. The skin, soft tissue and half the second phalanx should be removed. The foot then should be bandaged before removal of the tourniquet. The animal should be given antibiotic and NSAID cover for a minimum of 1 week. The bandage should be removed every third day until clean granulation tissue is seen.
response:
Septic pedal arthritis is rare in small ruminants, and even prolonged antibiotic therapy is usually unsuccessful. Animal welfare is paramount; euthanasia is an option. Although distal phalangeal joint drainage followed by arthrodesis can be considered, it causes a long period of severe pain, so surgical digit removal is a more humane choice. Digit removal should not be attempted if there is sepsis in proximal joints because pain will persist; if unsure, radiography should be performed.

For digit removal: use regional anaesthesia; clean the distal limb (full asepsis not required); place embryotomy wire between the digits and saw at a 45° angle above horizontal; remove skin, soft tissue, and half of the second phalanx; bandage before removing the tourniquet. Provide antibiotics and NSAIDs for at least 1 week, and change the bandage every third day until clean granulation tissue appears.

query: The most common abnormal urine color is pink, red, or reddish brown and can be attributed to intact red blood cells (RBC), hemolyzed RBC, muscle pigments, food pigments, or porphyrins (Figure 3). The most common cause of pink to red urine is the presence of intact RBC (hematuria) (Figure 4.4a–e). Intact RBC in urine impart a pink to brown color to urine, depending on the number of RBC, urine pH, and length of time the RBC have been in the urine [2]. A substantial number of RBC must be present in urine before a pink or red color is observed (Figure 4.5). Light pink color was observed in urine from dogs when approximately 600 RBC/hpf were present in the urine sediment and dark pink color was observed when 800–950 RBC/hpf were present [14]. Red color from intact RBC in urine clears with centrifugation or settling (Figure 4.6). Hemoglobinuria from intravascular hemolysis or lysis of previously intact red cells in the urine specimen (in vivo or in vitro) also may cause reddish color that persists in the supernatant after settling or centrifugation (Figure 4.7a,b). Uncommonly, the presence of myoglobinuria, or rarely porphyrinuria, may cause a reddish color (see also Chapter 5, occult blood). Rarely, dyes used in the manufacture of some dry dog foods or ingestion of an unusual food item will impart a pink color to the urine. Discoloration caused by free hemoglobin, myoglobin, porphyrin, or dyes will persist in the urine supernatant after centrifugation, because they are dissolved in the urine. The term “beeturia” has been used to describe pink to deep red discolored urine from human patients after eating beets or foods that have been colored with beet pigments. Betacyanuria is the preferred scientific term that describes these red pigments in urine. Betanin and its epimer isobetanin contribute most of this red color. Urine can become progressively pinker when beetroot pigments are exposed to sunlight. High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) can be used to definitively identify beetroot pigments in urine, but this is not clinically necessary since beeturia is a benign condition. A main concern in human medicine is that beeturia can be misdiagnosed as painless hematuria [15]. The occurrence of beeturia in urine of dogs and cats is not known.
response: Pink, red, or reddish-brown urine is most commonly due to intact red blood cells (hematuria), but it can also result from hemolyzed RBC/hemoglobin, muscle pigments (myoglobin), food pigments, porphyrins, or dyes. Intact RBC cause urine to range from pink to brown depending on RBC quantity, urine pH, and how long RBC have been in the urine; visible pink/red discoloration requires many RBC (in dogs, ~600 RBC/hpf for light pink and ~800–950 RBC/hpf for dark pink). With intact RBC, the red color clears after centrifugation or settling, whereas discoloration from dissolved hemoglobin, myoglobin, porphyrins, or dyes persists in the supernatant. Rarely, certain dry dog-food dyes or unusual foods can cause pink urine. In humans, beet ingestion can cause benign pink-to-deep-red urine (“beeturia,” scientifically “betacyanuria”) mainly from betanin/isobetanin; the urine may become pinker with sunlight exposure, HPLC can confirm pigments but is usually unnecessary, and the main clinical issue is confusion with painless hematuria. The occurrence of beeturia in dogs and cats is unknown.

query: Entrance of air into the pleural space causes intrapleural pressure to become positive, which results in collapse of the lungs with a subsequent drop in venous return and cardiac output. Pneumothorax can be closed or open depending on whether or not there is communication between the pleural space and outside the thorax. The most common causes of pneumothorax in dogs are likely blunt force trauma from car collisions or penetrating trauma from an inhaled foreign body. Exposure to porcupine quills has also resulted in pneumothorax in the northern United States and Canada (Sevy et al. 2023). In the cat, blunt trauma occurs from a car accident or fall from a height, although inflammatory lower airway disease is also a common cause of pneumothorax (Mooney et al. 2012). In dogs or cats, esophageal perforation can lead to pneumothorax, and it can also result from rupture of an emphysematous bulla, pleural bleb, neoplasm, Paragonimus cyst, or abscessed lung lobe. Lung necrosis due to embolization associated with heartworm disease or pulmonary thromboembolic disease has also been implicated in pneumothorax. Barotrauma during anesthesia or mechanical ventilation is recognized as an iatrogenic cause of pneumothorax and it can also occur post-­thoracocentesis or fine-­needle lung aspiration. Multiple lung lobes can be involved depending on the underlying disease process, and cranial lobes are affected most commonly in spontaneous pneumothorax.
response: Air entering the pleural space makes intrapleural pressure positive, collapsing the lungs and reducing venous return and cardiac output. Pneumothorax is classified as closed or open depending on whether the pleural space communicates with the outside. In dogs, the most common causes are blunt trauma (e.g., car accidents) or penetrating trauma (e.g., inhaled foreign bodies), and porcupine quills have also caused cases in northern US/Canada. In cats, causes include blunt trauma (car accidents, falls) and commonly inflammatory lower airway disease. In both species, pneumothorax can also result from esophageal perforation; rupture of an emphysematous bulla or pleural bleb; neoplasia; Paragonimus cysts; abscessed lung lobes; lung necrosis from embolization associated with heartworm or pulmonary thromboembolic disease; and iatrogenic barotrauma during anesthesia/mechanical ventilation, including after thoracocentesis or fine-needle lung aspiration. Multiple lobes may be involved, and cranial lobes are most commonly affected in spontaneous pneumothorax.

query: The liver has numerous key functions in the storage and conversion of metabolites [4]. In birds, the liver plays a major role in the synthesis and metabolism of lipids, notably because lipogenesis takes place primarily in the liver, unlike in mammals, where the adipose tissues are the site for lipogenesis [5]. De novo lipogenesis comprises those metabolic pathways that are involved in the synthesis of triglycerides from non-lipid precursors most commonly from dietary carbohydrate. [5]. Unfortunately, the high-energy diets used in the commercial poultry industry such as high carbohydrate diets stimulate hepatic lipogenesis [8]. Under some of these feeding regimes, pathological conditions such as the fatty liver and kidney syndrome in broilers arise [4].
response: In birds, the liver is essential for storing and converting metabolites and is the primary site of lipid synthesis and metabolism because lipogenesis occurs mainly in the liver (unlike mammals, where it occurs in adipose tissue). De novo lipogenesis refers to metabolic pathways that synthesize triglycerides from non-lipid precursors, most commonly dietary carbohydrates. High-energy, high-carbohydrate diets used in commercial poultry production stimulate hepatic lipogenesis and, under some feeding regimes, can lead to pathological conditions such as fatty liver and kidney syndrome in broilers.

query: Some reptiles will have problems shedding the skin. This is called dysecdysis. If the patient is having problems shedding the skin, the humidity and/or temperature in the cage should be increased or the animal can be soaked in a warm water bath. Always examine the toes of lizards such as leopard geckos if they are having problems shedding their skin, as the skin can become wrapped around the digits, cutting off circulation and causing necrosis. The shed skin should be examined to verify that all the skin has been shed. Snakes and some geckos have eye caps or spectacles that represent fused eyelids. Incomplete shedding can result in retained spectacles and give a dull and dry appearance to the eye caps. This can occur on one or both eyes.
response: Dysecdysis is difficulty shedding skin in reptiles. Management includes increasing cage humidity and/or temperature or soaking the animal in a warm water bath. In lizards (e.g., leopard geckos), toes should be checked because retained skin can constrict digits, cut off circulation, and cause necrosis. The shed skin should be inspected to ensure shedding is complete. Snakes and some geckos have eye caps (spectacles; fused eyelids), and incomplete shedding can cause retained spectacles, making the eye caps look dull and dry, potentially affecting one or both eyes.

query: Diagnosis of feline heartworm disease remains difficult. Peripheral eosinophilia is present in \(<50\%\) of cases. Radiographic findings in feline heartworm disease are reflected by enlargement of caudal pulmonary lobar arteries to greater than 6 times the size of the ninth rib (Figure 8.5). However, in some cases pulmonary infiltrates can obscure visualization of the vasculature, and in one study of naturally infected cats, abnormalities in the pulmonary vasculature were uncommon (Venco et al. 2008). Unlike dogs, cardiac chambers are unlikely to be changed by heartworm infection. Focal or diffuse bronchointerstitial infiltrates are the most common parenchymal changes in cats with heartworm, but the presence and type of infiltrates depend on the stage of disease (Venco et al. 2008). Heartworm antibody positivity indicates only exposure to heartworm, and false-­ negative tests are unfortunately common. The antigen test can detect a single female heartworm, but can be falsely negative when no females are present or when only a few live males are present. Also, antigen–antibody complex formation appears to be more problematic in cats than in dogs, and heat-­treating serum leads to a substantial increase in positive antigen tests in infected cats (Little et al. 2014). This methodology is not advised as a screening test however, because of an increase in false-­positive results. Heartworm disease can be diagnosed on echocardiography by the presence of two parallel hyperechoic lines in the right ventricle or pulmonary artery
response: Diagnosing feline heartworm disease is challenging because peripheral eosinophilia occurs in fewer than 50% of cases and imaging/lab tests have limitations. Radiographs may show enlarged caudal pulmonary lobar arteries (>6× the size of the ninth rib), but pulmonary infiltrates can obscure vessels and vascular abnormalities may be uncommon; unlike dogs, cats typically do not have cardiac chamber changes. The most common lung changes are focal or diffuse bronchointerstitial infiltrates, varying with disease stage. Antibody tests indicate exposure only and false negatives are common. Antigen tests can detect a single female worm but may be falsely negative if no females or only a few live males are present; antigen–antibody complexes are a greater issue in cats, and heat-treating serum increases antigen positives but is not recommended for screening due to more false positives. Echocardiography can diagnose infection by seeing two parallel hyperechoic lines in the right ventricle or pulmonary artery.

query: The snake mite Ophionyssus natricis appears as red to dark-coloured pin-head mites hiding under the overlapping edges of scales, although they are also commonly found around the commissures of the mouth. They may be seen in water dishes in which the reptile has been bathing. They can cause severe irritation, pruritus and selftrauma, as well as causing anaemia and dysecdysis. In addition, they can transmit Aeromonas spp. bacteria, which may cause septicaemia, and viruses such as inclusion body disease (IBD). Other mites include the cloacal mites (Cloacarus spp.) of aquatic turtles and Hirstiella spp. of mites in lizards (although the snake mite can also be found on reptiles other than snakes). In addition, there is of course the non-parasitic harvest mite Neotrombicula autumnalis, which may be brought in on straw and hay bedding material. The adult itself is not an irritant but the six-legged larval stage is and may cause the reptile to traumatise itself.
response: The snake mite *Ophionyssus natricis* is a red to dark pinhead-sized mite that typically hides under overlapping scale edges, often around the mouth corners, and may also be seen in the reptile’s water dish after bathing. It can cause severe irritation, itching and self-trauma, as well as anaemia and dysecdysis, and it can transmit *Aeromonas* spp. (leading to septicaemia) and viruses such as inclusion body disease (IBD). Other mites mentioned include cloacal mites (*Cloacarus* spp.) in aquatic turtles and *Hirstiella* spp. in lizards, and snake mites can infest reptiles other than snakes. The non-parasitic harvest mite *Neotrombicula autumnalis* may be introduced via straw/hay bedding; adults are not irritant, but the six-legged larvae are and can cause self-trauma.

query: The signaling network that triggers IFN production also recruits adaptor proteins, such as TRIF (TIR-domain-containing adapter-inducing IFN-  $\beta$  ) and MAVS (mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein). These proteins activate TBK1 to phosphorylate interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3), which is indispensable for driving the production of IFN-  $\beta$  (2, 3). Members of the I $\kappa$ B kinase (IKK) family are critical to the inflammatory response. While canonical IKKs activate transcriptional factor NF-  $\kappa$  B, TBK1 phosphorylates transcriptional factor IRFs, resulting in their dimerization, cytoplasm-to-nucleus translocation, and DNA binding to stimulate the transcription of IFNs (4, 5).
response: IFN production is triggered by a signaling network that recruits adaptor proteins such as TRIF and MAVS. These adaptors activate TBK1, which phosphorylates IRF3—an essential step for inducing IFN-β production. In the IKK family, canonical IKKs drive inflammatory responses by activating NF-κB, whereas TBK1 phosphorylates IRFs, leading to their dimerization, nuclear translocation, DNA binding, and subsequent transcription of IFNs.

query: Viperin exhibits broad antiviral and antimicrobial activity, by mechanisms which are still being understood (Hinson et al., 2010). Thus far, viperin has been shown to inhibit viral protein and/or RNA biosynthesis for a number of different viruses (Chin and Cresswell, 2001; Jiang et al., 2010). In addition, viperin has been shown to localise to the ER, which disrupts lipid rafts thereby inhibiting the trafficking of soluble virally encoded proteins during influenza infection (Hinson and Cresswell, 2009; Wang et al., 2007).
response: Viperin has broad antiviral and antimicrobial activity through mechanisms that are not yet fully understood. It has been shown to inhibit viral protein and/or RNA biosynthesis in multiple viruses, and to localize to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), where it disrupts lipid rafts and thereby inhibits trafficking of soluble virally encoded proteins during influenza infection.

query: Newcastle disease (ND) is among the major poultry diseases incriminated for reduction of total numbers and impairment of productivity. It is an acute and highly contagious viral infection that can affect most species of birds (OIE, 2009). The Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains are classified as velogenic, mesogenic, and lentogenic based on their pathotypes and virulence (Brown and Bevins, 2017; Schirrmacher, 2017). The pathogenicity of NDV strains is determined using virus isolation followed by in vivo tests such as the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), intravenous pathogenicity index, and mean death time (MDT) in specified pathogen-free chicken embryo and birds (Alexander et al., 2004; Putri et al., 2017).
response: Newcastle disease (ND) is a major poultry disease that reduces bird numbers and productivity. It is an acute, highly contagious viral infection affecting most bird species. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains are classified by pathotype/virulence into velogenic, mesogenic, and lentogenic. NDV pathogenicity is determined by isolating the virus and then performing in vivo tests, including the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), intravenous pathogenicity index, and mean death time (MDT) in specified pathogen-free chicken embryos and birds.

query: Blood collection can be particularly challenging in amphibians. Alcohol should not be used to clean the venipuncture site. This can irritate and/or desiccate the patient’s skin. A 1:40 diluted 2% chlorhexidine solution should be used to cleanse the site instead. Venipuncture in salamanders is generally performed using the caudal tail vein. This is the same technique described previously for both lizards and snakes. It is important to remember that the vessel is very small and can collapse easily; therefore, do not place a large amount of negative pressure on the syringe during collection. A 25- to 27-gauge needle attached to a 1-mL syringe should be used. An insulin syringe can also be used for very small patients. The blood sample should be placed in a heparinized Microtainer tube for analysis. Venipuncture sites in frogs and toads include the femoral vein, ventral abdominal vein, and the lingual vein. The femoral and lingual veins are rarely used. The ventral abdominal vein is by far the easiest vessel to obtain a blood sample from. The frog or toad is gently positioned on its back with the restrainer holding the pectoral girdle. The person drawing blood can hold the pelvic girdle with one hand and draw blood with the other hand. Restraint without gloves can damage the epithelium and cause subsequent elevated white blood cell counts. Some amphibians will need to be anesthetized for venipuncture. This can be achieved with a 2%–3% MS222 solution. A 1-mL syringe with a 25- to 27-gauge needle is generally used to obtain the sample although an insulin syringe can be used as well. The blood sample should be placed into a heparinized Microtainer tube for analysis. Blood volume needs to be considered in these small patients. No more than 1% of the body weight should be taken in blood volume from healthy amphibians, and no more than 5% should be taken from sick patients.
response: Blood collection in amphibians is challenging, and alcohol should not be used to clean venipuncture sites because it can irritate or desiccate the skin; instead, cleanse with a 1:40 dilution of 2% chlorhexidine. In salamanders, venipuncture is typically from the caudal tail vein using a 25–27 gauge needle on a 1 mL syringe (or an insulin syringe for very small animals), applying minimal negative pressure because the vessel is small and collapses easily; samples should be placed in a heparinized Microtainer tube. In frogs and toads, possible sites are the femoral, ventral abdominal, and lingual veins, with the ventral abdominal vein being the easiest; proper restraint involves positioning the animal on its back and avoiding glove-free restraint that can damage epithelium and raise white blood cell counts. Some amphibians may require anesthesia with 2%–3% MS222. Blood volume limits are important: take no more than 1% of body weight from healthy amphibians and no more than 5% from sick patients.

query: FOXO3 is involved in many biological processes where it functions as a transcriptional regulator. FOXO3 can retard the cell cycle by regulating cell cycle-related genes, such as cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor 1A  $(p21)$ , cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor 1B  $(p27)$ , RAB3 GTPase activating protein catalytic subunit 1  $(p130)$ , cyclin  $G2$ , and growth arrest and DNA damage inducible (GADD45) (Notas et al., 2012; Du et al., 2016). The functions of FOXO3 in the control of the cell cycle may explain its association with longevity. FOXO3 induces cellular apoptosis by activating apoptosis-related factors, such as Fas ligand  $(FasL)$ , BCL2 interacting protein 3 (BNIP3), autophagy-related 8 (ATG8), TNF superfamily member 10 (TRAIL), and phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) (Nakamura et al., 2000; Ghaffari et al., 2003; Shao et al., 2016). FOXO3 is an activator of the protein degradation pathway and it can promote the expression of muscle atrophy factors, including F-box protein 32 (FBXO32) (also known as atrogin 1) and muscle specific ring finger protein (MURF) to induce the atrophy of muscles (Lee et al., 2004; Sandri et al., 2004). In addition, the downstream genes of FOXO3 include microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3 (LC3), ubiquitin-binding protein  $p62$ , and Neighbor of BRCA1 gene 1 protein (NBR1), which are all involved in the muscle atrophy process (Mammucari et al., 2007). Thus, the inhibition of FOXO3 expression lead to the suppression of protein degradation as well as increasing the thickness of muscle fibers and the body weight (Zhao et al., 2007a).
response: FOXO3 is a transcriptional regulator involved in multiple biological processes. It can slow the cell cycle by regulating cell cycle-related genes (including p21, p27, p130, cyclin G2, and GADD45), which may help explain its association with longevity. FOXO3 also promotes apoptosis by activating factors such as FasL, BNIP3, ATG8, TRAIL, and PTEN. In addition, FOXO3 activates protein degradation pathways and contributes to muscle atrophy by increasing expression of muscle atrophy genes (FBXO32/atrogin 1 and MURF) and other downstream genes involved in atrophy (LC3, p62, and NBR1). Inhibiting FOXO3 suppresses protein degradation and increases muscle fiber thickness and body weight.

query: Recombinant antibody libraries derived from chicken immunoglobulin genes can be used as a source of diagnostic and research reagents. Accessing the chicken immunoglobulin repertoire is relatively easy since all the immunoglobulin variable heavy  $(\mathrm{V_H})$  and all the variable light  $(\mathrm{V_L})$  chain sequences are identical at their  $5^{\prime}$  and  $3^{\prime}$  ends. This implies that they can be amplified using only two sets of PCR primers [1-3]. Immunoglobulin diversity is generated in the bursa of Fabricius by gene conversion using pseudogene variable regions. This occurs in the first 4 months; therefore, the naive immunoglobulin repertoire can be accessed from avian bursal cells. Alternatively, chickens can be immunized with the antigens of interest and their spleens, blood lymphocytes, and/or bone marrow used as source of immunoglobulin mRNA [4-7].
response: Recombinant antibody libraries made from chicken immunoglobulin genes can serve as diagnostic and research reagents. The chicken immunoglobulin repertoire is relatively easy to access because all variable heavy (V_H) and variable light (V_L) chain sequences share identical 5′ and 3′ ends, allowing amplification with only two PCR primer sets. Immunoglobulin diversity is generated in the bursa of Fabricius via gene conversion using pseudogene variable regions during the first four months, so the naïve repertoire can be obtained from avian bursal cells. Alternatively, chickens can be immunized with target antigens and immunoglobulin mRNA sourced from spleen, blood lymphocytes, and/or bone marrow.

query: In recent years, polysaccharides, as an important plant extract compound, have been well known for their anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, immunomodulatory and microbiome regulating activities [1,2]. Moreover, due to their prominent pharmacological activities, some polysaccharides extracted from plants have been used to improve intestinal health, immunity, and growth performance in intensive farming [6,7]. Furthermore, recent studies have demonstrated that polysaccharides can regulate the intestinal microbiota structure and be fermented by the gut flora to produce the short chain fatty acids (SCFAs), which are further used to alleviate intestinal dysfunction [2,8]. Therefore, polysaccharides may serve as a useful natural dietary additive to improve the immunity, intestinal function, and structure of the intestinal flora of poultry at the chick stage.
response: Plant-derived polysaccharides are important bioactive extracts known for anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, immunomodulatory, and microbiome-regulating effects. Because of these pharmacological activities, some plant polysaccharides are used in intensive farming to improve intestinal health, immunity, and growth performance. Studies also show they can reshape gut microbiota and be fermented to produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), which help alleviate intestinal dysfunction. Thus, polysaccharides may be useful natural dietary additives to enhance immunity, intestinal function, and gut flora structure in chicks.

query: Pancreas disease (PD) or sleeping disease (SD) is an OIE-listed disease caused by infection with salmonid alphavirus (SAV) in Atlantic salmon, rainbow trout, common dab [21], and Arctic charr [22]. The disease is a systemic viral disease characterized by necrosis of exocrine pancreatic tissue, cardiomyocytic necrosis, and white skeletal muscle degeneration [15]. SAV is an enveloped spherical virus measuring 60–70 nm in diameter belonging to the genus Alphavirus and family Togaviridae. The genome consists of a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA of approximately 12 kb. The genome codes for eight proteins, four of which are non-structural proteins (nsP1–nsP4), and the remaining four are capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3 and 6K). Glycoprotein E2 induces neutralizing antibodies [21] and, hence, is an ideal candidate for developing sub-unit or DNA vaccines. Based on the sequences of protein E2 and nsP3, SAV isolates have been divided into six genotypes, SAV1–SAV6 [134]. Gills and intestinal track are the portals of entry. Although the predilection sites of the virus are not known, in acute cases, high titre of the virus is found in kidney, heart, blood, and several other organs. Virus is shed through mucus and faeces.
