Disease outbreaks are influenced by environmental factors, and increase in water temperature favours the virus [135]. The disease affects all life-stages in both freshwater and seawater [136]. The virus persists in the infected fish for several months and is transmitted horizontally through water [137].
response: Pancreas disease (PD) or sleeping disease (SD) is an OIE-listed systemic viral disease of Atlantic salmon, rainbow trout, common dab, and Arctic charr caused by salmonid alphavirus (SAV). It is characterized by necrosis of exocrine pancreatic tissue, cardiomyocytic necrosis, and degeneration of white skeletal muscle. SAV is an enveloped, spherical 60–70 nm alphavirus (family Togaviridae) with a ~12 kb positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome encoding eight proteins: four non-structural (nsP1–nsP4) and four structural/capsid glycoproteins (E1, E2, E3, 6K); E2 induces neutralizing antibodies and is a key vaccine candidate. Based on E2 and nsP3 sequences, SAV is divided into six genotypes (SAV1–SAV6). Entry occurs via gills and intestinal tract; in acute cases high viral titres occur in kidney, heart, blood, and other organs. The virus is shed in mucus and faeces, outbreaks are influenced by environmental factors with higher water temperature favouring the virus, it affects all life stages in freshwater and seawater, persists for months, and spreads horizontally through water.

query: In chickens, PGCs first separate in the epiblast in Eyal-Giladi and Kochav (EGK) stage X embryos and then move down the hypoblast of the area pellucida, and subsequently to the germinal crescent and enter the blood stream [15-17]. After migration through the circulatory system, they arrive at the genital ridges [18]. These unique characteristics in germline development make it possible to use them to produce transgenic chickens via the injection of genetically manipulated PGCs into the blood vessels of recipient eggs [19]. Moreover, recent advances have demonstrated that germline-competent chicken PGC lines can facilitate the production of germline chimeras and transgenic chickens with higher germline transmission efficiency than embryonic stem cells (ESC) and spermatogonial stem cells (SSC) [14, 20-22].
response: In chickens, primordial germ cells (PGCs) first segregate in the epiblast at Eyal-Giladi and Kochav (EGK) stage X, then migrate along the hypoblast of the area pellucida to the germinal crescent, enter the bloodstream, and finally reach the genital ridges. These migration and development features enable production of transgenic chickens by injecting genetically modified PGCs into recipient egg blood vessels. Recent advances show that germline-competent chicken PGC lines support generation of germline chimeras and transgenic chickens with higher germline transmission efficiency than embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs).

query: A parvovirus known as Aleutian disease is particularly lethal to mink, but in ferrets it produces unpleasant diarrhoea, although it is rarely fatal. It may produce melaenic faeces, fever, loss of weight and a number of other immune system-­mediated symptoms. Ferret epizootic coronaviral enteritis is an alphacoronavirus and results in high morbidity (up to 100%) but low mortality (<5%). \((<5\%)\) Clinical signs include lethargy and anorexia for a period of 48–72 hours after infection, with vomiting initially which then stops. After this profuse green (bile-­stained) diarrhoea with mucus is produced (so-­called ‘green slime disease’). Older ferrets with other diseases may show more severe clinical signs including intestinal ulceration. Younger ferrets have milder disease that resolves in 5–7 days. Some ferrets may be left with a maldigestion/ malabsorption syndrome. Clinical tests may show hypoalbuminaemia and increased ALT and alkaline phosphatase with a leukocytosis.
response: Aleutian disease parvovirus is highly lethal in mink but in ferrets usually causes unpleasant diarrhoea and is rarely fatal; signs can include melaena, fever, weight loss, and other immune-mediated symptoms. Ferret epizootic coronaviral enteritis is caused by an alphacoronavirus and has very high morbidity (up to 100%) but low mortality (<5%); after 48–72 hours of lethargy and anorexia, ferrets may initially vomit (then vomiting stops) and develop profuse green, bile-stained mucoid diarrhoea (“green slime disease”). Disease is more severe in older ferrets with comorbidities (including possible intestinal ulceration), milder in younger ferrets and typically resolves in 5–7 days, though some develop maldigestion/malabsorption. Laboratory findings may include hypoalbuminaemia, elevated ALT and alkaline phosphatase, and leukocytosis.

query: To date, 43 species and more than 50 genotypes of Cryptosporidium have been described, of which 21 have been reported to infect humans (Condlova et al. 2018; Ortega and Kvac 2013; Ryan and Xiao 2014). Many of these human pathogenic species and genotypes remain poorly characterized because only a few isolates are available for study. In contrast to other human-pathogenic protozoans, such as Toxoplasma (Muller and Hemphill 2013), there is a lack of in vitro methods to propagate Cryptosporidium oocysts (Arrowood 2002; Miller et al. 2019; Morada et al. 2016). In vivo,  $C.$  parvum can be propagated in several animal models (e.g. mice, piglets, calves, and gerbils) (Kvač et al. 2009; Petry et al. 1995; Vitovec and Koudela 1992), but many other human pathogenic species and genotypes have narrow host specificity and yield low numbers of oocysts in their typical hosts
response: More than 43 species and over 50 genotypes of *Cryptosporidium* are known, and 21 have been reported to infect humans. Many human-infective species/genotypes are still poorly characterized because few isolates are available. Unlike other human-pathogenic protozoa (e.g., *Toxoplasma*), *Cryptosporidium* lacks effective in vitro methods for propagating oocysts. In vivo, *C. parvum* can be propagated in several animal models (such as mice, piglets, calves, and gerbils), but many other human-pathogenic species/genotypes have narrow host specificity and produce low oocyst yields in their usual hosts.

query: Human β-defensin 3 (hBD-3) is a typical example of immunomodulatory effect of β-defensins. hBD-3 induces expression of costimulatory molecules CD80, 86 and 40 on immune cells through Toll-like receptors (TLRs) 1 and 2 (Funderburg et al., 2007). Also, hBD-3 shows chemotactic effects to leukocytes through chemokine receptor (CCR) 2 and 6 (Rohrl et al., 2010; Smithrithee et al., 2015). hBD-3 inhibit the binding of LPS through its binding to TLR4 that result in LPS-neutralizing activity (Hannahon et al., 2016). Moreover, hBD-3 show anti-inflammatory activity by targeting TLR signaling pathways (MyD88 and TRIF) that results in downregulation of proinflammatory genes (Semple et al., 2011).
response: Human β-defensin 3 (hBD-3) has immunomodulatory functions: it induces expression of costimulatory molecules (CD80, CD86, CD40) on immune cells via Toll-like receptors TLR1 and TLR2; acts as a chemoattractant for leukocytes through chemokine receptors CCR2 and CCR6; neutralizes LPS by binding TLR4 and inhibiting LPS binding; and exerts anti-inflammatory effects by targeting TLR signaling pathways (MyD88 and TRIF), downregulating proinflammatory gene expression.

query: Chicken type I interferons (type I IFNs) are key antiviral players of chicken immune system and mediate the first line of defense against viral pathogens infecting the avian species. Recognition of viral pathogens by specific pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) induce chicken type I IFNs expression followed by their subsequent interaction to IFN receptors and induction of a variety of IFN stimulated antiviral proteins. These antiviral effectors establish the antiviral state in neighboring cells and thus protect the host from infection. Three subtypes of chicken type I IFNs; chIFN- $\alpha$ , chIFN- $\beta$ , and a recently discovered chIFN- $\kappa$  have been identified and characterized in chicken. Chicken type I IFNs are activated by various host cell pathways and constitute major antiviral innate defense in chicken.
response: Chicken type I interferons (type I IFNs) are key antiviral components of the chicken immune system that provide a first line of defense against viral infections. Viral recognition by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) induces type I IFN expression, which then signals through IFN receptors to stimulate production of various IFN-stimulated antiviral proteins. These effectors establish an antiviral state in neighboring cells, helping protect the host from infection. Three chicken type I IFN subtypes have been identified and characterized: chIFN-α, chIFN-β, and the recently discovered chIFN-κ. They are activated via multiple host cell pathways and form a major part of chicken innate antiviral defense.

query: A series of studies in vitro and in vivo demonstrated that $\mathrm{Cr(VI)}$ can induce oxidative stress by enhancing the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). This phenomenon can lead to genomic DNA damage, as well as oxidative deterioration of lipids and proteins [1, 2]. Furthermore, $\mathrm{Cr(VI)}$ produces noxious ROS containing superoxide anion, hydroxyl radicals, and singlet oxygen through the formation of $\mathrm{Cr(V)}$ intermediates [3, 4]. ROS can cause oxidative injury if enzymatic and nonenzymatic antioxidation cannot control ROS [5]. Brains with high lipid content and low antioxidant levels exhibit large amounts of polyunsaturated fatty acids. The brain is especially vulnerable to attack of oxygen-containing free radicals. The brain can also influence oxidative balance as this organ consumes $20\%$ of the body's oxygen. Previous research demonstrated that $\mathrm{Cr(V)}$ increases the formation of ROS and lipid peroxidation in the mouse brain [6].
response: Studies in vitro and in vivo show that hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) induces oxidative stress by increasing reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can cause genomic DNA damage and oxidative deterioration of lipids and proteins. Cr(VI) generates harmful ROS—including superoxide anion, hydroxyl radicals, and singlet oxygen—via Cr(V) intermediates. ROS lead to oxidative injury when enzymatic and nonenzymatic antioxidant defenses cannot adequately control them. The brain is particularly susceptible because it has high lipid content with abundant polyunsaturated fatty acids, relatively low antioxidant levels, and high oxygen consumption (about 20% of the body’s oxygen). Prior research also found that Cr(V) increases ROS formation and lipid peroxidation in the mouse brain.

query: ‘Mouth rot’ is the colloquial term for stomatitis, commonly seen in many reptiles particularly in snakes and chelonians. The causes are many and varied. It can be caused by secondary infections with Gram-negative bacteria. The initial cause of the damage can be rubbing of the snout on vivarium glass, particularly in snakes. The use of opaque tape stuck to the outside of the glass helps the snake to ‘see it’, preventing this injury. Stomatitis may also be due to the overzealous force-feeding of anorectic reptiles or to other disease or stresses leading to reduced immune system function. Uric acid crystals deposited around the base of the teeth, due to visceral gout and renal failure, can allow infections to occur. Herpesvirus and ranavirus infections in terrestrial tortoises are also a cause, with oral ulceration and diphtherisis (see Figure 9). Mycoplasma spp. infections may also be associated with stomatitis in tortoises. Devriesea agamarum, a bacterium, has been reported in agamid lizards as a cause of proliferative cheilitis, pericloacal disease and dermatitis. Adenoviruses have been implicated in snakes and lizards and IBD in snakes. Diagnosis is made on impression smears and bacterial swab and culture of samples. A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for diagnosing many of the reptilian viral diseases is now commercially available, and reptile cell lines are available in some laboratories to attempt virus isolation where PCR is not accessible. Alternatively, electron microscopy of samples may aid the diagnosis.The snake mite Ophionyssus natricis appears as red to dark-coloured pin-head mites hiding under the overlapping edges of scales, although they are also commonly found around the commissures of the mouth. They may be seen in water dishes in which the reptile has been bathing. They can cause severe irritation, pruritus and selftrauma, as well as causing anaemia and dysecdysis. In addition, they can transmit Aeromonas spp. bacteria, which may cause septicaemia, and viruses such as inclusion body disease (IBD). Other mites include the cloacal mites (Cloacarus spp.) of aquatic turtles and Hirstiella spp. of mites in lizards (although the snake mite can also be found on reptiles other than snakes). In addition, there is of course the non-parasitic harvest mite Neotrombicula autumnalis, which may be brought in on straw and hay bedding material. The adult itself is not an irritant but the six-legged larval stage is and may cause the reptile to traumatise itself.
response:
‘Mouth rot’ (stomatitis) is common in reptiles, especially snakes and chelonians, and has many causes: secondary Gram-negative bacterial infection; snout rubbing on vivarium glass (preventable by placing opaque tape on the outside so the snake sees the barrier); trauma from force-feeding; other disease or stress causing immunosuppression; uric acid crystal deposition around teeth due to visceral gout/renal failure; viral causes in terrestrial tortoises (herpesvirus, ranavirus) leading to oral ulceration and diphtheresis; possible associations with Mycoplasma spp. in tortoises; and other reported pathogens/associations including Devriesea agamarum in agamid lizards (proliferative cheilitis, pericloacal disease, dermatitis), adenoviruses in snakes and lizards, and inclusion body disease (IBD) in snakes. Diagnosis uses impression smears plus bacterial swab/culture; PCR tests for many reptile viruses are commercially available; virus isolation may be attempted in some labs using reptile cell lines if PCR is unavailable; electron microscopy can also help.

The snake mite (Ophionyssus natricis) appears as red to dark pinhead-sized mites under scale edges and around mouth commissures and may be seen in water dishes; it causes irritation, pruritus, self-trauma, anaemia, and dysecdysis, and can transmit Aeromonas spp. (septicaemia) and viruses such as IBD. Other mites mentioned are Cloacarus spp. (cloacal mites of aquatic turtles), Hirstiella spp. in lizards (and snake mites can infest non-snake reptiles), and the non-parasitic harvest mite Neotrombicula autumnalis introduced via straw/hay, where the larval stage (not the adult) irritates and can lead to self-trauma.

query: Among Mycoplasma species, Mycoplasma gallisepticum  $(\mathrm{Mg})$  is an avian pathogen that causes infectious sinusitis in turkeys [4] and chronic respiratory disease in chickens [5], leading to serious economic losses in poultry industry in terms of low carcass quality, reduce egg production and hatchability [6]. Studies reported that  $\mathrm{Mg}$  adhere to the host mucosal epithelial cells, followed by subsequent colonization in host cells and produce vigorous inflammatory responses [7]. Accumulative evidences showed that a bird infected with  $\mathrm{Mg}$ , often remains infected for life and act as a carrier of infection for other wild birds and facilities [8]. Mg orchestrated immune dysregulation and setting the stage for chronic infection due to excessive activation and recruitment of inflammatory cells infiltrates in the chicken trachea, which results in lesions of various severities in chicken trachea [9,10]. Although studies reported that cytokines play a crucial role in the proliferation and activation of these cells and chemokines are involved in recruiting leukocytes to the sites of bacterial infection [2,11,12], but the detail molecular mechanism behind the recruitment and activation of these cells still remain unknown.
response: Mycoplasma gallisepticum (Mg) is an avian pathogen that causes infectious sinusitis in turkeys and chronic respiratory disease in chickens, resulting in major poultry-industry losses through poor carcass quality and reduced egg production and hatchability. Mg adheres to mucosal epithelial cells, colonizes the host, and triggers strong inflammatory responses; infected birds often remain lifelong carriers that can spread infection to other birds and facilities. Mg also promotes immune dysregulation and chronic infection by excessive activation and recruitment of inflammatory cell infiltrates in the chicken trachea, causing tracheal lesions of varying severity. While cytokines and chemokines are implicated in inflammatory cell activation/proliferation and leukocyte recruitment, the detailed molecular mechanisms driving these processes remain unclear.

query: Bacteria of the genus Salmonella can infect humans and animals. Two of the main pathogens of these genera infecting animals, and specifically poultry, are Salmonella enterica serovar Pollurum (S. Pullorum) and Salmonella enterica serovar Gallinarum (S. Gallinarum) [1]. Their economic impact in terms of loss in the poultry sector is due to their killing effect after infection. Both strains can cause death in up to $90\%$ of birds affected [1,2]. Another example is Salmonella enterica serovar Enteritidis (S. Enteritidis), which can infect humans through consumption of contaminated meat and eggs. At the same time, poultry infected with S. Enteritidis infect their healthy neighbors contributing to further economic loss. S. Enteritidis is one of the main foodborne pathogens responsible for spreading Salmonella in humans, representing a public health issue [3,4]. The indiscriminate use of antibiotics as growth promoters for weight gain in poultry contributed to the spread of antibiotic-resistant microorganisms in humans and has prompted the prohibition of antibiotics in the poultry sector, so bacteriophages or phages (viruses that infect and lyse bacteria) have emerged as a strategy bio-control of Salmonella. This can include applications intended to limit the spread of the bacterium or directly for the treatment of salmonellosis in poultry, an approach known as phage therapy [5-12].
response: Salmonella bacteria infect humans and animals; in poultry, two major pathogens are *Salmonella enterica* serovar Pullorum (*S. Pullorum*) and serovar Gallinarum (*S. Gallinarum*), which cause major economic losses due to high mortality that can reach up to 90% of affected birds. Another important serovar is *S. Enteritidis*, which can infect humans via contaminated meat and eggs and also spreads between poultry, adding further economic loss; it is a leading foodborne Salmonella pathogen and a public health concern. Indiscriminate antibiotic use as poultry growth promoters promoted antibiotic-resistant microorganisms in humans and led to antibiotic bans in the poultry sector, motivating the use of bacteriophages (phages) as a biocontrol strategy to limit Salmonella spread or treat poultry salmonellosis (phage therapy).

query: most common infectious ocular disease of sheep. It is called ‘pink eye’ in the UK and ‘contagious ophthalmia’ in other parts of the world. The cause can be either Mycoplasma conjunctivae or Chlamydophila psittaci, or it may be a combination of both. Sheep can get ocular disease in outbreaks of abortion caused by C. psittaci. Equally, C. psittaci can be isolated as a cause of the abortion and there is no ocular disease. There is no doubt that there is a crossover infection between sheep and goats as C. psittaci occurs in wild sheep and goats which act as a reservoir for the infection throughout the world. It is possible that deer may be the reservoir in the UK. Other bacteria causing the disease may be opportunist pathogens; these include E. coli, Moraxella (Branhamella) ovis and S. aureus. Regardless of the cause of the disease, it always shows a sequential pathogenesis. As many animals are likely to be affected, the clinician will see all the phases at one time. Initially there will be inflammation of the sclera, blepharospasm and an increase in lachrymation. This will lead to corneal inflammation and opacity. There may or may not be corneal vascularization. Lastly, there will be corneal ulceration. Treatment is with antibiotic eye ointment. It is important that corticosteroids are not instilled at the same time. Antibiotics may also be given parenterally. Oxytetracyclines are ideal as they appear in the tears and have long-acting formulations. To help reduce the pain and the inflammation, NSAIDs can be given parenterally.
response: The most common infectious ocular disease of sheep (“pink eye” in the UK; “contagious ophthalmia” elsewhere) is caused by *Mycoplasma conjunctivae* and/or *Chlamydophila psittaci*. It may be associated with outbreaks of abortion due to *C. psittaci*, though abortion can also occur without ocular disease. There is cross-species transmission between sheep and goats, with wild sheep and goats acting as global reservoirs; deer may be a UK reservoir. Opportunist bacteria such as *E. coli*, *Moraxella (Branhamella) ovis*, and *Staphylococcus aureus* can also be involved. The disease follows a consistent sequence: scleral inflammation with blepharospasm and increased tearing, progressing to corneal inflammation and opacity (with or without vascularization), and finally corneal ulceration; in outbreaks, different stages are seen simultaneously in different animals. Treatment is antibiotic eye ointment (avoid concurrent corticosteroids), sometimes with parenteral antibiotics—oxytetracyclines are preferred because they reach tears and have long-acting forms—and parenteral NSAIDs for pain and inflammation.

query: Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA), which can harbor mecA, or recently discovered mecC gene, are resistant to both cefoxitin and oxacillin (Chambers, 1997; Shore and Coleman, 2013). Borderline oxacillin-resistant S. aureus (BORSA) is another, relatively frequent phenotype among S. aureus. Borderline oxacillin-resistant S. aureus are cefoxitin susceptible, do not carry the mecA or mecC genes, but have oxacillin minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) between 1 and  $8\mu \mathrm{g / mL}$  (Chambers, 1997; Shore and Coleman, 2013). Hyperproduction of  $\beta$  -lactamase has been postulated to explain this phenomenon
response: Methicillin-resistant *S. aureus* (MRSA) carries the **mecA** gene or the recently discovered **mecC** gene and is **resistant to both cefoxitin and oxacillin**. In contrast, borderline oxacillin-resistant *S. aureus* (BORSA) is a relatively frequent phenotype that is **susceptible to cefoxitin**, **lacks mecA and mecC**, but shows **oxacillin MICs of 1–8 μg/mL**. **Hyperproduction of β-lactamase** has been proposed as a possible explanation for the BORSA phenotype.

query: Although all NDV isolates belong to a single serotype, the viruses are genetically and antigenically diverse. Based on genetic differences, NDV are currently classified in two major groups (class I and class II) (Czegledi et al., 2006), and the class II viruses have higher genetic and virulence variability and are known to infect a wide range of domestic and wild birds. They are divided into at least 18 genotypes (named I to XVIII), and vNDV belonging to multiple class II genotypes are identified in poultry outbreaks worldwide (Dimitrov et al., 2016). vNDV from different genotypes are often identified in wild birds, and the latter have been speculated to play a role in the spread of the virus (Snoeck et al., 2013). However, it is suggested that most of the wild bird isolations are a result of spillover of virus from infected poultry (Miller and Koch, 2013). Notably, there are two known exceptions where virulent viruses are endemic in wild birds. Birds of the family Columbidae are known to be a reservoir of the antigenic variants of vNDV, commonly referred to as pigeon paramyxoviruses 1 (PPMV-1). These pigeon-origin viruses are distributed worldwide, are commonly isolated from both wild and domestic pigeons, and are highly virulent for these species (Ujvari et al., 2003). The second group of viruses are endemic in some species of the genus Phalacrocorax (cormorant populations) in North America and are associated with periodic mortality events (Banerjee et al., 1994). Both groups of viruses have the potential to infect other avian species but appear to be highly adapted to pigeons and cormorants, respectively, and are rarely implicated with infections in poultry.
response: Although all Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates are a single serotype, they show substantial genetic and antigenic diversity and are classified into two major genetic groups (class I and class II). Class II viruses have greater genetic and virulence variability, infect many domestic and wild bird species, and are divided into at least 18 genotypes (I–XVIII); virulent NDV (vNDV) from multiple class II genotypes causes poultry outbreaks worldwide. vNDV of various genotypes is often detected in wild birds, which may contribute to spread, though most wild-bird detections are suggested to result from spillover from infected poultry. Two exceptions involve virulent viruses endemic in wild birds: (1) Columbidae (pigeons) as reservoirs of antigenic variant vNDV known as pigeon paramyxovirus 1 (PPMV-1), found worldwide, common in wild and domestic pigeons, and highly virulent for them; and (2) viruses endemic in some North American cormorants (Phalacrocorax), linked to periodic mortality events. Both groups can infect other birds but are highly adapted to pigeons or cormorants and rarely cause poultry infections.

query: Sex determination in chickens is primarily controlled by the genetic makeup of sex chromosomes (Clinton, 1998; Clinton et al., 2012; Kuroiwa, 2017; Smith, Major & Estermann, 2021; Smith & Sinclair, 2004). There are 39 pairs of chromosomes in chicken somatic cells, consisting of 38 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes. Unlike mammals, avians use a ZZ:ZW heteromorphic sex chromosome system, where females have ZW heterologous sex chromosomes and males have ZZ homologous chromosomes (Ellegren, 2009; Gilgenkrantz, 2004; Graves, 2016; Nanda et al., 2008; Smith & Sinclair, 2004). The expression of the Z-linked gene Dmrt1 plays a crucial role in sex determination in chickens, and this sex-determination mechanism is conserved in birds (Smith et al., 2009).
response: Sex determination in chickens is mainly controlled by sex chromosomes. Chicken somatic cells have 39 chromosome pairs: 38 autosome pairs and one sex-chromosome pair. Birds use a ZZ/ZW system unlike mammals: females are ZW (heterologous) and males are ZZ (homologous). Expression of the Z-linked gene **Dmrt1** is crucial for chicken sex determination, and this mechanism is conserved across birds.

query: Chicken infectious anemia virus (CIAV) is an economically important pathogen that has been commonly identified in chicken populations worldwide since it was first discovered in Japan in 1979 from contaminated vaccines (Yuasa et al., 1979). CIAV can cause the atrophy of bone marrow hematopoietic tissue and lymphatic tissues (e.g., thymus) in young chickens, leading to anemia and immune suppression (Taniguchi et al., 1982). CIAV is important both clinically and subclinically and can be spread both horizontally and vertically (Jorgensen et al., 1995; Todd, 2000).
response: Chicken infectious anemia virus (CIAV) is a globally prevalent, economically important chicken pathogen first identified in Japan in 1979 from contaminated vaccines. In young chickens, it causes atrophy of bone marrow hematopoietic tissue and lymphatic tissues (e.g., thymus), leading to anemia and immunosuppression. CIAV has both clinical and subclinical significance and can spread through both horizontal and vertical transmission.

query: Several lines of evidence revealed that the ancestors of modern chickens arose out of South and Southeast Asia. Chicken mitochondrial DNA sequence indicated that the domestic chicken breeds have descent from the red jungle fowls (Gallus gallus gallus) in Southeast Asia [1,2]. Hillel et al. [3] showed by using microsatellite data that the red jungle fowls were the main progenitor and the major contributor of the domestic chicken gene pool. Furthermore, the domestic chickens have multiple maternal origins that occurred in South and Southeast Asia in area ranging from India, South China, Myanmar, Vietnam and Thailand [4].
response: Several lines of evidence indicate that modern domestic chickens originated in South and Southeast Asia. Mitochondrial DNA data show that domestic chicken breeds descend from the red jungle fowl (Gallus gallus gallus) in Southeast Asia, and microsatellite analyses identify red jungle fowl as the main progenitor and major contributor to the domestic chicken gene pool. Additionally, domestic chickens have multiple maternal origins across South and Southeast Asia, including regions spanning India, South China, Myanmar, Vietnam, and Thailand.

query: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor (TRAF) family members (TRAF1-7) are intracellular signal transducers involved in inflammation and include immune receptor superfamilies, such as the tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) superfamily and interleukin-1 receptor/Toll-like receptor (IL-1/TLR) family members (Inoue et al., 2000). All TRAFs have a similar protein structure, an N-terminal region, and C-terminal TRAF domain (Rothe et al., 1994). The N-terminal contains a RING-finger domain and a series of five Zn-finger domains, which mediate protein ubiquitylation and activation of downstream signaling (Yang et al., 2015). The TRAF domain is comprised of a coiled-coil TRAF-N domain and a conserved TRAF-C domain, which is involved in self-association (Rothe et al., 1994) and interaction with various upstream regulators or downstream effectors (Zheng et al., 2010). TRAF6 was originally isolated by yeast two-hybrid screening using CD40 as bait (Ishida et al., 1996), and independently by screening of an expressed sequence tag (EST) library (Cao et al., 1996), and has been identified as a critical element for IL-1/TLR signaling. TRAF6 is the only TRAF family member that participates in both TNFR superfamily signaling pathways and TLR/IL-1R superfamily pathways (Chung et al., 2002).
response: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors (TRAF1–7) are intracellular signal transducers involved in inflammation and function in signaling from immune receptor superfamilies, including the TNF receptor (TNFR) superfamily and the interleukin-1 receptor/Toll-like receptor (IL-1/TLR) family. TRAFs share a common structure with an N-terminal region containing a RING-finger domain and five Zn-finger domains that mediate protein ubiquitylation and downstream signaling activation, and a C-terminal TRAF domain composed of a coiled-coil TRAF-N and a conserved TRAF-C domain responsible for self-association and interactions with upstream regulators and downstream effectors. TRAF6 was originally identified via yeast two-hybrid screening using CD40 and independently through EST library screening; it is a key component of IL-1/TLR signaling and uniquely participates in both TNFR and TLR/IL-1R signaling pathways.

query: The IFITM3 protein is localized in the late endosome to prevent viral invasion (Feeley et al. 2011). For this reason, the IFITM3 protein has a conserved sorting signal that is needed to enter the endosomal pathway. This signal peptide domain, referred to as Yxxφ, a tyrosine-based lysosomal targeting motif, is located in the N-terminal domain (NTD) of the IFITM3 protein (Jia et al. 2014). This signal peptide is conserved in species including mammals and birds and is used as classification criteria between IFITM1 and IFITM3 proteins, because these two proteins share a highly similar protein sequence (Wang et al. 2017). Mutagenesis of the Yxxφ domain augmented mislocalization of the IFITM3 protein and reduced its antiviral capacity in mammals (Jia et al. 2012). However, in a recent study performed in ducks, the Yxxφ domain was not essential for correct localization of the IFITM3 protein and did not affect antiviral capacity (Blyth et al. 2015). Although mammals and birds share a very similar protein structure called CD225, which is significantly associated with antiviral ability, birds do not likely depend on the YxxΦ domain for correct IFITM3 protein localization.
response: IFITM3 is localized in late endosomes to block viral invasion and therefore contains a conserved endosomal sorting signal. This signal is a tyrosine-based lysosomal targeting motif (Yxxφ) located in the N-terminal domain (NTD), conserved across mammals and birds, and used to distinguish IFITM1 from IFITM3 because their sequences are highly similar. In mammals, mutating the Yxxφ motif causes IFITM3 mislocalization and reduces antiviral activity. In ducks, however, the Yxxφ motif is not required for proper IFITM3 localization and does not affect antiviral capacity, suggesting that although mammals and birds share the antiviral-associated CD225 structure, birds likely do not rely on YxxΦ for IFITM3 localization.

query: Necrotic enteritis (NE) is a widespread disease caused by abnormal increase of Clostridium perfringens (CP) colonization in the chicken intestinal tract. It costs the US poultry industry  $>$  6 billion annually (Wade and Keyburn, 2015). Eimeria spp. are a known predisposing factor for NE, which spreads rapidly because of high-intensity breeding in modern farming systems (Lee et al., 2018). Particularly, co-infection with Eimeria maxima (EM) has been strongly implicated in promoting NE. CP is a Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming and rod-shaped bacterium. It is ubiquitous in nature and can be found as a normal component of soil, contaminated food, decaying vegetation, and marine sediments, and has been identified as a normal bacterium in various bird species (Li et al., 2017; Lyhs et al., 2013; Crespo et al., 2007).
response: Necrotic enteritis (NE) is a widespread chicken disease caused by an abnormal increase of *Clostridium perfringens* (CP) colonization in the intestinal tract, costing the US poultry industry over $6 billion annually. *Eimeria* spp. are a known predisposing factor, and NE spreads rapidly due to high-intensity breeding in modern farming systems; co-infection with *Eimeria maxima* is particularly strongly implicated in promoting NE. CP is a Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming, rod-shaped bacterium that is ubiquitous in nature (soil, contaminated food, decaying vegetation, marine sediments) and is also a normal bacterium in various bird species.

query: The chicken body louse is an obligate ectoparasite found on chickens and related poultry. These lice complete their entire 2-3-week life cycle on their chicken host [11], feeding on feathers and occasionally blood [12]. Chicken body louse infestations have been linked to decreased hen weight, egg production, and feed conversion [13]
response: The chicken body louse is an obligate ectoparasite of chickens and related poultry that completes its entire 2–3 week life cycle on the host. It feeds on feathers and occasionally blood, and infestations are associated with reduced hen weight, decreased egg production, and poorer feed conversion.

query: The chicken is a natural host for influenza A virus (FLUAV), and ongoing influenza outbreaks in poultry demonstrate both the economical relevance and the zoonotic threat for humans. Type I interferons (IFN) play an essential role in the innate host immune response against influenza viruses. The antiviral effect of IFN was first described in chicken embryos (15, 16) and later confirmed in many other species. Studies of mice revealed that the IFN-induced myxovirus resistance protein 1 (Mx1) is the main effector molecule of the IFN-induced antiviral state against FLUAV. Mouse strains carrying a functional $Mx1$ gene are highly resistant to infection with influenza viruses (23). In contrast, most of the laboratory mouse strains have a defective $Mx1$ gene and consequently are highly susceptible to FLUAV infection (40).
response: Chickens are natural hosts for influenza A virus (FLUAV), and ongoing poultry outbreaks highlight both major economic impact and zoonotic risk to humans. Type I interferons (IFN) are crucial for the innate immune response against influenza viruses; their antiviral effect was first shown in chicken embryos and later confirmed in other species. In mice, the IFN-induced myxovirus resistance protein 1 (Mx1) is the key effector of IFN-mediated antiviral protection against FLUAV: mouse strains with a functional **Mx1** gene are highly resistant to influenza infection, whereas most laboratory mouse strains carry a defective **Mx1** gene and are therefore highly susceptible.

query: Chagas disease or American trypanosomiasis is a zoonotic disease caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which can infect humans as well as domestic and wild animals (Galvao and Justi, 2015). This parasite is transmitted by triatomine vectors of the order Hemiptera, family Reduviidae, and subfamily Triatominae. They are hematophagous and primarily nocturnal insects that feed on the blood of humans, and of wild and domestic animals (Zeledón et al., 2016). Chagas disease occurs primarily in Latin America, where it is endemic. In endemic countries it is recommended to routinely evaluate dogs, which are one of the principal domestic hosts. Under natural conditions dogs are infected more frequently than humans, making it possible to use them as sentinels to estimate the risk of infection in humans
response: Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) is a zoonotic infection caused by the protozoan *Trypanosoma cruzi* that affects humans and domestic and wild animals. It is transmitted by blood-feeding, primarily nocturnal triatomine bugs (Hemiptera: Reduviidae: Triatominae). The disease is mainly endemic in Latin America; in endemic countries, routine evaluation of dogs is recommended because dogs are major domestic hosts, are infected more often than humans under natural conditions, and can serve as sentinels to estimate human infection risk.

query: The chicken lysozyme gene is specifically expressed in the oviduct constitutively in mature hens and inducibly in immature female chicks by steroid hormones (1). In addition to the oviduct, this gene has been expressed in macrophages and its expression was enhanced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS), although at a lower level than that in the oviduct (2,3). In the upstream region of the coding sequence, several regulatory regions that were sensitive to DNase I digestion (DNase I hypersensitive sites; DHSs) were identified  $-6.1$ ,  $-3.9$ ,  $-2.7$ ,  $-2.4$ ,  $-1.9$ ,  $-0.7$ , and  $-0.1$  kb upstream of the transcriptional start site (4,5). Among them, DHSs at  $-0.1$  and  $-1.9$  kb were detected in the oviduct and regarded as hormone-responsive enhancers (6,7), while those at  $-3.9$ ,  $-2.7$ , and  $-0.7$  kb were macrophage-specific enhancers (8). A silencer was also identified at  $-2.4$  kb, to which the CCCTC-binding factor (CTCF protein) bound (9), both in lysozyme-expressing and non-expressing cells, except for activated macrophages (2). The stimulation of macrophages with LPS induced the transient synthesis of a non-coding RNA, which resulted in the eviction of the CTCF protein from the silencer to up-regulate the transcription of the lysozyme gene (3).
response: The chicken lysozyme gene is constitutively expressed in the oviduct of mature hens and is inducible by steroid hormones in immature female chicks. It is also expressed in macrophages at lower levels, where expression is enhanced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Multiple DNase I hypersensitive regulatory sites occur upstream of the transcription start site at −6.1, −3.9, −2.7, −2.4, −1.9, −0.7, and −0.1 kb: the −0.1 and −1.9 kb sites act as hormone-responsive enhancers in the oviduct, while the −3.9, −2.7, and −0.7 kb sites are macrophage-specific enhancers. A silencer at −2.4 kb binds CTCF in both expressing and non-expressing cells except activated macrophages; LPS stimulation triggers transient non-coding RNA production that evicts CTCF from this silencer, increasing lysozyme gene transcription.

query: Myoglobin and free hemoglobin impart a reddish color to the urine that does not clear with settling or centrifugation (Figure 8a,b). Both pigments can turn darker over time, while the sample awaits analysis, but myoglobin more consistently turns reddish-­brown to brown in color [2]. In this situation, the reagent pad will be positive for occult blood (see Chapter 5), but intact erythrocytes are not seen in the urinary sediment. In patients with hemoglobinuria, the serum will be pink owing to hemoglobin binding to haptoglobin. Myoglobin has no carrier protein, and its presence does not result in discoloration of serum because it is rapidly cleared from the circulation. A simple screening test using ammonium sulfate can discriminate between myoglobin and hemoglobin in urine. Myoglobin in urine largely stays in solution when exposed to 80% saturation of urine with ammonium sulfate, whereas hemoglobin is completely precipitated [16]. Although evaluation of serum color and use of ammonium sulfate precipitation testing can presumptively distinguish between hemoglobinuria and myoglobinuria, definitive differentiation requires urinary protein electrophoresis. Myoglobinuria probably occurs more commonly than diagnosed because it is easily confused with hemoglobinuria. Myoglobinuria sometimes is observed with exertional rhabdomyolysis in horses and dogs, and during postanesthetic rhabdomyolysis in horses [17–19]. Porphyrins in urine turn red after oxidation of porphobilinogen. This color intensifies upon standing and often is described as red or port wine [3]. The color of the urine supernatant does not change after centrifugation. In cats, porphyrinuria has been described as imparting an orange–brown color to urine that becomes orange–pink during fluorescence. Teeth of affected cats are also discolored with an orange–brown shade and undergo red fluorescence [20–23]. Intermittent porphyria and congenital erythropoietic porphyria have been described in cats [23]. Rabbits often can have red urine as a result of ingesting porphyrins in cabbage, carrots, dandelions, parsley or broccoli, and this red color can be a normal finding [24]. King George III of England (1738–1820) reportedly had urine that was blue as a consequence of hereditary intermittent porphyria [25].
response:
Myoglobinuria and hemoglobinuria both cause red urine that does not clear with settling or centrifugation; the dipstick is positive for occult blood but no intact RBCs are seen in sediment. Both darken over time, with myoglobin more consistently becoming reddish-brown to brown. Hemoglobinuria can make serum pink due to hemoglobin–haptoglobin binding, whereas myoglobin has no carrier, does not discolor serum, and is rapidly cleared. An ammonium sulfate screen (80% saturation) differentiates them: myoglobin remains largely in solution while hemoglobin precipitates; definitive distinction requires urinary protein electrophoresis. Myoglobinuria is likely underdiagnosed and may occur with exertional rhabdomyolysis (horses, dogs) and postanesthetic rhabdomyolysis (horses).  

Porphyrins can also redden urine after porphobilinogen oxidation; the red/“port wine” color intensifies on standing and remains after centrifugation. In cats, porphyrinuria may appear orange-brown and fluoresce orange-pink, with similarly discolored, red-fluorescing teeth; intermittent and congenital erythropoietic porphyria are reported. Rabbits may normally have red urine from dietary porphyrins (e.g., cabbage, carrots, dandelion, parsley, broccoli). King George III was reported to have blue urine associated with hereditary intermittent porphyria.

query: Biomechanical cervical spine models have been used extensively to evaluate feasibility and potential side effects of surgical procedures and instrumentation as it is currently not feasible to directly measure spinal loading in-vivo (Jaeger et al., 2011). Theoretical and numerical biomechanical models of the human cervical spine have been developed over the last three decades to investigate kinetics and kinematics of the neck (Dugailly et al., 2011). However, these models have not been translated to the canine cervical spine in spite of the high incidence of spinal disorders and injuries (Jeffery et al., 2013). Successful development and implementation of these models in canine spinal studies would require accurate anatomical data of the underlying soft tissues and bone (Sharir et al., 2006). Among the many components which should be incorporated into a model, muscles play a vital role in stability, loading and locomotion as they exert the majority of the required moments to maintain equilibrium in different postures and to perform various tasks (Nussbaum et al., 1995; Vasavada et al., 1998). Studies have shown the substantial effect of muscle forces on cervical spine kinematics and injury potential on the neck structure (Borst et al., 2011). To this extent, comprehensive knowledge of canine muscle properties including estimation of muscle forces and orientation has yet to be established.
response: Biomechanical models of the human cervical spine are widely used to assess the feasibility and potential side effects of surgeries and instrumentation because direct in-vivo measurement of spinal loading is not currently feasible. Over the past three decades, theoretical and numerical human cervical spine models have been developed to study neck kinetics and kinematics, but similar models have not been translated to the canine cervical spine despite the high incidence of canine spinal disorders and injuries. Developing canine models would require accurate anatomical data for soft tissues and bone. Muscles are especially important to include because they are crucial for stability, loading, and locomotion, providing most of the moments needed for posture and task performance, and muscle forces substantially affect cervical spine kinematics and neck injury potential. However, comprehensive knowledge of canine muscle properties—particularly muscle force estimates and orientations—remains lacking.

query: A recent genome-wide level evolutionary study shows a sister relationship between the Grey and the Ceylon junglefowls, with a common ancestor of $\sim 1.8$ mya. It also indicates a common ancestor between the Red junglefowl and these two species of $\sim 2.6$ to $2.9$ mya and that the Green junglefowl is the oldest Gallus lineage with a divergence time of $\sim 4$ mya (Lawal et al. 2020). This phylogeny, (see also Tiley et al. 2020), differs from most of the previous ones inferred from short nuclear genome fragments and mitochondria DNA (mtDNA), which rather support a sister relationship between the Grey and the Red junglefowls (e.g. Eo et al. 2009; Li et al. 2015) or between the Green and the Red junglefowls (e.g. Jetz et al. 2012). It also differs from other alternative topologies including the placement of Red junglefowl at the basal of the Gallus tree (Fig. 2). Interestingly, the species relationship of topology T9, also highly supported in Lawal et al. (2020), is the one favoured in the recent genome-wide study of Mariassou et al. (2020). The dating of shared ancestry between the species lineages is also uncertain, with more ancient divergence times than those in Lawal et al. (2020), reported in other studies.
response: A recent genome-wide evolutionary study finds Grey and Ceylon junglefowls as sister species with a common ancestor ~1.8 million years ago, Red junglefowl sharing a common ancestor with them ~2.6–2.9 million years ago, and Green junglefowl as the oldest Gallus lineage diverging ~4 million years ago. This phylogeny differs from earlier trees based on short nuclear fragments and mtDNA, which often paired Grey with Red or Green with Red, and from other proposed topologies such as placing Red junglefowl as basal. The topology (T9) strongly supported in Lawal et al. (2020) is also favored by Mariassou et al. (2020). Divergence-time estimates remain uncertain, with some studies suggesting older splits than Lawal et al. (2020).

query: Several interferon (IFN)-inducible transmembrane protein (IFITM) family proteins (IFITM1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 for humans, and 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 10 for mice) have been identified in humans and mice.  ${ }^{1,2)}$  IFITM1, 2, and 3 block viral replication by preventing the fusion of virus and host-cell membranes, thereby restricting numerous pathogenic viruses including influenza A virus and Ebola virus.  ${ }^{1,2)}$  Since influenza viruses prevail on a worldwide scale in chickens, with the potential for a pandemic, chicken IFITMs have recently been studied. To date, IFITM1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 have been detected in chickens. A previous study reported that chicken IFITM3 restricted infections by influenza virus and lyssavirus in vitro. $^{3)}$  We also found that chicken IFITM3 prevented infections by a vesicular stomatitis virus G protein (VSV-G)-pseudotyped lentivirus, which has been used as a viral vector for gene transfer. $^{4)}$
response: Interferon-inducible transmembrane proteins (IFITMs) have been identified as IFITM1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 in humans and IFITM1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 10 in mice. IFITM1–3 inhibit viral replication by blocking fusion between viral and host-cell membranes, restricting many pathogenic viruses such as influenza A virus and Ebola virus. Because influenza viruses are widespread in chickens and pose pandemic potential, chicken IFITMs have been investigated; IFITM1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 have been detected in chickens. Prior work showed chicken IFITM3 restricts influenza virus and lyssavirus infections in vitro, and the authors also found chicken IFITM3 inhibits infection by a VSV-G–pseudotyped lentivirus used as a gene-transfer vector.

query: In dogs, cancers develop spontaneously at rates comparable to or greater than in humans. Lymphomas for example, may occur in dogs at incident rates of 13-100 per 100,000 cases, sharing similarity with non-Hodgkin lymphoma in humans (Zandvliet, 2016). In general, cancers in humans and dogs share features such as histologic appearance, tumour genetics, biological behaviour, molecular target presentation, therapeutic response and primary and metastatic microenvironments (Gordon et al., 2009). Several breeds of dogs are genetically predisposed to spontaneous diseases of haematologic origin and can be considered good candidates for HCT therapy.
response: Cancers in dogs develop spontaneously at rates comparable to or higher than in humans; for example, canine lymphoma occurs at about 13–100 cases per 100,000 and is similar to human non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Cancers in humans and dogs share key features including histologic appearance, tumour genetics, biological behaviour, molecular target presentation, therapeutic response, and primary/metastatic microenvironments. Additionally, some dog breeds are genetically predisposed to spontaneous haematologic diseases, making them good candidates for HCT therapy.

query: Canine distemper virus (CDV) is a highly infectious and an acknowledged lethal pathogen of wild and domestic carnivores. CDV belongs to the genus Morbillivirus of the family Paramyxoviridae, has a lipid envelope that contains non-segmented single stranded RNA genome of negative polarity which encodes for two surface glycoproteins (the hemoagglutinin H and the fusion protein F), the viral matrix protein (M), the nucleocapsid protein (N), the phosphoprotein (P) and the large RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L) (Sidhu et al., 1993). The replicative complex of paramyxoviruses, critical for both transcription and replication, is tripartite being formed by N-P-L proteins and is considered a promising target for the establishment of an effective antiviral chemotherapy (Bourhis et al., 2006).
response: Canine distemper virus (CDV) is a highly infectious, often lethal pathogen of wild and domestic carnivores. It is a Morbillivirus in the family Paramyxoviridae, and is an enveloped virus with a non-segmented, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA genome encoding two surface glycoproteins (hemagglutinin H and fusion protein F) plus M, N, P, and the large RNA-dependent RNA polymerase L proteins. Its replication/transcription machinery is a tripartite N–P–L complex, which is considered a promising target for antiviral chemotherapy.

query: The insulin-like growth factor receptor type 2 (IGF2R) sequesters the insulin-like growth factor (IGF-II) for internalization and degradation and also is considered a tumor suppressor with mutations being found in several cancers [23]. Unusually high levels of circulating IGF-II and simultaneous downregulation of IGF2R are correlated with the growth of human and murine tumors [24,25] while loss of function of IGF2R resulting in increased growth [26]. A recent publication has shown the consistent surface overexpression of IGF2R in human OS [27]. It was also previously found that a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) which alters methylation in an IGF2R CpG island was associated with an increased risk of OS development in humans [28]. Taken together, IGF2R expression appears to be both essential to and associated with the development of OS, making it an ideal therapeutic target. Sequence alignment of the IGFII binding region (Domains 11-FNII) in human, mouse, and dog have been demonstrated to be highly conserved (82% sequence identity) across these species [29].
response: The insulin-like growth factor receptor type 2 (IGF2R) binds and sequesters IGF-II for internalization and degradation and is also considered a tumor suppressor, with mutations found in several cancers. High circulating IGF-II together with IGF2R downregulation correlates with growth of human and mouse tumors, and IGF2R loss of function increases growth. In human osteosarcoma (OS), IGF2R has been reported to be consistently overexpressed on the cell surface, and a SNP affecting methylation in an IGF2R CpG island is associated with increased OS risk. Overall, IGF2R appears essential and linked to OS development, making it a promising therapeutic target, and its IGF-II binding region (Domains 11–FNII) is highly conserved across human, mouse, and dog (~82% sequence identity).

query: Core temperature is considered the gold standard of body temperature, as it closely reflects the temperature of the internal organs (Allegaert et al., 2014). The temperature at the hypothalamus is also a desired location to monitor, as this region is where body temperature is perceived (Cichocki et al., 2017). However, clinically, the most conventional method of taking a canine's temperature is through the rectal mucosa, as it continues to be a minimally invasive method that provides insight to core temperature (Kreissl and Neiger, 2015). Rectal thermometers have drawbacks, as they cannot be easily used on aggressive canids or ones with an infection or rupture of the anal mucosa (Kreissl and Neiger, 2015). To bypass the limitations caused by rectal temperatures, studies have been done using non - contact infrared (IR) thermometers, and focusing on alternative areas such as the axilla, auricular canal, and ocular regions of the canine (Gomart et al., 2014, Zanghi, 2016).
response: Core temperature best reflects internal organ temperature and is considered the gold standard, and hypothalamic temperature is also desirable because it is where body temperature is perceived. Clinically, canine temperature is most commonly measured via the rectal mucosa because it is minimally invasive and provides insight into core temperature, but rectal thermometers are difficult to use in aggressive dogs or when the anal mucosa is infected or ruptured. To overcome these limitations, studies have explored non-contact infrared thermometers at alternative sites such as the axilla, ear canal, and ocular regions.

query: KIT isoforms resulting from alternative splicing of  $c$ -kit transcripts are characterized by the presence or absence of four amino acids. $^{8}$  These four amino acids are denoted as GNNK (glycine, asparagine, asparagine and lysine) or GNSK (glycine, asparagine, serine and lysine) at exon 9 of  $c$ -kit in humans and dogs, respectively. $^{9}$  In humans, both isoforms differ greatly in biological activities, such as loss of contact inhibition, anchorage-independent growth and potential tumourigenicity, which are mainly induced by KIT with deletion of GNNK. $^{10}$  In addition, GNNK $^{-}$  dominates over the GNNK $^{+}$  isoform in phosphorylation and internalization despite the fact that the affinity for SCF is identical between both isoforms. $^{11}$  Different signal transduction pathways are induced according to the cell types. Stronger activation of the extracellular regulated kinase was demonstrated in GNNK $^{-}$  transformed NIH3T3 fibroblasts. $^{10}$  Additionally, a higher level of Akt and Gab2 phosphorylation was detected in B cell myeloma Ba/F3 cells expressing the GNNK $^{-}$  isoform. $^{12}$
response: KIT isoforms produced by alternative splicing of *c-kit* transcripts differ by the presence or absence of four amino acids at exon 9: GNNK (in humans) or GNSK (in dogs). In humans, the two isoforms show major functional differences, with the GNNK-deleted (GNNK⁻) form mainly driving effects such as loss of contact inhibition, anchorage-independent growth, and potential tumorigenicity. Although both isoforms have identical affinity for SCF, GNNK⁻ shows dominant phosphorylation and internalization compared with GNNK⁺. Signaling differences are cell-type dependent: GNNK⁻ more strongly activates ERK in transformed NIH3T3 fibroblasts and produces higher Akt and Gab2 phosphorylation in Ba/F3 myeloma cells.

query: Endotoxin or lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. Endotoxin exposure is a causative agent or contributing factor for various pulmonary illnesses including asthma, organic dust toxic syndrome, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease that affect human subjects including animal husbandry workers [1,3,10,12,17,19,22]. Endotoxin exposure initiates type 2 helper T cell (Th2)-mediated immune reactions resulting in respiratory allergic hyper-reactivity. Few studies have been performed to assess the effects of endotoxin exposure on immunity of livestock. LPS administration through intravenous injection into 7- to 8-month old chickens was reported to rapidly reduce the number of monocytes in peripheral blood and macrophages in the spleen; these values returned to control levels at 6 to  $24\mathrm{h}$  post-LPS injection [2]. In addition, 8-week old chickens intravenously injected with LPS had lower antibody titers following infectious bronchitis virus vaccination compared to the control group [20]. Up-regulated expression of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes such as interleukin (IL)-1 $\beta$ s, IL-6, and IL-8 was also observed in chicken heterophils in the presence of LPS in vitro [11]. Aside from these studies, few systemic investigations have been performed on the modulation of chicken immunity through endotoxin exposure via the indoor environment of chicken farms.
response: Endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide, LPS) is a component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. Exposure to endotoxin contributes to or causes several human pulmonary diseases (including asthma, organic dust toxic syndrome, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), notably affecting animal husbandry workers, and it can trigger Th2-mediated immune responses leading to respiratory allergic hyper-reactivity. In livestock, limited research exists: in 7–8 month old chickens, intravenous LPS rapidly decreased peripheral blood monocytes and splenic macrophages, returning to normal within 6–24 hours; in 8-week old chickens, intravenous LPS reduced antibody titers after infectious bronchitis virus vaccination compared with controls; and in vitro LPS exposure upregulated pro-inflammatory cytokine genes (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8) in chicken heterophils. Overall, few systemic studies have examined how endotoxin exposure in indoor chicken farm environments modulates chicken immunity.

query: Canine medical scent detection appears more promising for infectious diseases than non-infectious diseases such as cancer, diabetes mellitus and epileptic seizures. Despite some initially promising medical dog scent detection studies, published data can vary significantly for the identification of cancer. Studies with trained sniffer dogs achieved very different results in the identification of different cancer types, such as bladder, prostate or ovarian cancer, lung and breast cancer as well as colorectal neoplasms. Diagnostic accuracies varied with sensitivities ranging from 19 to  $99\%$  and specificities from 73 to  $99\%$  when compared to histopathology [8-17]. Different sample materials were used for presentation, e.g. urine, blood, breath or faeces, which could explain the variability in findings. Another influencing factor that plays a role regarding the variability of the results is the lack of standardisation of training and the trainer bias, which may have a major influence on the training results
response: Canine medical scent detection may be more promising for infectious than non-infectious diseases (e.g., cancer, diabetes, epileptic seizures). However, published results for cancer detection are highly variable: trained dogs have shown widely differing performance across cancer types (including bladder, prostate, ovarian, lung, breast, and colorectal neoplasms), with sensitivities ranging from 19–99% and specificities from 73–99% versus histopathology. Variability may stem from differences in sample materials used (urine, blood, breath, faeces) and from lack of standardized training methods and potential trainer bias, which can strongly affect outcomes.

query: CMTs have heterogeneous morphology and biology which makes it difficult to choose the most appropriate biomarker for its diagnosis. The tumors are usually noticed by owners when there are visible macroscopic changes in the mammary gland. Determination of tumor biomarker for CMT can be a milestone for early diagnosis of the disease in dogs which can help evaluate the progress of the disease and its response to chemotherapy (Kaszak et al. 2018). Serum tumor markers play an important role in screening, early diagnosis of the disease, and its recurrence, and help in deciding the treatment of many malignancies (Dai et al. 2013; Incoronato et al. 2014). Canine carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and cancer antigen (CA 15-3) are the two most widely used serum tumor markers being used in the clinic for the diagnosis of human breast cancer for more than 30 years (Shao et al. 2015). Studies have shown that preoperative CEA levels combined with CA 15-3 levels may provide useful information for the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer (Lee et al. 2013; Pedersen et al. 2013).
response: Canine mammary tumors (CMTs) have heterogeneous morphology and biology, making it difficult to select an optimal diagnostic biomarker, and owners typically notice them only after visible macroscopic mammary gland changes. Identifying reliable tumor biomarkers could enable earlier diagnosis in dogs and help assess disease progression and response to chemotherapy. Serum tumor markers are important for screening, early diagnosis, detecting recurrence, and guiding treatment decisions in many cancers. The most widely used serum markers in clinical practice for human breast cancer for over 30 years are carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3), and evidence suggests that combining preoperative CEA with CA 15-3 levels can provide useful diagnostic and treatment information.

query: The chicken genome is one-third the size of the human genome and has a similarity of sixty percent when it comes to gene content. Harboring similar genome sequences, chickens' gene arrangement is closer to the human genomic organization than it is to rodents. Chickens have been used as model organisms to study evolution, epigenome, and diseases. The chicken nucleated erythrocyte's physiological function is to carry oxygen to the tissues and remove carbon dioxide. The erythrocyte also supports the innate immune response in protecting the chicken from pathogens. Among the highly studied aspects in the field of epigenetics are modifications of DNA, histones, and their variants. In understanding the organization of transcriptionally active chromatin, studies on the chicken nucleated erythrocyte have been important. Through the application of a variety of epigenomic approaches, we and others have determined the chromatin structure of expressed/poised genes involved in the physiological functions of the erythrocyte. As the chicken erythrocyte has a nucleus and is readily isolated from the animal, the chicken erythrocyte epigenome has been studied as a biomarker of an animal's long-term exposure to stress. In this review, epigenomic features that allow erythroid gene expression in a highly repressive chromatin background are presented.
response: The chicken genome is about one-third the size of the human genome and shares roughly 60% similarity in gene content; despite similar sequences, its gene arrangement is closer to humans than to rodents. Chickens are used as model organisms for studying evolution, the epigenome, and disease. Chicken nucleated erythrocytes primarily transport oxygen and remove carbon dioxide, and they also contribute to innate immune protection against pathogens. Epigenetics research focuses heavily on DNA and histone (and histone variant) modifications, and chicken nucleated erythrocytes have been important for understanding transcriptionally active chromatin organization. Using multiple epigenomic approaches, researchers have characterized chromatin structures at expressed/poised erythrocyte genes involved in physiological functions. Because chicken erythrocytes retain a nucleus and are easy to isolate, their epigenome has been studied as a biomarker of long-term stress exposure. The reviewed work presents epigenomic features that enable erythroid gene expression within an otherwise highly repressive chromatin environment.

query: Mitral valve competence requires complex interplay between structures that comprise the mitral apparatus – the mitral annulus, mitral valve leaflets, chordae tendineae, papillary muscles, and left atrial and left ventricular myocardium. Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is prevalent in the canine, and most adult dogs develop some degree of mitral valve disease as they age, highlighting the apparent vulnerability of canine heart valves to injury. Myxomatous valvular remodeling is associated with characteristic histopathologic features. Changes include expansion of extracellular matrix with glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans; valvular interstitial cell alteration; and attenuation or loss of the collagen-laden fibrosa layer. These lead to malformation of the mitral apparatus, biomechanical dysfunction, and mitral incompetence. Mitral regurgitation is the most common manifestation of myxomatous valve disease and in advanced stages, associated volume overload promotes progressive valvular regurgitation, left atrial and left ventricular remodeling, atrial tears, chordal rupture, and congestive heart failure. Future studies are necessary to identify clinical-pathologic correlates that track disease severity and progression, detect valve dysfunction, and facilitate risk stratification. It remains unresolved whether, or to what extent, the pathobiology of myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is the same between breeds of dogs, between canines and humans, and how these features are related to aging and genetics.
response: Mitral valve competence depends on coordinated function of the mitral annulus, valve leaflets, chordae tendineae, papillary muscles, and left atrial/ventricular myocardium. In dogs, myxomatous mitral valve degeneration is common with aging, reflecting canine valve susceptibility to injury, and involves characteristic remodeling: extracellular matrix expansion with glycosaminoglycans/proteoglycans, changes in valvular interstitial cells, and thinning or loss of the collagen-rich fibrosa layer. These alterations deform the mitral apparatus, impair biomechanics, and cause mitral incompetence, most commonly presenting as mitral regurgitation. In advanced disease, volume overload drives worsening regurgitation and leads to left atrial/ventricular remodeling, atrial tears, chordal rupture, and congestive heart failure. Further studies are needed to link clinical and pathologic findings to severity/progression, improve detection and risk stratification, and clarify similarities across dog breeds and between dogs and humans, including relationships to aging and genetics.

query: Staphylococcus pseudintermedius is a commensal bacterium colonizing dog skin and mucosal sites<sup>1</sup>, and it is the predominant cause of canine pyoderma and otitis externa<sup>2</sup>. These common infections represent the main reason for antimicrobial prescription in dogs<sup>3</sup>. Over the last decade, methicillin-resistant S. pseudintermedius (MRSP) has been reported worldwide<sup>4</sup>, including sporadic infections in humans in contact with dogs<sup>5,6</sup>. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is another pathogen frequently involved in canine integumentary infections, in particular otitis externa<sup>7</sup>. P. aeruginosa is resistant to most antibiotics used in veterinary medicine. The presence of this pathogen and the increasing frequency of multidrug-resistant MRSP<sup>8</sup>, make treatment of dogs with integumentary infections difficult or even impossible in some cases<sup>9</sup>. In light of the few treatment options available against these pathogens, new therapeutic agents are needed, preferably drugs restricted to veterinary use and with a narrow spectrum<sup>10</sup>. This would limit their impact on the commensal microbiota<sup>11</sup>.
response: Staphylococcus pseudintermedius commonly colonizes dogs’ skin and mucosal sites and is the main cause of canine pyoderma and otitis externa, which are leading reasons for antimicrobial prescriptions in dogs. Methicillin-resistant S. pseudintermedius (MRSP) has spread worldwide and has occasionally infected humans who are in contact with dogs. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is another frequent cause of canine integumentary infections, especially otitis externa, and is resistant to most veterinary antibiotics. Together with the rising occurrence of multidrug-resistant MRSP, this makes treatment difficult or sometimes impossible, creating a need for new therapeutic agents—ideally veterinary-restricted, narrow-spectrum drugs to reduce disruption of commensal microbiota.

query: Canine atopic dermatitis is a complex disease that is often treated by multiple therapies either at the same time or over time. Most studies regarding efficacy are based on evaluating these drugs as sole therapy. Monotherapy is not frequently used in clinical practice because combination therapy is often necessary or more beneficial. The most common therapeutic interventions for CAD include the following: glucocorticoids, ciclosporin, antihistamines, essential fatty acids (EFAs) and allergen-specific immunotherapy (ASIT). Historically, glucocorticoids have been the most commonly prescribed medication for treatment of CAD, but even these are often used in conjunction with other therapies, such as bathing, antihistamines and fatty acids. Antihistamines have been described as having little benefit in managing atopic dermatitis;[3-5] however, antihistamines remain one of the most frequently used medications to treat the pruritus associated with CAD in dogs. Essential fatty acids, being commonly available and relatively inexpensive, are also frequently used in combination with other therapies. The slow onset of improvement with ASIT in dogs frequently results in the concurrent use of other therapies, at least during the first few months of therapy. Intermittent antimicrobial therapy is often necessary to eliminate complicating secondary infections. The most recent recommendation of the International Task Force on Canine Atopic Dermatitis focuses on this concept of a multimodal treatment approach.[4] A multimodal treatment approach will provide increased benefit to the dog by intervening at several different points along the pathway from exposure to an offending antigen to development of clinical signs (pruritus, superficial pyoderma and otitis externa).
response: Canine atopic dermatitis (CAD) is a complex condition typically managed with multiple therapies used concurrently or sequentially, although most efficacy studies evaluate drugs as monotherapy, which is uncommon in practice. Common CAD treatments include glucocorticoids, ciclosporin, antihistamines, essential fatty acids (EFAs), and allergen-specific immunotherapy (ASIT). Glucocorticoids have historically been most prescribed but are often combined with bathing, antihistamines, and fatty acids. Antihistamines are reported to offer little benefit for atopic dermatitis yet are still frequently used to relieve pruritus. EFAs are widely used because they are readily available and inexpensive, usually as adjuncts. Because ASIT improves slowly, other therapies are often used alongside it, especially early in treatment. Intermittent antimicrobial therapy is often needed for secondary infections. The International Task Force on CAD recommends a multimodal approach to target multiple points from allergen exposure to clinical signs (pruritus, superficial pyoderma, otitis externa), providing greater overall benefit.

query: Noroviruses (NoV) are members of the Caliciviridae family, and are important pathogens that cause gastroenteritis in children and young animals (Karst and Tibbetts, 2016; Villabruna et al., 2019). NoV can be classified into seven genogroups (GI to GVII) that are further divided into more than 40 genotypes based on their major capsid protein (VP1) sequences (Vinje and Doern, 2015). Four distinct genotypes (GIV.2, GVI.1, GVI.2 and GVII) have been previously identified in canine norovirus(CNV) (Scipioni et al., 2008; Villabruna et al., 2019). Extensive epidemiological data suggest that CNV is a diarrhea-causing pathogen of canine, however, with no suitable cell culture system for CNV, the precise pathogenicity of CNV has not been investigated. Currently, CNV strains have been detected in at least eight countries with a wide geographical distribution, GIV.2 strains have been detected in six countries (Martella et al., 2008; Ntafis et al., 2010; Lyoo et al., 2018; Soma et al., 2015; Mesquita and Nascimento, 2012b), GVI.1 strains have been detected in four countries (Mesquita et al., 2010; Martella et al., 2009; Ford-Siltz et al., 2019), GVI.2 strains have been detected in five countries (Bodnar et al., 2017; Mesquita and Nascimento, 2012a; Mihalov-Kovács et al., 2014), and GVII strains have only been detected in Hong Kong, China (Tse et al., 2012).
response: Noroviruses (NoV) in the Caliciviridae family are important causes of gastroenteritis in children and young animals. They are classified into seven genogroups (GI–GVII) and over 40 genotypes based on VP1 sequences. Canine norovirus (CNV) has four identified genotypes (GIV.2, GVI.1, GVI.2, GVII). Epidemiological evidence indicates CNV causes diarrhea in dogs, but its precise pathogenicity remains unclear due to the lack of a suitable cell culture system. CNV has been detected in at least eight countries: GIV.2 in six countries, GVI.1 in four, GVI.2 in five, and GVII only in Hong Kong, China.

query: Aging canine subjects exhibit similar naturally occurring neuropathology to aging humans, such as the development of beta-amyloid plaques (Aβ) and tauopathy unlike other commonly used translational models such as mice and rats (Cummings et al., 1996, 1993; Head, 2013; Mazzatenta et al., 2017). Due to thousands of years of contact with humans and domestication, canines and humans have a unique relationship sharing social cues, dietary and other environmental stimuli (Hoffman et al., 2018). Canine models also provide a useful evolutionary intermediate model to that of rodents featuring a gyrencephalic brain and convergent sociocognitive skills with humans (Berns et al., 2012; Thompkins et al., 2016). Though research into differences in longevity among canines is still ongoing, selective breeding and diverse features within the canine population have potential for classifying specific neuropathology phenotypes (Kaeberlein et al., 2016; Urfer et al., 2019). In addition, studies have found the aging canine brain exhibits cortical atrophy (Tapp et al., 2006), accumulates beta-amyloid with age (Kumar et al., 2018), and can develop progressive cognitive decline with memory dysfunctions as seen in Alzheimer's disease (Prpar Mihevc and Majdic, 2019). As in human cohorts, a high percentage of dogs exhibit age-related cognitive decline in memory, mood and processing speed related cognitive domains (Cotman and Head, 2008; Head, 2013). An estimated  $60\%$  of older dogs ( $>8$  years old) are affected by canine cognitive dysfunction (CCD) (Fast et al., 2013) which is defined by a decline in cognitive function accompanied by cerebral degeneration and decreases in cortical volume (Kimotsuki et al., 2005), similar to that observed in mild cognitive impairment as related to early Alzheimer's disease in humans (Schütt et al., 2016). For these reasons, canines are the subject of increasing research as a naturally occurring model of human aging.
response: Aging dogs develop naturally occurring brain pathologies similar to aging humans—including beta-amyloid plaques and tauopathy—unlike common rodent models. Because of long domestication and close contact with humans, dogs share social cues and environmental influences with people, and they offer an intermediate translational model with a gyrencephalic brain and convergent sociocognitive skills. Selective breeding and diversity within dog populations may help classify specific neuropathology phenotypes. Studies show aging canine brains exhibit cortical atrophy, increasing beta-amyloid accumulation with age, and progressive cognitive decline with memory dysfunction resembling Alzheimer’s disease; many dogs also show age-related declines in memory, mood, and processing speed. About 60% of dogs older than 8 years are estimated to have canine cognitive dysfunction (CCD), characterized by cognitive decline with cerebral degeneration and reduced cortical volume, paralleling mild cognitive impairment/early Alzheimer’s in humans. Consequently, dogs are increasingly researched as a naturally occurring model of human aging.

query: The regenerative capability of the mammalian spinal cord is very limited [12]. Complete regeneration would require production of new neurons and glia with successful reinnervation of the correct targets in order to restore function. There is still no therapy tailored to this complex scenario. The discovery of resident stem cells within the nervous system has created the promise of new therapies [13].
